entry.title: Fair Division 8 Strategic Aspects of Fair Divison
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate strategic aspects of fair division, considering Pure Nash equilibria and fairness.

Activities: Review the paper Allocating Indivisible Goods to Strategic Agents: Pure Nash Equilibria and Fairness.

Abstract

What if the agents are strategic?

Goal: whether there exist mechanisms that have pure Nash Equilibria. If so, what is the fairness guarantee for these equilibria?

Focus on EF1, EFX. The answer is positive.

2 algorithms:

  • round-robin (computing EF1 allocation). Its pure Nash equilibria are EF1 w.r.t. true values.
  • cut and choose algorithm (computing EFX allocation for 2 agents). The corresponding allocations not only are EFX, but also satisfy MMS. A weaker result holds for any mechanism for two agents that always has pure Nash equilibria, which all induce EFX allocations.

Introduction

This paper is interested in exploring the problem from a game-theoretic perspective.

Assume that the agents are strategic, i.e., agent may misreport its true valuation for the goods to end up with a bundle of higher total value.

The algorithm takes the input values (which are probably misreported) the agents declare.

The existence of truthful mechanisms. Even for 2 agents, truthfulness and fairness are incompatible by providing impossibility results for every non-trivial fairness notion. So next natural question: Is it possible to have non-truthful mechanisms that are guaranteed to have equilibria with these equilibria always inducing fair allocations?

Contributions

The class of mechanisms that are implementable in polynomial time have pure Nash equilibria for every instance and provide some fairness guarantee as the allocations they produce in their equilibria is non-empty.

  • Round-robin has pure Nash equilibria for every instance, and these equilibria induce allocations that are known properties of round-robin with a novel recursive construction of ‚Äúnicely structured‚Äù bid profiles.
  • Mod-Cut&Choose has pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents, and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX and MMS w.r.t. the underlying true values. For the case of 2 agents, MMS allocations are always EFX allocations; i.e., MMS fairness is stronger. In non-strategic setting, for any œµ>0\epsilon\gt 0œµ>0, there are instances in which the output of Mod-Cut&Choose is not (5/6+œµ)(5/6+\epsilon)(5/6+œµ)-MMS allocation.
  • A weaker result. All mechanisms that have pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX provide stronger MMS guarantees in these allocations than generic EFX allocations do.

Related Works

Omitted

Preliminaries

Goods MMM, agents NNN.

Valuations v\mathbf vv are additive, non-negative.

All the goods must be allocated.

Allocation AAA.

Preference ‚âΩi,‚âªi\succcurlyeq_i,\succ_i‚âΩi‚Äã,‚âªi‚Äã

Fairness Notions

EF, EF1, EFX

PROP

MMS, Œ±\alphaŒ±-MMS

üéØü§îTheorem 1. For n=2n=2n=2, any MMS allocation is also an EFX allocation.

For n=2n=2n=2, MMS allocation is indeed PMMS allocation. Any PMMS allocation is EFX allocation.

üéØü§îTheorem 2. For n=2n=2n=2, any EFX is also 2/32/32/3-MMS allocation. The bound is tight for any m‚â•4m\ge4m‚â•4.

Mechanisms and Equilibria

An allocation mechanism M\mathcal MM is an algorithm that takes its input from the agents and allocates all the goods to them.

Assume each agent iii reports a bid vector bib_ibi‚Äã, where bij‚â•0b_{ij}\ge0bij‚Äã‚â•0 is the value agent iii claims to have for good gjg_jgj‚Äã. M\mathcal MM takes bid profile b\mathbf bb of bid vectors and outputs an allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b).

Assume that the agents are strategic (They may misreport their true values in order to get a bundle with higher value).

Hence, in general, bi‚â†(vi(g1),‚ãØ‚Äâ,vi(gm))\mathbf b_i\neq(v_i(g_1),\cdots,v_i(g_m))bi‚ÄãÓÄ†=(vi‚Äã(g1‚Äã),‚ãØ,vi‚Äã(gm‚Äã)).

Focus: Fairness guarantees of the pure Nash equilibria of the mechanisms.

Best response.

The profile b\mathbf bb is pure Nash equilibria (PNE) if for each i‚ààNi\in Ni‚ààN, bi\mathbf b_ibi‚Äã is a best response to b‚àíi\mathbf b_{-i}b‚àíi‚Äã.

When b\mathbf bb is a PNE and the allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b) has a fairness guarantee, we say that b\mathbf bb is EF1.

Some remarks:

  1. Here we don‚Äôt consider too much about the complexity of mechanism.
  2. Any PNE of any Œ±\alphaŒ±-approximation mechanism for computing MMS allocation is an Œ±\alphaŒ±-MMS allocation. This is also true for PROP.

Fairness of Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin

Round-Robin Mechanism takes a bid profile as input. Then RR should also take a permutation NNN as an input to determine the priority of the agents.

WLOG, let the permutation be 1,2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,n1,2,\cdots,n1,2,‚ãØ,n.

It‚Äôs known that RR outputs EF1 allocation when all agents have additive valuation functions.

Pseudo-code: Omitted, can refer to here.

ü§îLemma 1. If bi\mathbf b_ibi‚Äã is the truthful bid of agent iii, then the allocation A\mathcal AA returned by Round-Robin is EF1 from iii‚Äôs perspective. Moreover, if i=1i=1i=1, then A\mathcal AA is EF from agent 111‚Äôs perspective, i.e., ‚àÄj‚ààN,v1(A1)‚â•v1(Aj)\forall j\in N,v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(A_j)‚àÄj‚ààN,v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â•v1‚Äã(Aj‚Äã).

Truth-telling is not a Pure Nash equilibria. Example omitted.

RR is known to have PNE for any instance in which no agent values two goods exactly the same and at least some such equilibria are easy to compute. Strict preference ranking is convenient as it reduces the number of corner case with which one has to deal. This results can be extended to general additive valuation functions.

For only 2 agents, all PNE of round-robin are EF1 w.r.t. the real valuation functions. Complex even for n=3n=3n=3.

üéØü§îTheorem 3. For any fair division instance with 2 agents, every PNE of RR is EF1 w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã.

Assume there exists a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(b_1,b_2)b=(b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã) s.t., in the allocation (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1‚Äã,A2‚Äã) returned by RR(b\mathbf bb), at least one of the agents is not EF1-satisfied.

  • If agent 1 is not EF1-satisfied, then is not EF-satisfied either. Because PROP and EF are equivalent for n=2n=2n=2, we have v1(A1)<v1(M)/2v_1(A_1)\lt v_1(M)/2v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)<v1‚Äã(M)/2. According to Lemma 1, no matter what agent 2 bids, if agent 1 reports true values, the resulting allocation is EF from the agent‚Äôs perspective. So, if (A1‚Ä≤,A2‚Ä≤)(A_1',A_2')(A1‚Ä≤‚Äã,A2‚Ä≤‚Äã) is the allocation after agent 1 deviates to the agent‚Äôs true values, it is EF-satisfied to agent 1, which contradicts the assumption before.

  • If agent 2 is not EF1-satisfied. Let h1h_1h1‚Äã be the good that agent 1 takes during the first round of RR and g‚àó‚ààarg‚Å°max‚Å°h‚ààA1v2(h)g^*\in\arg\max_{h\in A_1}v_2(h)g‚àó‚ààargmaxh‚ààA1‚Äã‚Äãv2‚Äã(h) be the highest valued good in A1A_1A1‚Äã according to agent 2.

    Since agent 2 is not EF1-satisfied, v2(A2)<v2(A1‚ï≤{g‚àó})<v2(A1‚ï≤{h1})v_2(A_2)\lt v_2(A_1\diagdown\{g^*\})\lt v_2(A_1\diagdown\{h_1\})v2‚Äã(A2‚Äã)<v2‚Äã(A1‚Äã‚ï≤{g‚àó})<v2‚Äã(A1‚Äã‚ï≤{h1‚Äã}). This implies that (A1‚ï≤{h1},A2)(A_1\diagdown\{h_1\},A_2)(A1‚Äã‚ï≤{h1‚Äã},A2‚Äã) of M‚ï≤{h1}M\diagdown\{h_1\}M‚ï≤{h1‚Äã} is not EF-satisfied to agent 2.

    Thus v2(A2)‚â§v2(M‚ï≤{h1})/2v_2(A_2)\le v_2(M\diagdown\{h_1\})/2v2‚Äã(A2‚Äã)‚â§v2‚Äã(M‚ï≤{h1‚Äã})/2 by the equivalence between EF and PROP for n=2n=2n=2.

    Then suppose agent 2 deviates to reporting the agent‚Äôs true values and let (A1‚Ä≤,A2‚Ä≤)(A_1',A_2')(A1‚Ä≤‚Äã,A2‚Ä≤‚Äã) be the resulting allocation. Since the allocation of h1h_1h1‚Äã is not affected by deviation, it is still given to agent 1 in 1st step of RR. Thus the execution of the mechanism would be exactly the same if the input v2v_2v2‚Äã had higher priority than agent 1. This would result in EF w.r.t agent 2 to (A1‚Ä≤‚ï≤{h1},A2‚Ä≤)(A_1'\diagdown\{h_1\},A_2')(A1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚ï≤{h1‚Äã},A2‚Ä≤‚Äã). We have v2(A2‚Ä≤)‚â•v2(A1‚Ä≤‚ï≤{h1})v_2(A_2')\ge v_2(A_1'\diagdown\{h_1\})v2‚Äã(A2‚Ä≤‚Äã)‚â•v2‚Äã(A1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚ï≤{h1‚Äã}). Therefore v2(A2)‚â•v2(M‚ï≤{h1})/2>v2(A2)v_2(A_2)\ge v_2(M\diagdown\{h_1\})/2\gt v_2(A_2)v2‚Äã(A2‚Äã)‚â•v2‚Äã(M‚ï≤{h1‚Äã})/2>v2‚Äã(A2‚Äã) contradicts the fact that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

The proof doesn‚Äôt work for n‚â•3n\ge3n‚â•3 because there is no equivalence between EF and PROP.

Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin for Any Number of Agents

Agent 1 have no envy toward any other bundle whenever agent 1 bids truthfully. Agent 1 is EF-satisfied.

No matter what agent 1 bids, it is possible to ‚Äúreplace‚Äù the agent with an imaginary version of agent, who

  1. does not affect the allocation
  2. bids truthfully
  3. considers the bundles of the allocation to be as valuable as the original agent 1 though they were

üéØü§îTheorem 4. For any fair division instance I\mathcal II, every PNE of round-robin is EF1 w.r.t. v\mathbf vv.

Proving it reduces to showing that the agent who picks first in the round-robin is EF-satisfied as long as the agent bids a best response to other agent‚Äô bids.

From theorem 5, we know for PNE input, allocation returned by round-robin is EF-satisfied to agent 1.

Fix an agent ‚Ñì,‚Ñì‚â•2\ell,\ell\ge2‚Ñì,‚Ñì‚â•2. For i‚àà[‚Ñì‚àí1]i\in[\ell-1]i‚àà[‚Ñì‚àí1], let hih_ihi‚Äã be the good that agent iii claims to be the agent‚Äôs favorite among the goods that are available when it is the agent‚Äôs turn in the first round, that is hi=arg‚Å°max‚Å°h‚ààM‚ï≤{h1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,hi‚àí1}bi(h)h_i=\arg\max_{h\in M\diagdown\{h_1,\cdots,h_{i-1}\}}b_i(h)hi‚Äã=argmaxh‚ààM‚ï≤{h1‚Äã,‚ãØ,hi‚àí1‚Äã}‚Äãbi‚Äã(h). Before ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì is first assigned a good, all goods in H={h1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,h‚Ñì‚àí1}H=\{h_1,\cdots,h_{\ell-1}\}H={h1‚Äã,‚ãØ,h‚Ñì‚àí1‚Äã} have been allocated.

Consider the instance I‚Ä≤=(N,M‚ï≤H,v‚Ä≤)\mathcal I'=(N,M\diagdown H,\mathbf v')I‚Ä≤=(N,M‚ï≤H,v‚Ä≤) in which all goods in HHH are missing.

Consider round-robin on such instance, it starts with agent ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì and the follows the indices in increasing order.

Claim that the bid b‚Ñì‚Ä≤\mathbf b_\ell'b‚Ñì‚Ä≤‚Äã is a best response for agent ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì assuming that the restricted bid vectors of all the other agents are fixed.

‚Ä¶

Proof is analogous to induction?

üéØü§îTheorem 5. For any fair division instance I\mathcal II, if the reported bid vector b1\mathbf b_1b1‚Äã of agent 1 is a best response to the bid vector b‚àí1\mathbf b_{-1}b‚àí1‚Äã of all other players, then agent 1 is EF-satisfied with output.

In PNE, each agent‚Äôs bid is a BR to other agents‚Äô bids. Thus theorem 5 is a corollary to lemma 2.

ü§îLemma 2. Suppose that v1v_1v1‚Äã induces a strict preference ranking on the goods. Let b=(b1,b‚àí1)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_{-1})b=(b1‚Äã,b‚àí1‚Äã). Then, there exists a valuation function v1‚àóv_1^*v1‚àó‚Äã with the following properties:

  • If b1‚àó\mathbf b_1^*b1‚àó‚Äã is the truthful bid for v1‚àóv_1^*v1‚àó‚Äã, then round-robin(b\mathbf bb) and round-robin(b1‚àó,b‚àí1\mathbf b_1^*,\mathbf b_{-1}b1‚àó‚Äã,b‚àí1‚Äã) produce the same allocation AAA.
  • v1‚àó(A1)=v1(A1)v_1^*(A_1)=v_1(A_1)v1‚àó‚Äã(A1‚Äã)=v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)
  • For every good g‚ààM‚ï≤A1g\in M\diagdown A_1g‚ààM‚ï≤A1‚Äã, it holds that v1‚àó(g)=v1(g)v_1^*(g)=v_1(g)v1‚àó‚Äã(g)=v1‚Äã(g).

Proof of Lemma 2.

Recall that k=‚åàm/n‚åâk=\lceil m/n\rceilk=‚åàm/n‚åâ, we have kkk total rounds.

Let ‚âª1\succ_1‚âª1‚Äã be the preference ranking induced by b1\mathbf b_1b1‚Äã and consider all the goods according to this ranking: h1‚âª1h2‚âª1‚ãØ‚âª1hmh_1\succ_1h_2\succ_1\cdots\succ_1h_mh1‚Äã‚âª1‚Äãh2‚Äã‚âª1‚Äã‚ãØ‚âª1‚Äãhm‚Äã. Let n1=1<n2<‚ãØ<nkn_1=1\lt n_2\lt\cdots\lt n_kn1‚Äã=1<n2‚Äã<‚ãØ<nk‚Äã be the indices in this ordering of the goods assigned to agent 1 by round-robin(b\mathbf bb). In round rrr, agent 1 receives good hnrh_{n_r}hnr‚Äã‚Äã. Thus A1={hn1,hn2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,hnk}A_1=\{h_{n_1},h_{n_2},\cdots,h_{n_k}\}A1‚Äã={hn1‚Äã‚Äã,hn2‚Äã‚Äã,‚ãØ,hnk‚Äã‚Äã}.

Recursively construct v1‚àóv_1^*v1‚àó‚Äã from v1v_1v1‚Äã over the rounds of RR. We define a sequence of intermediate bid vector b1r\mathbf b_1^rb1r‚Äã and valuation functions v1rv_1^rv1r‚Äã. One for each round rrr starting from the last round kkk, so that v_1^*=v_1^1\and\mathbf b_1^*=\mathbf b_1^1. For defining each b1r\mathbf b_1^rb1r‚Äã, we use a number of auxiliary bid vectors. For any round rrr we maintain that

  1. v1r(A1)=v1(A1)v_1^r(A_1)=v_1(A_1)v1r‚Äã(A1‚Äã)=v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)
  2. v1r(g)=v1(g)‚àÄg‚ààM‚ï≤A1v_1^r(g)=v_1(g)\forall g\in M\diagdown A_1v1r‚Äã(g)=v1‚Äã(g)‚àÄg‚ààM‚ï≤A1‚Äã
  3. b1r\mathbf b_1^rb1r‚Äã is truthful from round rrr w.r.t. v1rv_1^rv1r‚Äã, meaning that for every good that is no better than hnrh_{n_r}hnr‚Äã‚Äã, according to the preference ranking ‚âª1r\succ_1^r‚âª1r‚Äã induced by b1r\mathbf b_1^rb1r‚Äã. Formally gÃ∏‚âª1rhnr‚áíb1r(g)=v1r(g)g\not\succ_1^rh_{n_r}\Rarr\mathbf b_1^r(g)=v_1^r(g)gÓÄ†‚âª1r‚Äãhnr‚Äã‚Äã‚áíb1r‚Äã(g)=v1r‚Äã(g).
  4. The preference ranking ‚âª1r\succ_1^r‚âª1r‚Äã is identical to ‚âª1\succ_1‚âª1‚Äã up to good hnr‚àí1h_{n_r-1}hnr‚Äã‚àí1‚Äã.
  5. min‚Å°g,h‚ààM,g‚â†h‚à£v1r(g)‚àív1r(h)‚à£>0\min_{g,h\in M,g\neq h}|v_1^r(g)-v_1^r(h)|\gt0ming,h‚ààM,gÓÄ†=h‚Äã‚à£v1r‚Äã(g)‚àív1r‚Äã(h)‚à£>0. (strict preference?)

Focus on the last round kkk. Let Œªk\lambda_kŒªk‚Äã be the most valuable available good for v1v_1v1‚Äã at very beginning of the round. It is easy to see hnk=Œªkh_{n_k}=\lambda_khnk‚Äã‚Äã=Œªk‚Äã. (If not, by increasing the agent‚Äôs bid for Œªk\lambda_kŒªk‚Äã be above the agent‚Äôs bid for hnkh_{n_k}hnk‚Äã‚Äã, agent 1 would end up with the bundle {hn1,hn2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Œªk}\{h_{n_1},h_{n_2},\cdots,\lambda_k\}{hn1‚Äã‚Äã,hn2‚Äã‚Äã,‚ãØ,Œªk‚Äã}), which strictly improve over A1A_1A1‚Äã and contradict the fact that b1\mathbf b_1b1‚Äã is BR.

We construct the auxiliary bid bÀâ1k\bar{\mathbf b}_1^kbÀâ1k‚Äã by moving up ‚âª1\succ_1‚âª1‚Äã every good that is more valuable than Œªk\lambda_kŒªk‚Äã but comes after it in ‚âª1\succ_1‚âª1‚Äã.

‚Ä¶

A long tough proof

Definition of partial slide: Let {q1,q2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,qm}\{q_1,q_2,\cdots,q_m\}{q1‚Äã,q2‚Äã,‚ãØ,qm‚Äã} be a renaming of the goods according to ‚âª\succ‚âª. We say ‚âª\succ‚âª and ‚âª‚Ä≤\succ'‚âª‚Ä≤ are within a partial slide of each other if there exist x,y‚àà[m],x‚â§yx,y\in[m],x\le yx,y‚àà[m],x‚â§y s.t.

q1‚âªq2‚âª‚ãØ‚âªqmq1‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qx‚àí1‚âª‚Ä≤qx+1‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qy‚âª‚Ä≤qx‚âª‚Ä≤qy+1‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qmq_1\succ q_2\succ\cdots\succ q_m\\q_1\succ'\cdots\succ'q_{x-1}\succ'q_{x+1}\succ'\cdots\succ'q_y\succ'q_x\succ'q_{y+1}\succ'\cdots\succ'q_mq1‚Äã‚âªq2‚Äã‚âª‚ãØ‚âªqm‚Äãq1‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qx‚àí1‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤qx+1‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qy‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤qx‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤qy+1‚Äã‚âª‚Ä≤‚ãØ‚âª‚Ä≤qm‚Äã

Let Mt(b)M_t(\mathbf b)Mt‚Äã(b) denote the set of available goods right after t‚àí1t-1t‚àí1 goods have been allocated in a run of round-robin(b\mathbf bb).

Lemma 3 states that, at beginning of each step, there is at most one difference between the sets of unallocated goods, and this is difference is either fixed or passed on to the next step, possibly slightly altered.

ü§îLemma 3. Let b\mathbf bb and b‚Ä≤\mathbf b'b‚Ä≤ be two profiles s.t. the corresponding induced preference ranking ‚âªi\succ_i‚âªi‚Äã and ‚âªi‚Ä≤\succ'_i‚âªi‚Ä≤‚Äã of agent iii are within a partial slide of each other. Then

‚à£Mt(b)‚ï≤Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚à£=‚à£Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt(b)‚à£‚â§1|M_t(\mathbf b)\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b')|=|M_t(\mathbf b')\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b)|\le1‚à£Mt‚Äã(b)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚à£=‚à£Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b)‚à£‚â§1

for all t‚àà[m+1]t\in[m+1]t‚àà[m+1].

Case 1: Mt(b)=Mt(b‚Ä≤)M_t(\mathbf b)=M_t(\mathbf b')Mt‚Äã(b)=Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤).

  • No matter who jjj is and what g,g‚Ä≤g,g'g,g‚Ä≤ are. It always holds either
    • ‚à£Mt(b)‚ï≤Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚à£=‚à£Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt(b)‚à£=‚àÖ|M_t(\mathbf b)\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b')|=|M_t(\mathbf b')\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b)|=\empty‚à£Mt‚Äã(b)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚à£=‚à£Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b)‚à£=‚àÖ or
    • Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt(b)={g}M_t(\mathbf b')\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b)=\{g\}Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b)={g} or
    • Mt(b)‚ï≤Mt(b‚Ä≤)={g‚Ä≤}M_t(\mathbf b)\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b')=\{g'\}Mt‚Äã(b)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)={g‚Ä≤}
  • Thus Lemma 3 holds in this case.

Because ‚âªi,‚âªi‚Ä≤\succ_i,\succ_i'‚âªi‚Äã,‚âªi‚Ä≤‚Äã are within a partial slide of each other, there exists a unique good s‚ààMs\in Ms‚ààM that goes from a better position in ‚âªi\succ_i‚âªi‚Äã to a worst position in ‚âªi‚Ä≤\succ_i'‚âªi‚Ä≤‚Äã

Claim 1. Suppose that t‚àót_*t‚àó‚Äã is the first time step in which the good Œ≥\gammaŒ≥ allocated in round-robin(b\mathbf bb) is different from the good Œ≥‚Ä≤\gamma'Œ≥‚Ä≤ allocated in round-robin(b‚Ä≤)(\mathbf b')(b‚Ä≤). Then Œ≥=s\gamma=sŒ≥=s. Proof of claim 1 is omitted here.

Case 2: M_t(\mathbf b)\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b')=\{h\}\and M_t(\mathbf b')\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b)=\{h'\}.

  • When g=h\or g'=h', it‚Äôs easy to complete the induction.
  • If g=h\and g'\neq h', we have Mt(b)‚ï≤Mt(b‚Ä≤)={g‚Ä≤}M_t(\mathbf b)\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b')=\{g'\}Mt‚Äã(b)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)={g‚Ä≤}.
  • If g\neq h\and g'=h', analogously we have Mt(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt(b)={h‚Ä≤}M_t(\mathbf b')\diagdown M_t(\mathbf b)=\{h'\}Mt‚Äã(b‚Ä≤)‚ï≤Mt‚Äã(b)={h‚Ä≤}
  • The sub-case g\neq h\and g'\neq h' can‚Äôt happen, proof by contradiction.

EFX Equilibria: The Case of 2 Agents

When the agents are not strategic, EFX exist when n‚â§3n\le3n‚â§3.

Even for n=3n=3n=3, we are not sure whether there is a polynomial time algorithm.

We consider n=2n=2n=2 in this paper.

Mechanism with EFX Nash Equilibria

A polynomial time algorithm that outputs EFX allocation when we have 2 agents: modified cut-and-choose algorithm in which cut is a variant of envy-cycle-elimination. In this paper, we refer it as ‚ÄúMod-Cut&Choose‚Äù.

This mechanism is not truthful.

This paper shows that although its non-truthful, Mod-Cut&Choose always has at least one PNE for any instance, and all its equilibria are MMS and EFX. (MMS for 2 agent is PMMS, PMMS is EFX.)

Pseudo-code

input: b1,b2\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã

  1. (E1,E2)=(‚àÖ,‚àÖ)(E_1,E_2)=(\empty,\empty)(E1‚Äã,E2‚Äã)=(‚àÖ,‚àÖ)
  2. (h1,h2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,hm)(h_1,h_2,\cdots,h_m)(h1‚Äã,h2‚Äã,‚ãØ,hm‚Äã) is MMM, sorted in decreasing order w.r.t. v1v_1v1‚Äã.
  3. for i=1,‚ãØmi=1,\cdots mi=1,‚ãØm do // agent 1 partition the bundles
    • j=arg‚Å°min‚Å°k‚àà[2]b1(Ek)j=\arg\min_{k\in[2]}\mathbf b_1(E_k)j=argmink‚àà[2]‚Äãb1‚Äã(Ek‚Äã)
    • Ej=Ej‚à™{hi}E_j=E_j\cup\{h_i\}Ej‚Äã=Ej‚Äã‚à™{hi‚Äã}
  4. ‚Ñì=arg‚Å°max‚Å°k‚àà[2]b2(Ek)\ell=\arg\max_{k\in[2]}\mathbf b_2(E_k)‚Ñì=argmaxk‚àà[2]‚Äãb2‚Äã(Ek‚Äã) // agent 2 chooses the bundle
  5. return A=(M‚ï≤E‚Ñì,E‚Ñì)\mathcal A=(M\diagdown E_\ell,E_\ell)A=(M‚ï≤E‚Ñì‚Äã,E‚Ñì‚Äã)

Mod-Cut&Choose algorithm is 5/65/65/6-MMS (tight).

ü§îLemma 4. Let (X1,X2)(X_1,X_2)(X1‚Äã,X2‚Äã) be a partition of MMM. Agent 111, by bidding accordingly, can force Mod-Cut&Choose to construct E1,E2E_1,E_2E1‚Äã,E2‚Äã in for loop s.t. {E1,E2}={X1,X2}\{E_1,E_2\}=\{X_1,X_2\}{E1‚Äã,E2‚Äã}={X1‚Äã,X2‚Äã}.

Agent 111 can report in order to create the desired partition (X1,X2)(X_1,X_2)(X1‚Äã,X2‚Äã) or its permutation (X2,X1)(X_2,X_1)(X2‚Äã,X1‚Äã).

Case 1: One set has all the goods. Agent 111 declares zero value for all the goods. Then all the goods goes to E1E_1E1‚Äã.

Case 2: One set has m‚àí1m-1m‚àí1 goods. Agent 1 declares value 111 for the good that is contained in the set with cardinality 111, and for every good that is contained in the set with cardinality m‚àí1m-1m‚àí1, the agent declares value 1m‚àí1\frac{1}{m-1}m‚àí11‚Äã. The first good is added in E1E_1E1‚Äã, so E2E_2E2‚Äã is going to get chosen next. According to these values, E2E_2E2‚Äã must get all the remaining goods.

Case 3: The two set have cardinalities k‚â•2k\ge2k‚â•2 and m‚àík‚â•2m-k\ge2m‚àík‚â•2. Agent 111 declares value of one for one of the goods that are contained in the set with cardinality kkk. For every good that is contained in the m‚àíkm-km‚àík set, the agent declares a value of 1+œµm‚àík\frac{1+\epsilon}{m-k}m‚àík1+œµ‚Äã where 0<œµ<1m‚àík‚àí10\lt\epsilon\lt\frac{1}{m-k-1}0<œµ<m‚àík‚àí11‚Äã, For the rest of the goods, the agent declares œµk‚àí1\frac{\epsilon}{k-1}k‚àí1œµ‚Äã.

Agent 111 can manipulate bidding to produce min‚Å°{v1(E1),v1(E2)}=Œº1\min\{v_1(E_1),v_1(E_2)\}=\mu_1min{v1‚Äã(E1‚Äã),v1‚Äã(E2‚Äã)}=Œº1‚Äã.

Corollary: Agent 111 can force Mod-Cut&Choose mechanism to construct Œº1\mu_1Œº1‚Äã-partition in for loop.

üéØü§îTheorem 6. For any instance I=({1,2},M,v)\mathcal I=(\{1,2\},M,\mathbf v)I=({1,2},M,v), the Mod-Cut&Choose has at least one PNE. Every PNE of the mechanism is MMS and EFX w.r.t. valuation function v1,v2v_1,v_2v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã.

Given a partition X=(X1,X2)\mathcal X=(X_1,X_2)X=(X1‚Äã,X2‚Äã), we define a profile (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã) and show that it is a PNE.

Let b2\mathbf b_2b2‚Äã be the truthful bid of agent 2.

Let b1\mathbf b_1b1‚Äã be the bidding vector that results in Mod-Cut&Choose constructing a partition in

arg‚Å°max‚Å°X‚ààŒ†2(M)v1(arg‚Å°min‚Å°X‚ààX(X)).\arg\max_{\mathcal X\in\Pi_2(M)}v_1(\arg\min_{X\in\mathcal X}(X)).argX‚ààŒ†2‚Äã(M)max‚Äãv1‚Äã(argX‚ààXmin‚Äã(X)).

Notice that Œ†2(M)\Pi_2(M)Œ†2‚Äã(M) is finite. By lemma 4, every possible partition can be produced by Mod-Cut&Choose given the appropriate bid vector of agent 111.

So agent 111 forces the partition that maximizes (according v1v_1v1‚Äã) the value of the least desirable bundle according to v2v_2v2‚Äã.

Now it‚Äôs easy to see that given the bidding strategy of agent 222 (truth-telling), there is no deviation for agent 111 that is profitable. Moreover, agent 222 gets the best of the two bundles according to the agent‚Äôs valuation function (truth-telling is dominant strategy for agent 222). Thus, there is no profitable deviation for the agent either. Therefore (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã) is a PNE for I\mathcal II.

Suppose a contradiction that there is a PNE b\mathbf bb, for which an agent iii does not achieve the agent‚Äôs Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã in the allocation returned by Mod-Cut&Choose(b\mathbf bb). If it‚Äôs agent 111, then according to Corollary 111, there is a bid vector b1‚Ä≤\mathbf b_1'b1‚Ä≤‚Äã the agent can report so that the algorithm produces a Œº1\mu_1Œº1‚Äã-partition. By deviating to b1‚Ä≤\mathbf b_1'b1‚Ä≤‚Äã, regardless of the set given to agent 222, agent 111 ends up with a bundle the agent values at least Œº1\mu_1Œº1‚Äã. This would be a strict improvement over the agent‚Äôs current gain, contradicting that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

So it must be the case that agent 222 gets a bundle that strictly less than Œº2\mu_2Œº2‚Äã. Regardless of the partition, by declaring the truthful bid, agent 222 gets a bundle of value at least v2(M)/2v_2(M)/2v2‚Äã(M)/2. Then it‚Äôs immediate to see that this value is at least Œº2\mu_2Œº2‚Äã, which is a contradiction.

So it‚Äôs MMS for 222 agents, thus it‚Äôs PMMS, thus EFX.

The Enhanced Fairness of EFX Nash Equilibria

Consider the class of mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and these equilibria always lead to EFX allocations.

Goal: If these allocations have better fairness guarantees than EFX allocation in general.

2 agents + 4 goods, this paper proved that for every mechanism of this class, all allocations at a PNE are MMS allocations. By Theorem 2, there are instances with just 4 goods in which an EFX allocation is 2/32/32/3-MMS (tight bound).

ü§îLemma 5. Consider an instance with 222 agents and 444 goods. If agent i‚àà[2]i\in[2]i‚àà[2] has strictly positive value for 333 or fewer goods, then in every allocation that is EFX from the agent‚Äôs point of view, agent iii has value at least Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for at most 3 goods. The statement is trivial when there is at most one positively valued good as in this case Œºi=0\mu_i=0Œºi‚Äã=0, and agent iii always gets Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã no matter the bundle that agent gets. When agent has a positive value for two goods, in order to consider the allocation as EFX, the agent must get at least one of them. In this case, the agent also achieves the agent‚Äôs Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã as it is equal to the smaller of the 2 positive values.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for 3 goods, notice that Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã in this case is equal to min‚Å°(\min(min(the largest one, the sum of two smallest values))). If agent iii gets 2 goods, then the agent always derives a value of at least Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã. If agent gets just one good, then this good must have the highest value; otherwise the agent wouldn‚Äôt consider the allocation as EFX. So agent gets value at least Œºi\mu_iŒºi‚Äã.

üéØü§îTheorem 7. Let M\mathcal MM be a mechanism that has PNE for any instance ([2],M,(v1,v2))([2],\mathcal M,(v_1,v_2))([2],M,(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã)) with ‚à£M‚à£=4|\mathcal M|=4‚à£M‚à£=4 and all these equilibria lead to EFX allocations w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã. Then, each such EFX allocation is also an MMS allocation.

Suppose for contradiction. There exists a valuation instance v\mathbf vv for which there is a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)b=(b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã) that produces an EFX allocation (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1‚Äã,A2‚Äã), where, WLOG, v1(A1)<Œº1v_1(A_1)\lt\mu_1v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)<Œº1‚Äã. Rename good to h1,h2,h3,h4h_1,h_2,h_3,h_4h1‚Äã,h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã,h4‚Äã so that valuation is in decreasing order. By lemma 6, A1A_1A1‚Äã must be either a singleton or one of {h2,h3},{h2,h4},{h3,h4}\{h_2,h_3\},\{h_2,h_4\},\{h_3,h_4\}{h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã},{h2‚Äã,h4‚Äã},{h3‚Äã,h4‚Äã}.

  • ‚à£A1‚à£=1|A_1|=1‚à£A1‚Äã‚à£=1. Because (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1‚Äã,A2‚Äã) is an EFX allocation and all goods have positive value according to v1v_1v1‚Äã, it is easy to see that A1={h1}A_1=\{h_1\}A1‚Äã={h1‚Äã}. Then again because we have an EFX allocation, v1(h1)‚â•v1({h2,h3})v_1(h_1)\ge v_1(\{h_2,h_3\})v1‚Äã(h1‚Äã)‚â•v1‚Äã({h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã}). The latter implies v1(A1)‚â•Œº1v_1(A_1)\ge\mu_1v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â•Œº1‚Äã by second inequality of lemma 6.

  • A1={h2,h3}A_1=\{h_2,h_3\}A1‚Äã={h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã}. Because A1A_1A1‚Äã is EFX-satisfied, v1(A1)‚â•v1(h1)v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(h_1)v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â•v1‚Äã(h1‚Äã). Similar to case 1, this implies v1(A1)‚â•Œº1v_1(A_1)\ge\mu_1v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â•Œº1‚Äã.

  • A1={h2,h4}A_1=\{h_2,h_4\}A1‚Äã={h2‚Äã,h4‚Äã} or {h3,h4}\{h_3,h_4\}{h3‚Äã,h4‚Äã}. Consider different v‚àó\mathbf v^*v‚àó, where agents have same values over the goods. The valuation function v‚àóv^*v‚àó is defined

    v‚àó(hj)={1.2¬†j=11¬†j‚àà{2,3}0.1¬†j=4v^*(h_j)=\begin{cases}1.2\ j=1\\1\ j\in\{2,3\}\\0.1\ j=4\end{cases}v‚àó(hj‚Äã)=‚é©‚é™‚é™‚é®‚é™‚é™‚éß‚Äã1.2¬†j=11¬†j‚àà{2,3}0.1¬†j=4‚Äã

    There are only 2 EFX allocations ({h1,h4},{h2,h3}),({h2,h3},{h1,h4})(\{h_1,h_4\},\{h_2,h_3\}),(\{h_2,h_3\},\{h_1,h_4\})({h1‚Äã,h4‚Äã},{h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã}),({h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã},{h1‚Äã,h4‚Äã}). According to assumption, there must be a bid b‚àó\mathbf b^*b‚àó that is a PNE of M\mathcal MM for this valuation profile. Because we require PNE to be EFX, M(b‚àó)\mathcal M(\mathbf b^*)M(b‚àó) must be one of these allocations.

    Observe that the value that agent 2‚Äã derives in these allocations is at most 2.

    discuss on bundle of agent 1 accordingly.

    • A1A_1A1‚Äã is singleton. Contradicts PNE.
    • A1A_1A1‚Äã has 3 items. Contradicts PNE.
    • A1A_1A1‚Äã is one of 12,13,14,2312,13,14,2312,13,14,23. By lemma 6, this contradicts MMS.
    • A1A_1A1‚Äã is one of 24,3424,3424,34. Contradicts PNE.

Thus EFX allocations here are all MMS allocations. Q.E.D.

ü§îLemma 6. For N,M,v1N,M,v_1N,M,v1‚Äã as earlier, we have vi({h1,h4})‚â•Œº1v_i(\{h_1,h_4\})\ge\mu_1vi‚Äã({h1‚Äã,h4‚Äã})‚â•Œº1‚Äã and max‚Å°{vi(h1),vi({h2,h3})}‚â•Œº1\max\{v_i(h_1),v_i(\{h_2,h_3\})\}\ge\mu_1max{vi‚Äã(h1‚Äã),vi‚Äã({h2‚Äã,h3‚Äã})}‚â•Œº1‚Äã.

For m‚â•5m\ge5m‚â•5, theorem 7 is not work. Because there are cases don‚Äôt lead to contradiction.

We need relaxation on MMS to Œ±\alphaŒ±-MMS, but here Œ±>2/3\alpha\gt2/3Œ±>2/3.

üéØü§îTheorem 8. Let M\mathcal MM be a mechanism that has PNE for any instance ([2],M,(v1,v2))([2],\mathcal M,(v_1,v_2))([2],M,(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã)) and all these equilibria lead to EFX allocation w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã. Then, each such EFX allocation is also an Œ±\alphaŒ±-MMS with Œ±>2/3\alpha\gt2/3Œ±>2/3.

Suppose for contradiction: there exists such a mechanism M\mathcal MM and an instance ({1,2},M,(v1,v2))(\{1,2\},M,(v_1,v_2))({1,2},M,(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã)) for which there is a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)b=(b1‚Äã,b2‚Äã) that results in an EFX allocation A\mathcal AA, where vi(Ai)‚â§2Œºi/3v_i(A_i)\le2\mu_i/3vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)‚â§2Œºi‚Äã/3 for at least one i‚àà[2]i\in[2]i‚àà[2]. WLOG, assume v1(A1)‚â§2Œº1/3v_1(A_1)\le2\mu_1/3v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â§2Œº1‚Äã/3. By Theorem 2, this implies v1(A1)=2Œº1/3v_1(A_1)=2\mu_1/3v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)=2Œº1‚Äã/3. Thus v1(A2)‚â•4Œºi/3v_1(A_2)\ge4\mu_i/3v1‚Äã(A2‚Äã)‚â•4Œºi‚Äã/3 because v1(M)‚â•2Œº1v_1(M)\ge2\mu_1v1‚Äã(M)‚â•2Œº1‚Äã by definition of MMS.

Initially, we restrict # goods with positive value in A2A_2A2‚Äã. Let S‚äÜA2S\subseteq A_2S‚äÜA2‚Äã be the set of such goods. Let ‚à£S‚à£=k|S|=k‚à£S‚à£=k and notice that kkk can‚Äôt be 000 or 111. Finally, let x‚ààarg‚Å°min‚Å°g‚ààSv1(g)x\in\arg\min_{g\in S}v_1(g)x‚ààargming‚ààS‚Äãv1‚Äã(g) be a minimum valued good for agent 111 in SSS. We have

23Œº1=v1(A1)‚â•v1(S‚ï≤{x})‚â•v1(S)‚àív1(S)k=k‚àí1kv1(A2)‚â•k‚àí1k43Œº1,\frac{2}{3}\mu_1=v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(S\diagdown\{x\})\ge v_1(S)-\frac{v_1(S)}{k}=\frac{k-1}{k}v_1(A_2)\ge\frac{k-1}{k}\frac{4}{3}\mu_1,32‚ÄãŒº1‚Äã=v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)‚â•v1‚Äã(S‚ï≤{x})‚â•v1‚Äã(S)‚àíkv1‚Äã(S)‚Äã=kk‚àí1‚Äãv1‚Äã(A2‚Äã)‚â•kk‚àí1‚Äã34‚ÄãŒº1‚Äã,

where the first inequality follows from EFX. Observe that k‚â§2k\le2k‚â§2, this implies k=2k=2k=2.

‚Ä¶ Yet another long proof

Discussion

This paper discusses fair division with indivisible goods to a set of strategic agents.

Surprisingly, there exists strong impossibilities for truthful mechanisms. The paper shows that there exist mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and at the same time the PNE allocation have strong guarantees w.r.t. true valuations.

Possible directions for future work:

  • Algorithm that compute EF1 allocations for richer valuation function domains (Envy-cycle elimination) in strategic setting.

    • Does there exist pure or mixed Nash Equilibria?
    • If there exist NE, does it still maintain fairness properties at the NE?

  • Theorem 7&8 leave an open problem: MMS guarantee that the equilibria of mechanisms that always have PNE and these are EFX.

    • suspect: corresponding allocations are not always MMS.
    • For every such mechanism that runs in polynomial time, finding a best response of an agent is NP. For n‚â•3n\ge3n‚â•3 the problem is absolutely non-trivial.

  • The complexity for computing best response. Want to know if best response dynamics always converge to a PNE or there might be cyclic behavior?

entry.title: Êï∞ÊçÆÊåñÊéò 13 Sequence Segmentation and Similarities
entry.content:
How to segment a sequence of points with an efficient algorithms and how to find similar documents in a linear manner.

2 algorithm.

The first is clustering a sequence to form kkk partitions with a dynamic programming.

The second is an approximation that allows to compute pairwise distance avoiding O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2). The idea is to use efficient signatures and hash the signatures in bands so as similar items will likely end up in the same bucket.

Sequence Segmentation

A sequence is a vector (x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)‚ààRn(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb R^n(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã)‚ààRn.

Sequence segmentation: Given a set sequence (x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)(x_1,\cdots,x_n)(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã), find kkk contiguous segments that are as homogeneous as possible.

The sequence segmentation problem requires a notion of homogeneity similar to one of clustering. Points in the segment should be subsequences rendering the problem different from that of clustering.

A sequence is homogeneous if its points have a small deviation from the mean. Let D\mathcal DD be a sequence of nnn ddd-dimensional points.

Definition of kkk-segmentation: A kkk-segmentation SSS is a partition of D\mathcal DD into kkk contiguous segments (s1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,sk)(s_1,\cdots,s_k)(s1‚Äã,‚ãØ,sk‚Äã). Each segment sis_isi‚Äã is represented by a ddd-dimensional mean vector Œºi=1‚à£s‚à£‚àëx‚ààsx\mu_i=\frac{1}{|s|}\sum_{\mathbb x\in s}\mathbb xŒºi‚Äã=‚à£s‚à£1‚Äã‚àëx‚ààs‚Äãx.

The mean vector has the same role of the centroid for kkk-means clustering. The error E(S)E(S)E(S) of a kkk-segmentation SSS is the error of replacing each individual point with the means. Similar to kkk-means, one of the most common errors is sum of squares error:

E(S)=‚àës‚ààS‚àës‚ààS(x‚àíŒºs)2E(S)=\sum_{s\in S}\sum_{\mathbb s\in S}(\mathbb x-\mu_s)^2E(S)=s‚ààS‚àë‚Äãs‚ààS‚àë‚Äã(x‚àíŒºs‚Äã)2

Problem of k-segmentation problem

Given a sequence D=(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)\mathcal D=(\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n)D=(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã) of length nnn, find a set of kkk segments SSS of D\mathcal DD s.t. the SSE error is minimized.

A Dynamic Programming Solution

A dynamic programming solution from Bellman solves the kkk-segmentation problem in polynomial time.

The idea is to build the solution bottom-up solving progressively larger instances of the problem.

DP requires the property of optimal sub-problem that states that the solution on a subset of the input is also optimal.

Denote D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] the sub-sequence x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xi\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_ix1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xi‚Äã with i‚â§ni\le ni‚â§n. E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s) is the error of the optimal segmentation of the sub-sequence D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] with sss segments with s‚â§ks\le ks‚â§k. The dynamic programming algorithm follows the recursion

E(i,s)=min‚Å°s‚â§j‚â§i‚àí1(E(j,s‚àí1)+‚àëj+1‚â§t‚â§i(t‚àíŒºj+1,i)2)E(i,s)=\min_{s\le j\le i-1}\left(E(j,s-1)+\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{j+1,i})^2\right)E(i,s)=s‚â§j‚â§i‚àí1min‚Äã(E(j,s‚àí1)+j+1‚â§t‚â§i‚àë‚Äã(t‚àíŒºj+1,i‚Äã)2)

In practice we can use a 2-dimensional table that stores in position s,is,is,i the value E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s).

Pseudo-code

Input: Sequence D,k,E(‚ãÖ)\mathcal D,k,E(\cdot)D,k,E(‚ãÖ)

  1. for each i‚Üê1‚ãØni\gets1\cdots ni‚Üê1‚ãØn do
    • A[1,i]=E(D[1‚ãØi])A[1,i]=E(D[1\cdots i])A[1,i]=E(D[1‚ãØi])
  2. for each s‚Üê1‚ãØks\gets1\cdots ks‚Üê1‚ãØk do
    • A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0
  3. for each s=2‚ãØns=2\cdots ns=2‚ãØn do
    • for each i=s+1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,ni=s+1,\cdots,ni=s+1,‚ãØ,n do
      • A[k,i]=min‚Å°j<i(A[s‚àí1,j]+E(D[j+1‚ãØi]))A[k,i]=\min_{j\lt i}(A[s-1,j]+E(D[j+1\cdots i]))A[k,i]=minj<i‚Äã(A[s‚àí1,j]+E(D[j+1‚ãØi]))

To recover the actual segmentation, the matrix AAA should store also the values jjj minimizing the error.

Complexity

The algorithm needs to fill O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk) table, each cell computes the minimum, takes O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n) cells to check, each of it computes the error in O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n). Thus total complexity of O(n3k)\mathcal O(n^3k)O(n3k) for naive version.

The errors per cell can be further optimized by noticing that

‚àëj+1‚â§t‚â§i(t‚àíŒº[j+1,i])2=‚àëj+1‚â§t‚â§it2‚àí1i‚àíj(‚àëj+1‚â§t‚â§it)2\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{[j+1,i]})^2=\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t^2-\frac{1}{i-j}(\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t)^2j+1‚â§t‚â§i‚àë‚Äã(t‚àíŒº[j+1,i]‚Äã)2=j+1‚â§t‚â§i‚àë‚Äãt2‚àíi‚àíj1‚Äã(j+1‚â§t‚â§i‚àë‚Äãt)2

that requires the repeated computation of t2\mathbf t^2t2 and t\mathbf tt. These two terms can be easily pre-computed for all i=1‚ãØni=1\cdots ni=1‚ãØn. By this optimization, complexity is reduced to O(n2k)\mathbf O(n^2k)O(n2k).

Heuristic: we can further reduce the computational burden by using greedy approaches or local search that assigns border points randomly and move the in a way to reduce the errors. The total time is O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk).

Finding Similar Points Efficiently

Comparing each point in the data with other, raising O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

Given a dataset D={x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn}\mathcal D=\{\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n\}D={x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã} of ddd-dimensional data points, find all the pairs of data point (xi,xj)(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)(xi‚Äã,xj‚Äã) s.t. d(xi,xj)‚â§sd(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)\le sd(xi‚Äã,xj‚Äã)‚â§s for some distance function ddd.

With Locality-Sensitive Hashing, we can get rid of O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

LSH ‰∏çÊòØ ‰ªäÂ§©‰∏äÂçàÁöÑÈöèÊú∫ÁÆóÊ≥ïËØæ ÊâçËÆ≤ÁöÑ‰πà‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Ëøô‰∏ãÈó≠ÁéØ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

Definition of Jaccard similarity: of two sets is the size of their intersection sim(C_1,C_2)=|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|. The Jaccard distance is then d(C_1,C_2)=1-|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|.

A large number of documents do not fit into memory and we need a representation of each document that allows for preserving the distances while considerably reducing the memory footprint. In order to achieve such a gold, we use the 3 steps:

  1. Shingling: Convert documents to sets.
  2. Min-hashing: Convert large sets to short signatures, while preserving similarity.
  3. LSH: Focus on pairs of signatures likely to be from similar documents.

Shingling

A kkk-shingle is a set of kkk tokens that appear in the document.

Idea: we return a large number of sparse vector with low similarity.

For instance, the set of 222-shingle for document D1=abcabD_1=abcabD1‚Äã=abcab is S(D1)={ab,bc,ca}S(D_1)=\{ab,bc,ca\}S(D1‚Äã)={ab,bc,ca}.

Long shingles can be easily compressed by hashing. Documents are compared through the hash values. Finally each document is a binary vector in the space of kkk-shingle in which a shingle is a dimension.

We assume that documents have a large number of common shingles if they are similar. However, kkk is a critical choice to compare documents. A small kkk leads to a large number of similar documents. As rule of thumb k=5,10k=5,10k=5,10 is a reasonable choice for short/large documents.

Shingling doesn‚Äôt solve the problem of a large number of similarity computation.

Min-hash

The document is converted into a set of shingles and consequently as a binary vector, where each dimension is a shingle and a 111 in position iii of document jjj indicates that the document contains the shingle iii. This way can we represent our dataset as a matrix where each row represents.

Computing Jaccard similarity in such a matrix relies on simple bit-wise AND, intersection and OR.

Min-Hashing is used for faster comparison. It converts the binary representation into small signatures through hashing. The key idea is to hash each column to a small signatures h(C)h(C)h(C) s.t.

  • h(C)h(C)h(C) is small enough that the signature fits in RAM
  • sim(C1,C2)sim(C_1,C_2)sim(C1‚Äã,C2‚Äã) is the same as the similarity of signatures h(C1),h(C2)h(C_1),h(C_2)h(C1‚Äã),h(C2‚Äã).

Definition of min-hash function: The hash function hœÄ(C)h_\pi(C)hœÄ‚Äã(C) returns the index of the first row in which column CCC has value 111.

hœÄ(C)=min‚Å°œÄ(C)h_\pi(C)=\min_\pi(C)hœÄ‚Äã(C)=œÄmin‚Äã(C)

Hash function is a approximation of a set.

Min-hash preserves the property that Pr‚Å°[hœÄ(C1)=hœÄ(C2)]=sim(C1,C2)\Pr[h_\pi(C_1)=h_\pi(C_2)]=sim(C_1,C_2)Pr[hœÄ‚Äã(C1‚Äã)=hœÄ‚Äã(C2‚Äã)]=sim(C1‚Äã,C2‚Äã).

A trick

For each column CCC, and hash function, kik_iki‚Äã keep a slot for the min-hash value. Initialize Sig(C)[i]=‚àûSig(C)[i]=\inftySig(C)[i]=‚àû, then scan rows looking for 111s. How to choose kik_iki‚Äã? Using universal hashing.

ÂèàÊòØÈöèÊú∫ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂâçÈù¢Â≠¶ËøáÁöÑ‰∏úË•ø„ÄÇ

LSH

LSH tackles the problem of the comparison by hashing the signatures in an appropriate manner.

Intuition: use a function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) to determine whether xxx and yyy is a candidate pair whose similarity must be evaluated. For Min-hash matrices we hash the columns of the signature matrix MMM to different buckets. If two documents hashes into the same buckets, they become a candidate pair with similarity sim‚â•thresholdsim\ge thresholdsim‚â•threshold.

LSH works:

  • Pick a similarity threshold sss.
  • The columns of xxx and yyy of MMM are a candidate pair if their signatures agree on at least a fraction sss of their rows. M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y) for at least a fraction sss of iii.
  • The idea is to hash columns of signatures matrix MMM several times. Similar columns should be likely to hash to the same bucket with high probability.

LSH partitions MMM‚Äôs columns into bbb bands each of rrr rows. For each band, compute a signatures using a hash function with kkk buckets, where kkk is arbitrarily large. The candidate column pairs are those that hash to the same bucket for at least 111 band. Tune bbb and rrr to catch most similar pairs, few non-similar pairs.

How to choose bbb and rrr?

Balances false positives / negatives.

We need to strike a trade-off with the number of bands and the number of rows.

As bbb increases, the method becomes more reliable, but the time increases as well.

If t=sim(C1,C2)t=sim(C_1,C_2)t=sim(C1‚Äã,C2‚Äã) the probability that all rows in a band are equal is trt^rtr and probability that some row in a band are different is 1‚àítr1-t^r1‚àítr.

As such the probability that no band is identical is (1‚àírt)b(1-r^t)^b(1‚àírt)b that leads to (1‚àí(1‚àírt)b)(1-(1-r^t)^b)(1‚àí(1‚àírt)b) the probability that at least 111 band is identical.

Pros and Cons

üëçFinds similar items in linear time

üëçEasy and fast to implement

üëçGeneralizes to other similarity measures

üëéPerformance depend on the choice of b,rb,rb,r

üëéRequres a fairly large number of buckets
entry.summary:
How to segment a sequence of points with an efficient algorithms and how to find similar documents in a linear manner.

2 algorithm

entry.title: Fair Division for 2 Strategic Agents with Divisible Items
entry.content:
For randomized fair division with indivisible items, we consider its ex-ante fairness. Indeed when it comes to expected valuation (or payoff), it‚Äôs equivalent to fair division with divisible items.

Consider fair division with divisible items among only 2 AGENT.

The input valuation for each agent is the ordinal preference ‚âªi\succ_i‚âªi‚Äã.

We want to explore to what extent agent can manipulate by misreporting preference profile to gain more share of items with higher priority.

The source code and experiment results is available in my GitHub Repo

Reporting State Graph

A (directed) reporting state graph is defined: G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

VVV denote the set of all the possible preference input.

EEE denotes the set of all edges. A directed edge e=(v1,v2)e=(v_1,v_2)e=(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã) denotes there exist a agent in reporting state v1v_1v1‚Äã, who can better off by deviating its report to state v2v_2v2‚Äã.

(In this scenario, better off means that agent strictly SD-prefer v2v_2v2‚Äã to v1v_1v1‚Äã)

  • For case of 3 items, there are 3!√ó3!=363!\times3!=363!√ó3!=36 reporting state vertices.
  • For case of 4 items, there are 4!√ó4!=5764!\times4!=5764!√ó4!=576 reporting state vertices.

‚ùìIs there any cycle in the reporting state graph?

# States Can be Reduced

Without loss of generality, by rotational symmetry,

  • For case of 3 items, it suffices to analyze only 3!=63!=63!=6 reporting state vertices.

    For example 1:g1‚âªg2‚âªg3,2:g1‚âªg2‚âªg31:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3,2:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_31:g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã,2:g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã is equivalent to 1:g1‚âªg3‚âªg2,2:g1‚âªg3‚âªg21:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2,2:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_21:g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã,2:g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã.

  • Analogously, for case of 444 items, it‚Äôs enough to analyze 4!=244!=244!=24 reporting states.

2 Agents, 3 Items

Without loss of generality, by symmetry of two agents, it suffice to check only one agent.

Analysis Case-by-case

For the scenario of 2 agents with 3 divisible goods.

Assume the 3 items are g1,g2,g3g_1,g_2,g_3g1‚Äã,g2‚Äã,g3‚Äã, 2 agent 1,21,21,2.

  • There are 363636 cases in total, but by rotational symmetry, it can be reduced to 666 cases.
  • For example 1:g1‚âªg2‚âªg3,2:g1‚âªg2‚âªg31:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3,2:g_1\succ g_2\succ g_31:g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã,2:g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã is equivalent to 1:g1‚âªg3‚âªg2,2:g1‚âªg3‚âªg21:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2,2:g_1\succ g_3\succ g_21:g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã,2:g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã.
  • The 666 cases are in the following (Fix the ordinal preference on agent 1 on g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã, we analysis agent 2 for all permutations on preference):

  1. agent 1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 2‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 1 gets: [50.0,50.0,50.0][50.0, 50.0, 50.0][50.0,50.0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [50.0,50.0,50.0][50.0, 50.0, 50.0][50.0,50.0,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Because there are no other preference profile of player 2 inducing high sum of share of first kkk item for k=[3]k=[3]k=[3].

  2. agent1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent2‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg3‚âªg2g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã

    agent1 gets: [50.0,100,0][50.0, 100, 0][50.0,100,0]

    agent2 gets: [50.0,0,100][50.0, 0, 100][50.0,0,100]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      First observe that by eating protocol, each agent exactly gain the total share of 150150150 item.

      The top priority of both agents are g1g_1g1‚Äã, thus agent 2 can‚Äôt manipulate to gain higher than 505050 share of g1g_1g1‚Äã when agent 1 reports truthfully by putting g1g_1g1‚Äã on its top priority.

    • Agent 2 in case 5 has an incentive to deviate to case 2. Then it‚Äôs natural to ask whether it‚Äôs the best response for agent 1.

      The answer is Yes.

      • Agent 1 must put g1g_1g1‚Äã on top priority, otherwise it will loss the share of its favorite g1g_1g1‚Äã.
      • If agent 111 switch the position of g2g_2g2‚Äã and g3g_3g3‚Äã, it will loss the share of second priority g2g_2g2‚Äã.

  3. agent 1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 2‚Äôs true preference: g2‚âªg1‚âªg3g_2\succ g_1\succ g_3g2‚Äã‚âªg1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 1 gets: [100,0,50.0][100, 0, 50.0][100,0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,100,50.0][0, 100, 50.0][0,100,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Here any other misreport which promote share of g1g_1g1‚Äã will hurt the 100100100 share of g2g_2g2‚Äã.

  4. agent 1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 2‚Äôs true preference: g2‚âªg3‚âªg1g_2\succ g_3\succ g_1g2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg1‚Äã

    agent1 gets: [100,0,50.0][100, 0, 50.0][100,0,50.0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,100,50.0][0, 100, 50.0][0,100,50.0]

    • Best response for agent 2? Yes.

      Indeed, it‚Äôs the best outcome for both agent: 100100100 share of top priority, 505050 share of second priority.

  5. agent 1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 2‚Äôs true preference: g3‚âªg1‚âªg2g_3\succ g_1\succ g_2g3‚Äã‚âªg1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã

    agent1 gets: [100,50.0,0][100, 50.0, 0][100,50.0,0]

    agent2 gets: [0,50.0,100][0, 50.0, 100][0,50.0,100]

    • Best response for agent 2? NO!!!

      By misreporting g1‚âªg3‚âªg2g_1\succ g_3\succ g_2g1‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã, the eating protocol allocates:

      • agent 1 gets: [50.0,100,0][50.0, 100, 0][50.0,100,0]
      • agent 2 gets: [50.0,0,100][50.0, 0, 100][50.0,0,100]

      Which is strictly better off w.r.t. agent 2.

  6. agent 1‚Äôs true preference: g1‚âªg2‚âªg3g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã

    agent 2‚Äôs true preference: g3‚âªg2‚âªg1g_3\succ g_2\succ g_1g3‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg1‚Äã

    agent 1 gets: [100,50.0,0][100, 50.0, 0][100,50.0,0]

    agent 2 gets: [0,50.0,100][0, 50.0, 100][0,50.0,100]

    • Best response for agent 222? Yes.

      Indeed, it‚Äôs the best outcome for both agent: 100100100 share of top priority, 505050 share of second priority.

Graph of reporting states

There are 3!√ó3!=363!\times3!=363!√ó3!=36 reporting states VVV. An directed edge in the graph e=(v1,v2)‚ààEe=(v_1,v_2)\in Ee=(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã)‚ààE means there are a agent in reporting state node v1v_1v1‚Äã has an incentive to deviate to reporting state v2v_2v2‚Äã.

By the analysis for 6 cases above, there are no cycle in the graph.

Case of 4 Items

Fix agent 1 with preference g1‚âªg2‚âªg3‚âªg4g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3\succ g_4g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg4‚Äã.

For agent 2, the reporting states graph is:

  flowchart LRsubgraph TB ["incentive to deviate"]0312 --> 01322013 --> 02132013 --> 02312031 --> 02132031 --> 02313012 --> 01323012 --> 03123012 --> 03213012 --> 10323012 --> 13023012 --> 13203021 --> 03123021 --> 03213102 --> 01323102 --> 10323102 --> 13023102 --> 13203120 --> 10323120 --> 13023120 --> 1320endsubgraph BT ["prefer truth-telling"]01230132021302310321102310321203123013021320210321302301231032013210end

Observation: There are also no cycle in the reporting states graph for 4 items.

Case of 5 Items

As the # agent growth, the state grows exponentially.

Fix agent 1 with preference g1‚âªg2‚âªg3‚âªg4‚âªg5g_1\succ g_2\succ g_3\succ g_4\succ g_5g1‚Äã‚âªg2‚Äã‚âªg3‚Äã‚âªg4‚Äã‚âªg5‚Äã.

For agent 2, the reporting states graph contains 469 edges. But no cycle exists.

My Conjectures

ü§îIn 2 strategic agents with n‚â•4n\ge4n‚â•4 divisible items, There is no cycle in the corresponding reporting-state-graph.

entry.title: ÈöèÊú∫ÁÆóÊ≥ï 11 Randomized Rounding for MAX SAT
entry.content:
MAX SAT and MAX CUT

randomized ¬Ω approximation for each problem

MAX SAT

aka maximum satisfiability problem

  • Input consists of nnn Boolean variables x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã, mmm clauses C1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,CmC_1,\cdots,C_mC1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Cm‚Äã.
    • Clauses CjC_jCj‚Äã consist of some number of variables and \or and a non-negative weight wjw_jwj‚Äã.
  • The objective of the problem is to find an assignment of xix_ixi‚Äã that maximizes the weight of the satisfied clauses.
  • A clause is said to be satisfied if one of the unnegated variables is set to true, or one of the negated variables is set to false.

Some terminology:

  • literal. A variable xix_ixi‚Äã or a negated variable xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã is a literal, so that each clause consists of some number of literals.
    • xix_ixi‚Äã is called positive literal
    • xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã is called negative literal
  • length. The number of literals in a clause. Length of CiC_iCi‚Äã is lil_ili‚Äã.
  • Clause of length 1 is unit clause.

WLOG, assume that no literal is repeated in a clause, at most one of xix_ixi‚Äã and xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã appears in a clause.

Assume the clauses are distinct.

A very straightforward use of randomization: set each xix_ixi‚Äã to true independently with probability 1/21/21/2.

ü§îTheorem 1. Setting each xix_ixi‚Äã to true with probability 1/21/21/2 independently gives a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the MAX SAT problem.

Define indicator variable YjY_jYj‚Äã: 111 if clause jjj is satisfied and 000 otherwise.

Let WWW be a random variable that is equal to the total weight of the satisfied clauses, so that W=‚àëjwjYjW=\sum_jw_jY_jW=‚àëj‚Äãwj‚ÄãYj‚Äã.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimum value of the MAX SAT instance. Then, by linearity of expectation, and the definition of the expectation of 0-1 random variable, we know

E[W]=‚àëj=1mwjE[Yj]=‚àëj=1mwjPr‚Å°[Cj¬†is¬†satisfied].\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\mathbb E[Y_j]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}].E[W]=j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚ÄãE[Yj‚Äã]=j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚ÄãPr[Cj‚Äã¬†is¬†satisfied].

For each CjC_jCj‚Äã, the probability that it is not satisfied is the probability that each positive literal in CjC_jCj‚Äã is set to false and each negative literal is set to true, each of which happens with probability 1/21/21/2. Hence,

Pr‚Å°[Cj¬†is¬†satisfied]=(1‚àí(12)lj)‚â•12,\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}]=\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^{l_j}\right)\ge\frac{1}{2},Pr[Cj‚Äã¬†is¬†satisfied]=(1‚àí(21‚Äã)lj‚Äã)‚â•21‚Äã,

where the last inequality is a consequence of the fact that lj‚â•1l_j\ge1lj‚Äã‚â•1. Hence,

E[W]‚â•12‚àëj=1mwj‚â•12OPT,\mathbb E[W]\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[W]‚â•21‚Äãj=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äã‚â•21‚ÄãOPT,

where the last inequality follows from the fact that the total weight is an easy upper bound on the optimal value, since each weight is assumed to be non-negative.

If lj‚â•kl_j\ge klj‚Äã‚â•k for each clause jjj, the algorithm is a (1‚àí(12)k)\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^k\right)(1‚àí(21‚Äã)k)-approximation algorithm for such instances. Thus the longer the clauses, the better the approximation.

Consider lj=3l_j=3lj‚Äã=3 for all clauses, the problem turns into MAX E3SAT. By analysis above, this randomized algorithm gives guarantee of 7/87/87/8 approximation. Nothing better is possible for these instances unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

ü§îTheorem 2. If there is an (78+œµ)(\frac{7}{8}+\epsilon)(87‚Äã+œµ)-approximation algorithm for MAX E3SAT for any constant œµ>0\epsilon\gt 0œµ>0, then P=NPP=NPP=NP.

MAX CUT

aka maximum cut problem

In this problem. the input is an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), along with a non-negative weight wij‚â•0w_{ij}\ge0wij‚Äã‚â•0 for each edge (i,j)‚ààE(i,j)\in E(i,j)‚ààE. The goal is to partition the vertex set into two parts UUU and W=V‚àíUW=V-UW=V‚àíU, so as to maximize the weight of edges whose two endpoints are in different parts, one in UUU and another in WWW.

An edge with endpoints in both UUU and WWW is in the cut. In the case wij=1w_{ij}=1wij‚Äã=1 for each edge ‚ààE\in E‚ààE, we have an unweighted MAX CUT problem.

We place each vertex v‚ààVv\in Vv‚ààV into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2. As with the MAX SAT algorithm, this can be viewed as sampling a solution uniformly form the space of all possible solutions.

ü§îTheorem 3. If we place each vertex v‚ààVv\in Vv‚ààV into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2, then we obtain a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the maximum cut problem.

Consider a random variable XijX_{ij}Xij‚Äã that is 111 if edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut, and 000 otherwise.

Let ZZZ be the random variable equal to the total weight of edges in the cut, so that Z=‚àë(i,j)‚ààEwijXijZ=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}X_{ij}Z=‚àë(i,j)‚ààE‚Äãwij‚ÄãXij‚Äã.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimal value of the maximum cut instance. Then, as before, by linearity of expectation and the definition of expectation of a 0-1 random variable, we get that

E[Z]=‚àë(i,j)‚ààEwijE[Xij]=‚àë(i,j)‚ààEwijPr‚Å°[(i,j)¬†in¬†cut].\mathbb E[Z]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\mathbb E[X_{ij}]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\Pr[(i,j)\text{ in cut}].E[Z]=(i,j)‚ààE‚àë‚Äãwij‚ÄãE[Xij‚Äã]=(i,j)‚ààE‚àë‚Äãwij‚ÄãPr[(i,j)¬†in¬†cut].

The probability that a specific edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut: since the 2 endpoints are placed in the sets independently, they are in different sets with probability equal to 1/21/21/2. Hence,

E[Z]=12‚àë(i,j)‚ààEwij‚â•12OPT,\mathbb E[Z]=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[Z]=21‚Äã(i,j)‚ààE‚àë‚Äãwij‚Äã‚â•21‚ÄãOPT,

where the inequality follows directly from the fact that the sum of the non-negative weights of all edges is obviously an upper bound on the weight of the edges in an optimal cut.

Derandomization

Randomized algorithm for MAX SAT can be derandomized by replacing the randomized decision of whether to set xix_ixi‚Äã to true with a deterministic one that will preserve the expected value of the solution. The decisions will be made sequentially.

Assume that x1x_1x1‚Äã is fixed, and other variables will be set true with probability 1/21/21/2. Intuitively we should choose the value of x1x_1x1‚Äã which maximize the expected value of WWW. In this way, we should maintain the algorithm that the expected value is at least half the optimum, while having fewer random variables left.

If E[W‚à£x1‚Üêtrue]‚â•E[W‚à£x1‚Üêfalse]\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]\ge\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false]E[W‚à£x1‚Äã‚Üêtrue]‚â•E[W‚à£x1‚Äã‚Üêfalse], then we set x1x_1x1‚Äã to true, otherwise false. Then

E[W]=E[W‚à£x1‚Üêture]Pr‚Å°[x1‚Üêtrue]+E[W‚à£x‚Üêfalse]Pr‚Å°[x1‚Üêflase]=12(E[W‚à£x1‚Üêtrue]+E[W‚à£x1‚Üêfalse])\mathbb E[W]=\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets ture]\Pr[x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x\gets false]\Pr[x_1\gets flase]\\=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false])E[W]=E[W‚à£x1‚Äã‚Üêture]Pr[x1‚Äã‚Üêtrue]+E[W‚à£x‚Üêfalse]Pr[x1‚Äã‚Üêflase]=21‚Äã(E[W‚à£x1‚Äã‚Üêtrue]+E[W‚à£x1‚Äã‚Üêfalse])

By induction, we can set the sequence of variables better than 1/21/21/2.

Flipping Biased Coins

Consider MAX SAT instance with no unit clauses xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã. (This condition can be moved)

Suppose we set each xix_ixi‚Äã to be true independently with probability p>12p\gt\frac{1}{2}p>21‚Äã, then the probability that any given clause is satisfied is at least min‚Å°(p,1‚àíp2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1‚àíp2) for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

ÂÅáËÆæËøô‰∫õÂ∏ÉÂ∞îË°®ËææÂºè‰∏çÂê´ÊúâÂçï‰∏™ÈùûÂèòÈáè„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫éÂè™Âê´‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂ∏ÉÂ∞îË°®ËææÂºèÔºåÊª°Ë∂≥ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÁéá‰∏∫ ppp.

ÂØπ‰∫éÂê´ÊúâËá≥Â∞ë‰∏§‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂ∏ÉÂ∞îË°®ËææÂºèÔºåÂÅáËÆæ xix_ixi‚Äã Êúâ aaa ‰∏™ÔºåxÀâj\bar x_jxÀâj‚Äã Êúâ bbb ‰∏™ÔºåÂàôËØ•Ë°®ËææÂºè‰∏çÊª°Ë∂≥ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÁéá‰∏∫Ôºö

Pr‚Å°[Ck¬†not¬†satisfied]=(1‚àíp)apb‚â§pa+b‚â§p2‚à¥Pr‚Å°[Ck¬†satisfied]‚â•1‚àíp2\Pr[C_k\text{ not satisfied}]=(1-p)^ap^b\le p^{a+b}\le p^2\\\therefore\Pr[C_k\text{ satisfied}]\ge 1-p^2Pr[Ck‚Äã¬†not¬†satisfied]=(1‚àíp)apb‚â§pa+b‚â§p2‚à¥Pr[Ck‚Äã¬†satisfied]‚â•1‚àíp2

Áé∞Âú®Â∞±ÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞Ü min‚Å°(p,1‚àíp2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1‚àíp2) ÊúÄÂ§ßÂåñ„ÄÇ

Best performance is p=1‚àíp2‚áíp‚âà0.618p=1-p^2\Rarr p\approx0.618p=1‚àíp2‚áíp‚âà0.618.

ü§îTheorem 4. Setting each xix_ixi‚Äã to true with probability ppp independently gives a randomized min‚Å°(p,1‚àíp2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1‚àíp2)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

Let viv_ivi‚Äã be the weight of the unit clause xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã if it exists in the instance, and let viv_ivi‚Äã be zero otherwise.

OPTOPTOPT has a tighter bound: OPT‚â§‚àëj=1mwj‚àí‚àëi=1nviOPT\le\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_iOPT‚â§‚àëj=1m‚Äãwj‚Äã‚àí‚àëi=1n‚Äãvi‚Äã.

Let UUU be the set of indices of clauses of the instance excluding unit clauses of the form xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã. WLOG the weight of each clause xÀâi\bar x_ixÀâi‚Äã is no greater than the weight of clause xix_ixi‚Äã. Thus ‚àëj‚ààUwj=‚àëj=1mwj‚àí‚àëi=1nvi\sum_{j\in U}w_j=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_i‚àëj‚ààU‚Äãwj‚Äã=‚àëj=1m‚Äãwj‚Äã‚àí‚àëi=1n‚Äãvi‚Äã. Each xix_ixi‚Äã is set to true with probability 0.6180.6180.618. So the algorithm produces

E[W]=‚àëj=1mwjPr‚Å°[Cj¬†satisfied]‚â•‚àëj‚ààUmwjPr‚Å°[Cj¬†satisfied]‚â•p‚ãÖ‚àëj‚ààUwj=p‚ãÖ(‚àëj=1mwj‚àí‚àëi=1nvi)‚â•p‚ãÖOPT.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j\in U}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge p\cdot\sum_{j\in U}w_j\\=p\cdot(\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_i)\ge p\cdot OPT.E[W]=j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚ÄãPr[Cj‚Äã¬†satisfied]‚â•j‚ààU‚àëm‚Äãwj‚ÄãPr[Cj‚Äã¬†satisfied]‚â•p‚ãÖj‚ààU‚àë‚Äãwj‚Äã=p‚ãÖ(j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äã‚àíi=1‚àën‚Äãvi‚Äã)‚â•p‚ãÖOPT.

This algorithm can be derandomized using the method of conditional expectations.

Randomized Rounding

Biasing probability with which we set xix_ixi‚Äã true yields an improved approximation algorithm. However, we gave each variable the same bias. We can do better by giving each variable its own bias!

Idea of randomized rounding:

  • First set up an integer programming formulation of the problem at hand in which there are 0-1 integer variables. 0-1 variable yiy_iyi‚Äã for each Boolean variable xix_ixi‚Äã s.t. yi=1y_i=1yi‚Äã=1 corresponds to xix_ixi‚Äã set true.
  • The integer program is relaxed to a linear program by replacing the constraints yi‚àà{0,1}y_i\in\{0,1\}yi‚Äã‚àà{0,1} with 0‚â§yi‚â§10\le y_i\le 10‚â§yi‚Äã‚â§1.
  • The fractional value yi‚àóy_i^*yi‚àó‚Äã is interpreted as the probability that yiy_iyi‚Äã should be set to 111. In this case we set each xix_ixi‚Äã to true with probability yi‚àóy_i^*yi‚àó‚Äã independently.

For MAX SAT problem, in addition to the variables yiy_iyi‚Äã, we introduce a variable zjz_jzj‚Äã for each CjC_jCj‚Äã that will be 111 if the clause is satisfied and 000 otherwise. For each clause CjC_jCj‚Äã let PjP_jPj‚Äã be the indices of the variables xix_ixi‚Äã that are positive, NjN_jNj‚Äã be negated in the clause.

We denote the clause CjC_jCj‚Äã by

\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i.

Then the inequality

‚àëi‚ààPjyi+‚àëi‚ààNj(1‚àíyi)‚â•zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_ji‚ààPj‚Äã‚àë‚Äãyi‚Äã+i‚ààNj‚Äã‚àë‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚Äã)‚â•zj‚Äã

must hold for CjC_jCj‚Äã since if each variable that occurs positively in the clause is set to false and each variable that occurs negatively is set to true, then the clause is not satisfied, and zjz_jzj‚Äã must be 000.

This yields integer programming formulation of MAX SAT problem:

  • maximize ‚àëj=1mwjzj\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j‚àëj=1m‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚Äã
  • subject to ‚àëi‚ààPjyi+‚àëi‚ààNj(1‚àíyi)‚â•zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_j‚àëi‚ààPj‚Äã‚Äãyi‚Äã+‚àëi‚ààNj‚Äã‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚Äã)‚â•zj‚Äã, \forall C_j=\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i,
  • yi‚àà{0,1},i=1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,ny_i\in\{0,1\},i=1,\cdots,nyi‚Äã‚àà{0,1},i=1,‚ãØ,n
  • 0‚â§zj‚â§1,j=1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,m0\le z_j\le 1,j=1,\cdots,m0‚â§zj‚Äã‚â§1,j=1,‚ãØ,m

ZLP‚àóZ^*_{LP}ZLP‚àó‚Äã is the optimum value of this linear program LPLPLP, then clearly the optimum value of integer program (IP) ZIP‚àó=OPTZ^*_{IP}=OPTZIP‚àó‚Äã=OPT.

Let (y‚àó,z‚àó)(y^*,z^*)(y‚àó,z‚àó) be the optimum value of solution to the linear programming, relaxation. Consider the result of using randomized rounding, and setting xix_ixi‚Äã to true with probability yi‚àóy_i^*yi‚àó‚Äã independently. Before we can begin the analysis, we will need 2 facts. The first is commonly called the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality, because it compares the arithmetic and geometric means of a set of numbers.

‚àèi=1kaik‚â§1k‚àëi=1kai\sqrt[k]{\prod_{i=1}^ka_i}\le\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^ka_iki=1‚àèk‚Äãai‚Äã‚Äã‚â§k1‚Äãi=1‚àëk‚Äãai‚Äã

If f‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(x)‚â§0‚àÄx‚àà[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+af''(x)\le0\forall x\in[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+af‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(x)‚â§0‚àÄx‚àà[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+a, then f(x)‚â•bx+a‚àÄx‚àà[0,1]f(x)\ge bx+a\forall x\in[0,1]f(x)‚â•bx+a‚àÄx‚àà[0,1].

ü§îTheorem 5. Randomized rounding gives a randomized (1‚àí1e)(1-\frac{1}{e})(1‚àíe1‚Äã)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Applying arithmetic-geometric mean inequality:

Pr‚Å°[Cj¬†not¬†satisfied]=‚àèi‚ààPj(1‚àíyi‚àó)‚àèi‚ààNjyi‚àó‚â§[1lj(‚àëi‚ààPj(1‚àíyi‚àó)+‚àëi‚ààNjyi‚àó)]lj\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]=\prod_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)\prod_{i\in N_j}y_i^*\\\le\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}Pr[Cj‚Äã¬†not¬†satisfied]=i‚ààPj‚Äã‚àè‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚àó‚Äã)i‚ààNj‚Äã‚àè‚Äãyi‚àó‚Äã‚â§‚é£‚é¢‚é°‚Äãlj‚Äã1‚Äã(i‚ààPj‚Äã‚àë‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚àó‚Äã)+i‚ààNj‚Äã‚àë‚Äãyi‚àó‚Äã)‚é¶‚é•‚é§‚Äãlj‚Äã

By rearranging terms,

[1lj(‚àëi‚ààPj(1‚àíyi‚àó)+‚àëi‚ààNjyi‚àó)]lj=[1‚àí1lj(‚àëi‚ààNj(1‚àíyi‚àó)+‚àëi‚ààPjyi‚àó)]lj\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}=\left[1-\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}‚é£‚é¢‚é°‚Äãlj‚Äã1‚Äã(i‚ààPj‚Äã‚àë‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚àó‚Äã)+i‚ààNj‚Äã‚àë‚Äãyi‚àó‚Äã)‚é¶‚é•‚é§‚Äãlj‚Äã=‚é£‚é¢‚é°‚Äã1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã(i‚ààNj‚Äã‚àë‚Äã(1‚àíyi‚àó‚Äã)+i‚ààPj‚Äã‚àë‚Äãyi‚àó‚Äã)‚é¶‚é•‚é§‚Äãlj‚Äã

By the inequality Optimum of LP ‚â•\ge‚â• Optimum of IP, we see

Pr‚Å°[Cj¬†not¬†satisfied]‚â§(1‚àízj‚àólj)lj.\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]\le\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}.Pr[Cj‚Äã¬†not¬†satisfied]‚â§(1‚àílj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã‚Äã)lj‚Äã.

Function f(zj‚àó)=1‚àí(1‚àízj‚àólj)ljf(z_j^*)=1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}f(zj‚àó‚Äã)=1‚àí(1‚àílj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã‚Äã)lj‚Äã is concave for lj‚â•1l_j\ge1lj‚Äã‚â•1, then

Pr‚Å°[Cj¬†satisfied]‚â•1‚àí(1‚àízj‚àólj)lj‚â•[(1‚àí1lj)lj]zj‚àó.\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\ge1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\\\ge\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*.Pr[Cj‚Äã¬†satisfied]‚â•1‚àí(1‚àílj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã‚Äã)lj‚Äã‚â•[(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã]zj‚àó‚Äã.

Therefore the expected value of the randomized rounding algorithm is

E[W]=‚àëj=1mwjPr‚Å°[Cj¬†satisfied]‚â•‚àëj=1mwjzj‚àó[(1‚àí1lj)lj]‚â•min‚Å°k‚â•1[(1‚àí1k)k]‚àëj=1mwjzj‚àó.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]\\\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*.E[W]=j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚ÄãPr[Cj‚Äã¬†satisfied]‚â•j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã[(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã]‚â•k‚â•1min‚Äã[(1‚àík1‚Äã)k]j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã.

[(1‚àí1k)k]\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right][(1‚àík1‚Äã)k] is non-increasing. It approaches 1‚àí1e1-\frac{1}{e}1‚àíe1‚Äã from above as kkk tends to infinity. Thus we have

E[W]‚â•min‚Å°k‚â•1[(1‚àí1k)k]‚àëj=1mwjzj‚àó‚â•(1‚àí1e)OPT.\mathbb E[W]\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\ge(1-\frac{1}{e})OPT.E[W]‚â•k‚â•1min‚Äã[(1‚àík1‚Äã)k]j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã‚â•(1‚àíe1‚Äã)OPT.

This randomized rounding algorithm can be derandomized in the standard way using the method of conditional expectations.

Ëøô‰∏™ËØÅÊòé‰∏çÂ§™‰ºòÈõÖÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂèØ‰ª•Áî® ex‚â•x+1e^x\ge x+1ex‚â•x+1 ËøõË°åÊîæÁº©ÔºåÂ∞Ü‰πòÁßØÂåñ‰∏∫ eee ÁöÑÊåáÊï∞ÂíåÁöÑÂΩ¢Âºè„ÄÇ

ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂÜçÁî®Á∫øÊÄßËßÑÂàíÁöÑÁªìÊûúËá≥Â∞ë‰ºò‰∫éÊï¥Êï∞Á∫øÊÄßËßÑÂàíÁöÑÁªìÊûúÔºåÂæóÂà∞ Pr‚Å°[Ci(x)=1]‚â•1‚àíexp‚Å°(‚àízj‚àó)\Pr[C_i(x)=1]\ge1-\exp(-z_j^*)Pr[Ci‚Äã(x)=1]‚â•1‚àíexp(‚àízj‚àó‚Äã)„ÄÇ

Choosing the Better of 2 Solutions

Consider a given clause CjC_jCj‚Äã of length ljl_jlj‚Äã. The randomized rounding algorithm satisfies the clause with probability at least [(1‚àí1lj)lj]zj‚àó\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*[(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã]zj‚àó‚Äã, while the unbiased randomized algorithm satisfies the clause with probability 1‚àí2‚àílj‚â•(1‚àí2‚àílj)zj‚àó1-2^{-l_j}\ge(1-2^{-l_j})z_j^*1‚àí2‚àílj‚Äã‚â•(1‚àí2‚àílj‚Äã)zj‚àó‚Äã.

When the clause is short, it is very likely to be satisfied by the randomized rounding algorithm, tough not by the unbiased randomized algorithm. When the clause is long, the opposite is true.

ü§îTheorem 6. Choosing the better of the two solutions given by the randomized rounding algorithm and the unbiased randomized algorithm yields a randomized 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Let W1W_1W1‚Äã be a random variable denoting the value of the solution by randomized rounding algorithm.

Let W2W_2W2‚Äã be the results of unbiased randomized algorithm. To show:

E[max‚Å°(W1,W2)]‚â•34OPT\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\frac{3}{4}OPT\\E[max(W1‚Äã,W2‚Äã)]‚â•43‚ÄãOPT

Observe that

E[max‚Å°(W1,W2)]‚â•E[12(W1+W2)]=12E[W1]+12E[W2]‚â•12‚àëj=1mwjzj‚àó[(1‚àí1lj)lj]+12‚àëj=1mwj(1‚àí2‚àílj)‚â•‚àëj=1mwjzj‚àó[12(1‚àí(1‚àí1lj)lj)+12(1‚àí2‚àílj)].\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\mathbb E[\frac{1}{2}(W_1+W_2)]\\=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_1]+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_2]\\\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j(1-2^{-l_j})\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right].E[max(W1‚Äã,W2‚Äã)]‚â•E[21‚Äã(W1‚Äã+W2‚Äã)]=21‚ÄãE[W1‚Äã]+21‚ÄãE[W2‚Äã]‚â•21‚Äãj=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã[(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã]+21‚Äãj=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äã(1‚àí2‚àílj‚Äã)‚â•j=1‚àëm‚Äãwj‚Äãzj‚àó‚Äã[21‚Äã(1‚àí(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã)+21‚Äã(1‚àí2‚àílj‚Äã)].

Claim that

[12(1‚àí(1‚àí1lj)lj)+12(1‚àí2‚àílj)]‚â•34\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right]\ge\frac{3}{4}[21‚Äã(1‚àí(1‚àílj‚Äã1‚Äã)lj‚Äã)+21‚Äã(1‚àí2‚àílj‚Äã)]‚â•43‚Äã

for all positive integers ljl_jlj‚Äã.

ÈÄöËøáÊ±ÇÂØºÁ≠âÊñπÊ≥ïÂèØ‰ª•Ê±ÇÂá∫Ëøô‰∏™ÂºèÂ≠êÁöÑÊúÄÂ∞èÂÄºÔºå‰∏çÂ§™‰ºòÈõÖÂïä‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

Notice that taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms gives at least half of sum of two results.

Thus taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms is a deterministic 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm.

Non-linear Randomized Rounding

3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT can be obtained by using randomized rounding with a non-linear function fff.

fff is a function from [0,1][0,1][0,1] to [1,0][1,0][1,0]

Select fff s.t. 1‚àí4‚àíy‚â§f(y)‚â§4y‚àí11-4^{-y}\le f(y)\le 4^{y-1}1‚àí4‚àíy‚â§f(y)‚â§4y‚àí1 for every y‚àà[0,1]y\in[0,1]y‚àà[0,1]. Such an fff does exist.

Use the similar analysis of linear randomized rounding.

entry.title: Êï∞ÊçÆÊåñÊéò 12 Frequent Itemsets and Association Rules
entry.content:
Frequent itemsets and association rules.

This problem aims to find a set of items that are bought together. These itemsets can be efficiently mined by exploiting the apriori principle of the support measure.

Frequent Itemsets Mining

Frequent itemsets: collections of objects that appear a minimum number of times in the baskets of the customers.

Set of ddd items I\mathcal II, set of nnn transactions identifiers T\mathcal TT.

Dataset D\mathcal DD is a set of pairs (i,t)‚ààI√óT(i,t)\in\mathcal I\times\mathcal T(i,t)‚ààI√óT.

A basket is a transaction-set t(D)={i1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,i‚à£t‚à£}t(\mathcal D)=\{i_1,\cdots,i_{|t|}\}t(D)={i1‚Äã,‚ãØ,i‚à£t‚à£‚Äã}.

An itemset is a subset of I‚äÜ2II\subseteq2^\mathcal II‚äÜ2I items, where 2I2^\mathcal I2I is the powerset of all subsets of I\mathcal II.

Definition of support: For an itemset III we define the support œÉ(I)\sigma(I)œÉ(I) as the number of transactions that contain itemset III, i.e., œÉ(I)=‚à£{t‚ààT‚à£I‚äÜt(D)}‚à£\sigma(I)=|\{t\in\mathcal T|I\subseteq t(\mathcal D)\}|œÉ(I)=‚à£{t‚ààT‚à£I‚äÜt(D)}‚à£.

Frequent itemset mining problem finds all the itemsets I‚äÜ2II\subseteq 2^\mathcal II‚äÜ2I that have a support œÉ(I)‚â•minsup\sigma(I)\ge minsupœÉ(I)‚â•minsup. The support can be expressed as a number or a percentage, similarly to frequent subgraph mining in last lecture. If we have ddd items, we have potentially 2d2^d2d itemsets. Itemsets are typically represented in a lattice structure, in which the root is empty, and each node is the union of itemsets in the parent nodes. The question is how do we find frequent itemsets efficiently.

A naive solution. To count each itemset individually. This requires to construct 2d2^d2d itemsets and compte the frequency for each of them, reaching O(2dnw)\mathcal O(2^dnw)O(2dnw) time and O(d)\mathcal O(d)O(d) space, where www is the size of the largest transaction. üëéIMPRACTICAL!

The Apriori Algorithm

If X,Y‚àà2IX,Y\in 2^\mathcal IX,Y‚àà2I are two itemsets s.t. X‚äÜYX\subseteq YX‚äÜY, the support œÉ(X)‚â•œÉ(Y)\sigma(X)\ge\sigma(Y)œÉ(X)‚â•œÉ(Y). We say that the support is anti-monotone.

The algorithm exploits the Apriori property by means of an iterative process that alternates frequent itemset generation, and candidate generation. Let CkC_kCk‚Äã be the candidate itemsets of size kkk, let LkL_kLk‚Äã be the frequent itemsets of size kkk. The Apriori algorithm starts from the intuition that, instead of generating all the itemsets, the candidates of size kkk should only contain frequent itemsets of size k‚àí1k-1k‚àí1.

Pseudo-code

Input: Data D\mathcal DD, items I\mathcal II, minimum support minsupminsupminsup.

  1. k‚Üê1k\gets 1k‚Üê1

  2. C1‚ÜêIC_1\gets\mathcal IC1‚Äã‚ÜêI

  3. while Ck‚â†‚àÖC_k\neq\emptyCk‚ÄãÓÄ†=‚àÖ do

    // frequent itemset generation

    • Scan DB to find which itemsets in CkC_kCk‚Äã are frequent, put them into LkL_kLk‚Äã

    // candidate generation

    • Use LkL_kLk‚Äã to generate a collection of candidate itemsets Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1‚Äã of size k+1k+1k+1.
    • k‚Üêk+1k\gets k+1k‚Üêk+1

Candidate generation. It constructs the candidate itemsets of size k+1k+1k+1 by combining frequent itemsets of size kkk. For simplicity, we assume that itemsets are ordered. Also we assume that itemsets in LkL_kLk‚Äã are ordered. We can generate candidates of size k+1k+1k+1 by joining two itemsets of size kkk that share the first k‚àí1k-1k‚àí1 items. In a database terms, we are computing a self-join between the list of candidates of size kkk using the first k‚àí1k-1k‚àí1 columns as joining attributes.

Once a new candidate is generated, we can check whether all the ordered subsets are also frequent, i.e., they are in the set LkL_kLk‚Äã. This ensure the correct application of the Apriori principle. The generatiion of candidates Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1‚Äã proceeds as follows

  1. Self-join LkL_kLk‚Äã: create set Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1‚Äã by joining frequent kkk-itemsets that share the first k‚àí1k-1k‚àí1 items
  2. Pruning step: Remove a Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1‚Äã candidate if a kkk-subset is not frequent.

Frequent itemset generation. Important step: counting the support for each of the candidates CkC_kCk‚Äã. Speed up by using hash map. Better solution: hash-tree.

Itemsets of size k=2k=2k=2. For a typical shop-basket data, the number of k=2k=2k=2 items is by far the largest among other kkk values. It‚Äôs important to have efficient, in-memory optimizations. There are 2 approaches:

  1. counting all pairs using a triangular matrix

    requires 4 bytes per pair

  2. keeping a table for triples [i,j,c][i,j,c][i,j,c], where ccc is the count of the pair of items (ii,ij)(i_i,i_j)(ii‚Äã,ij‚Äã).

    require 12 bytes per pair but only for those pair with positive count.

Factors Affecting the Complexity

  • Minimum support threshold
  • Dimensionality of the dataset
  • Size of Database
  • Average transaction width. It may increase max length of frequent itemsets and traversals of has h tree.

Association Rule Mining

It is a refinement of frequent itemsets, in which an itemset is frequent conditionally to another itemset. E.g. {a,b}‚áí{c,d,e}\{a,b\}\Rarr\{c,d,e\}{a,b}‚áí{c,d,e} means when items a,ba,ba,b occurs, also c,d,ec,d,ec,d,e occur.

Definition of association rule. It is an implication of the form X‚áíYX\Rarr YX‚áíY as the number of items YYY appears in transactions that contain XXX, i.e., Œ≥(X‚áíY)=œÉ(X‚à™Y)œÉ(X)\gamma(X\Rarr Y)=\frac{\sigma(X\cup Y)}{\sigma(X)}Œ≥(X‚áíY)=œÉ(X)œÉ(X‚à™Y)‚Äã.

The association rule mining task finds all rules at least with support minsupminsupminsup and confidence mincon¬†fmin con\ fmincon¬†f. The algorithm is apriori + additional step to generate the rules. The algorithm proceeds:

  1. Frequent itemset generation. Generate all itemsets whose support is greater than minsupminsupminsup
  2. Rule generation. Generate rules with confidence at least mincon¬†fmincon\ fmincon¬†f for each frequent itemset, where a rule is a partitioning of a frequent itemset into left-hand-side and right-hand-side.

So the pending issue for new algorithm is how do we generate such rules.

Rule Generation

The naive way: enumerate all the LHS and RHS. The process takes for each frequent itemset SSS all subsets L‚äÇSL\subset SL‚äÇS and generates rules of the form S‚àíL‚áíLS-L\Rarr LS‚àíL‚áíL that satisfy minimum confidence.

Does confidence posses the desired apriori property? Not in the strict sense.

Luckily, the apriori property holds for rules generated from the same itemset.

If we move items from LHS to RHS as the support in the denominator of the confidence increases. As such, if a rule X‚áíYX\Rarr YX‚áíY from the same item has confidence ‚â§minconf\le minconf‚â§minconf all rules in which the RHS is a superset of YYY also have low confidence and can be pruned.

So we generate a candidate rule by merging 2 rules that share the same prefix on RHS. This process is essentially the apriori algorithm on RHS.

FP-Tree and FP-Growth

A smarter and more intricate algorithm, that exploits a tree structure called FP-tree.

FP-tree construction. An FP-tree is a prefix tree that contains a compressed representation of the transaction database. Each transaction in the FP-tree is a overlapping path in the tree.

The first step before constructing the tree is sorting the itemsets to ensure the uniqueness of the prefixes.

  1. The construction of the FP-tree starts from an empty node. Each node has a label corresponding to an item and a counter, corresponding to the number of transactions in the paths containing the item.
  2. For each transaction follow the prefix-path and increase the counters on the way.
  3. If at some point we reach a leaf node we expand the path adding nodes with counter 1.
  4. Add a pointer between nodes that refer to the same item.

We add a header table corresponding to the first (from the left of the tree) correspondence of the item.

The final size of the tree depends on the redundancy in the transactions. In the best case, all transaction are the same and the FP-tree is a path. In worst case, all the transactions are different and the size of the tree is bigger than that of the data.

FP-Growth is an algorithm that takes the FP-tree as input and performs a divide-and-conquer strategy to enumerate all the frequent itemsets.

Pseudo-code

Itemsets mining with FP-Tree

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each Items i‚ààIi\in\mathcal Ii‚ààI do
    • Consider candidate itemsets CCC ending with iii
    • Recursion on CCC

The meta-algorithm works bottom-up. This means that for each possible last item, consider itemsets with last items one of items preceding it in the ordering.

The items are lexicographically ordered and the header-table contains the first occurrence of an item.

FP-Growth

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each suffix XXX do
    • Construct a prefix-tree for XXX, compute support using header table and pointers
    • If XXX is frequent then
      • Recompute support
      • Prune infrequent items
      • Prune leaves and recur

However, the items counter of the items need to be updated as the global FP-tree contains the counters for all transactions, including those not ending with the considered suffix. The counters propagates bottom-up from the leaves to the root.

Once the counters are updated, if any of the labels have support less than minsupminsupminsup the node is pruned and the subtree of the node is attacked to the node‚Äôs father. After pruning, the suffix is removed from the tree and the computation proceeds recursively bottom-up.

Pros and Cons

üëç

  • Efficient
  • Allows to compute support along with the frequent items.

üëé

  • Efficiency depends on the compaction factor
  • If the tree is bushy, the number of sub-problems to solve is large

Frequent itemsets and association rules.

This problem aims to find a set of items that are bought together. These itemsets can be
