entry.title: Fair Division 7 Ex-ante and Ex-post Fairness
entry.content:
Objective: Explore randomized indivisible allocations (equivalent to fractional allocation) and their implications on fairness: the compatibility of Ex-ante and Ex-post fairness.

Activities: Study the paper Best of Both Worlds: Ex-Ante and Ex-Post Fairness in Resource Allocation.

What does Both worlds here means?

The indivisible allocation is randomized.

  • Before the allocation, each agent has a expected valuation for the bundle. Ex-ante WORLD I

  • After the allocation, each agent has its actual valuation for the bundle. Ex-post WORLD II

Iannis told me to ignore anything related to GROUP FAIRNESS.

Indivisible goods, additive valuations.

When RANDOMIZATION is allowed, it is possible to achieve envy-freeness.

When allocation is deterministic, achieving exact fairness is impossible but approximate notions such as EF1 can be guaranteed.

Goal: Achieve both simultaneously by randomized allocation that is fair ex-ante and approximately fair ex-post.

Algorithm that achieves ex-ante EF with ex-post EF1.

ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + economic efficiency? impossible. ‚ùå

ex-ante EF + relaxed ex-post fairness + economic efficiency? feasible. ‚úîÔ∏è

Introduction

If we allowed to randomize, then we can choose an agent uniformly at random and allocate the entire set of goods. This is trivially ex-ante envy-free since all agents receive the same distribution.

ex-ante ÂèØ‰ª•ÁêÜËß£‰∏∫È¢ÑÊúüÁöÑÔºåÂÖàÈ™åÁöÑ

ex-post ÂèØ‰ª•ÁêÜËß£‰∏∫ÂÆûÊñΩÁ°ÆÂÆöÂàÜÈÖçÂêéÁöÑÔºåÂêéÈ™åÁöÑ

However, this allocation induces a large amount of envy ex-post because there are times when one agent receives everything while others receive nothing.

Some ex-post envy is unavoidable: 2 agents, 1 item.

EF1 always exists, which limits the ex-post envy, but still be unfair if some agents are systematically favored over others.

Question: Can we randomize over EF1 allocations s.t. the resulting randomized allocation is EF? aka ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

Êú¨ËÆ∫ÊñáÊèêÂá∫ÁöÑÊúüÊúõÊó†Â´âÂ¶íÂíåÂêéÈ™åÂ´âÂ¶íÁâπ‰∏ÄÁâ©ÂàÜÈÖçÔºåÂç≥

  • ÂàÜÈÖçÂâçÔºöÊâÄÊúâÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËé∑ÂæóÁöÑ‰ª∑ÂÄºÁöÑÊúüÊúõÊòØ EF ÁöÑ

  • ÂàÜÈÖçÂêéÔºöÊâÄÊúâÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁúüÂÆûËé∑Âæó‰ª∑ÂÄºÊòØ EF1 ÁöÑ

This paper: Yes.

Basic Results

en-ante\ex-postProp1+EF11EF1EF1+POEF1+fPO
Prop‚úîÔ∏è‚úîÔ∏è‚ùì‚ùå Thm. 3
EF‚úîÔ∏è‚úîÔ∏è Thm. 2‚ùì‚ùå
GF‚úîÔ∏è Cor. 1‚ùå Thm. 3‚ùå‚ùå

Algorithm: Recursive Probabilistic Serial, which produces an ex-ante EF distribution over deterministic allocation that each satisfy EF1.

Impossibility of ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + ex-ante PO.

But with relaxation of ex-post fairness, awe are able to achieve ex-ante group fairness (GF) (aka EF + PO), in conjunction with Prop1 or EF11 (envy-freeness up to one good more-and-less)

EF1‚áíEF11,EF1‚áíPROP1EF1\Rarr EF_1^1,EF1\Rarr PROP1EF1‚áíEF11‚Äã,EF1‚áíPROP1.

Related Work

Omitted

Preliminaries

Agent N=[n]N=[n]N=[n], Indivisible item M=[m]M=[m]M=[m].

Fractional and Randomized Allocations

Fractional allocation: for every item jjj, we have ‚àëi‚ààNAi,j‚â§1\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}\le1‚àëi‚ààN‚ÄãAi,j‚Äã‚â§1.

Complete allocation: a fractional allocation AAA satisfying ‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àëi‚ààNAi,j=1\forall j\in M,\sum_{i\in N}A_{i,j}=1‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àëi‚ààN‚ÄãAi,j‚Äã=1. Otherwise call it partial allocation.

Integral allocation: a fractional allocation if Ai,j‚àà{0,1}‚àÄi‚ààN,j‚ààMA_{i,j}\in\{0,1\}\forall i\in N,j\in MAi,j‚Äã‚àà{0,1}‚àÄi‚ààN,j‚ààM.

Let X\mathcal XX be all fractional allocations w.r.t. N,MN,MN,M.

Randomized allocation

X\mathbf XX, a lottery over integral allocations.

X\mathbf XX is specified by a set of ‚Ñì‚ààN\ell\in\mathbb N‚Ñì‚ààN ordered pairs {(pk,Ak)}k‚àà[‚Ñì]\{(p^k,A^k)\}_{k\in[\ell]}{(pk,Ak)}k‚àà[‚Ñì]‚Äã.

AkA^kAk is an integral allocation implemented with probability pk‚àà[0,1]p^k\in[0,1]pk‚àà[0,1].

The support of X\mathbf XX is the set of integral allocations.

Preferences

gj‚âΩigk‚áîvi,j‚â•vi,kg_j\succcurlyeq_i g_k\Lrarr v_{i,j}\ge v_{i,k}gj‚Äã‚âΩi‚Äãgk‚Äã‚áîvi,j‚Äã‚â•vi,k‚Äã

gj‚âªigk‚áîvi,j>vi,kg_j\succ_i g_k\Lrarr v_{i,j}\gt v_{i,k}gj‚Äã‚âªi‚Äãgk‚Äã‚áîvi,j‚Äã>vi,k‚Äã

The utility of agent iii under X‚ààXX\in\mathcal XX‚ààX is vi(Xi)=‚àëj‚ààMXi,j‚ãÖvi,jv_i(X_i)=\sum_{j\in M}X_{i,j}\cdot v_{i,j}vi‚Äã(Xi‚Äã)=‚àëj‚ààM‚ÄãXi,j‚Äã‚ãÖvi,j‚Äã.

Allocation rule

f:I‚Üí2Xf:\mathcal I\rarr2^\mathcal Xf:I‚Üí2X

Fractional Maximum Nash Welfare Rule. Given an instance I‚ààII\in\mathcal II‚ààI, the fractional MNW returns all fractional allocations that maximize the product of agents‚Äô utilities, i.e., MNW(I)=arg‚Å°max‚Å°X‚ààX‚àèi‚ààNvi(Xi)MNW(I)=\arg\max_{X\in\mathcal X}\prod_{i\in N}v_i(X_i)MNW(I)=argmaxX‚ààX‚Äã‚àèi‚ààN‚Äãvi‚Äã(Xi‚Äã). We refer to an allocation A‚ààMNW(I)A\in MNW(I)A‚ààMNW(I) as a fractional MNW allocation.

Integral MNW allocation maximizes the product of agents‚Äô utilities across all integral allocations.

Fairness and Efficiency Properties

PROP: Omitted

EF: Omitted

SD-EF: An allocation is SD-EF if for every pair of agents i,h‚ààNi,h\in Ni,h‚ààN, we have Xi‚âΩiSDXhX_i\succcurlyeq_i^{SD}X_hXi‚Äã‚âΩiSD‚ÄãXh‚Äã

‚ùóXi‚âΩiSDYiX_i\succcurlyeq_i^{SD}Y_iXi‚Äã‚âΩiSD‚ÄãYi‚Äã means agent iii is SD-prefers XiX_iXi‚Äã to YiY_iYi‚Äã, if for every good g‚ààMg\in Mg‚ààM, we have

‚àëgj‚àà{g‚Ä≤‚ààM:g‚Ä≤‚âΩig}Xi,j‚â•‚àëgj‚àà{g‚Ä≤‚ààM:g‚Ä≤‚âΩig}Yi,j\sum_{g_j\in\{g'\in M:g'\succcurlyeq_ig\}}X_{i,j}\ge\sum_{g_j\in\{g'\in M:g'\succcurlyeq_ig\}}Y_{i,j}gj‚Äã‚àà{g‚Ä≤‚ààM:g‚Ä≤‚âΩi‚Äãg}‚àë‚ÄãXi,j‚Äã‚â•gj‚Äã‚àà{g‚Ä≤‚ààM:g‚Ä≤‚âΩi‚Äãg}‚àë‚ÄãYi,j‚Äã

For example: 333 agents, 444 goods.

Based on round-robin, with manipulation of agent order. Uniformly randomizing the agent ordering also achieves ex-ante proportionality.

ü§îProposition 2. With additive valuations, randomized round-robin is ex-ante PROP and ex-post EF1.

Obviously, randomized round-robin is ex-post EF1. For ex-ante PROP, fix an agent iii, and suppose, without loss of generality, that vi,1‚â•vi,2‚â•‚ãØ‚â•vi,mv_{i,1}\ge v_{i,2}\ge\cdots\ge v_{i,m}vi,1‚Äã‚â•vi,2‚Äã‚â•‚ãØ‚â•vi,m‚Äã. Suppose m=cnm=cnm=cn for some positive integer ccc.

When agent iii is kkk-th in the ordering, her value for her allocation is at least vi,k+vi,k+n+‚ãØ+vi,k+(c‚àí1)n=‚àëc‚Ä≤=1cvi,(c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+kv_{i,k}+v_{i,k+n}+\cdots+v_{i,k+(c-1)n}=\sum_{c'=1}^cv_{i,(c'-1)n+k}vi,k‚Äã+vi,k+n‚Äã+‚ãØ+vi,k+(c‚àí1)n‚Äã=‚àëc‚Ä≤=1c‚Äãvi,(c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+k‚Äã because the c‚Ä≤c'c‚Ä≤-th good she chooses must be no less preferred than her (c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+k(c'-1)n+k(c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+k-th most preferred good.

Since she appears in every position in the ordering with probability 1/n1/n1/n, her expected value is at least 1n‚àëk=1m‚àëc‚Ä≤=1cvi,(c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+k=1n‚àëj=1mgi,j\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^m\sum_{c'=1}^cv_{i,(c'-1)n+k}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^mg_{i,j}n1‚Äã‚àëk=1m‚Äã‚àëc‚Ä≤=1c‚Äãvi,(c‚Ä≤‚àí1)n+k‚Äã=n1‚Äã‚àëj=1m‚Äãgi,j‚Äã, which matches her proportionality guarantee.

However, just by randomizing agent order, sometimes we fail to achieve ex-ante EF. Example omitted.

Noted that there are n!n!n! possible agent orders. For iii, some orders may better than the others.

Instead of starting from a method that guarantees ex-post EF1 and using it to achieve ex-ante EF, we do the opposite: Start from a fractional EF allocation and implement it using integral EF1 allocations.

Probabilistic serial is an algorithm that produces a fractional EF allocations.

  • serial eating protocol wherein all agents simultaneously start eating their respective favorite goods at the same constant speed.
  • Once a good is completely consumed by a subset of agents, each of those agents proceeds to eating her favorite available good at the same speed.
  • The algorithm terminates when all goods have been eaten, and fraction of each good consumed by an agent is allocated to her.

A very vivid algorithm

A useful property of this algorithm: it only uses the ordinal preferences of agents over goods, and computes an allocation that is ex-ante envy-free for any additive utilities consistent with the ordinal preferences. Thus, it‚Äôs SD-EF.

Use a variant of probabilistic serial, recursive probabilistic serial, which provides the desired fairness guarantees, i.e., ex-ante EF and ex-post EF1.

Recursive Probabilistic Serial

Given as input a subset of goods M‚Ä≤‚äÜMM'\subseteq MM‚Ä≤‚äÜM, the algorithm allows each agent to consume its favorite available good in M‚Ä≤M'M‚Ä≤ out of those that have not yet been fully consumed at a rate of one good per unit time.

Let Xt=eating(M‚Ä≤,t)X^t=eating(M',t)Xt=eating(M‚Ä≤,t) denote the partial allocation obtained when the algorithm is run for ttt unit of time. Note that eating(M,‚åàmn‚åâ)eating(M,\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil)eating(M,‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ) is equivalent to the outcome of the probabilistic serial algorithm.

üéØü§îTheorem 1. (Brikhoff-von Neumann) Let XXX be a real-valued n√ómn\times mn√óm matrix s.t.

  1. X_{ij}\in[0,1]\forall i\in[n]\and j\in[m]
  2. ‚àëj=1mXij‚â§1‚àÄi‚àà[n]\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\le1\forall i\in[n]‚àëj=1m‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚â§1‚àÄi‚àà[n]
  3. ‚àëi=1nXij‚â§1‚àÄj‚àà[m]\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\le1\forall j\in[m]‚àëi=1n‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚â§1‚àÄj‚àà[m]

Then, in strongly polynomial time, one can compute integral matrices A1,A2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,AqA^1,A^2,\cdots,A^qA1,A2,‚ãØ,Aq and weights w1,w2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,wq‚àà[0,1]w^1,w^2,\cdots,w^q\in[0,1]w1,w2,‚ãØ,wq‚àà[0,1] s.t.

  1. ‚àëk=1qwk=1\sum_{k=1}^qw^k=1‚àëk=1q‚Äãwk=1 and X=‚àëk=1qwkAkX=\sum_{k=1}^qw^kA^kX=‚àëk=1q‚ÄãwkAk
  2. For each integral matrix AkA^kAk, we have A^k_{ij}\in\{0,1\}\forall i\in[n]\and j\in[m]
  3. For every k‚àà[q]k\in[q]k‚àà[q], we have
    • ‚åä‚àëj=1mXij‚åã‚â§‚àëj=1mAijk‚â§‚åà‚àëj=1mXij‚åâ\lfloor\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rfloor\le\sum_{j=1}^mA^k_{ij}\le\lceil\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rceil‚åä‚àëj=1m‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚åã‚â§‚àëj=1m‚ÄãAijk‚Äã‚â§‚åà‚àëj=1m‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚åâ
    • ‚åä‚àëi=1nXij‚åã‚â§‚àëi=1nAijk‚â§‚åà‚àëi=1nXij‚åâ\lfloor\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\rfloor\le\sum_{i=1}^nA^k_{ij}\le\lceil\sum_{i=1}^nX_{ij}\rceil‚åä‚àëi=1n‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚åã‚â§‚àëi=1n‚ÄãAijk‚Äã‚â§‚åà‚àëi=1n‚ÄãXij‚Äã‚åâ

The algorithm proceeds in stages. In each stages, the EATING procedure is run for one unit of time, after which every agent has consumed a total mass of one item.

Then, by theorem 1, this fractional partial allocation can be decomposed into integral allocations. By 3. of theorem 1, each agent receives exactly one item in each integral allocation in the support.

We interpret the weights w1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,wqw^1,\cdots,w^qw1,‚ãØ,wq as probabilities, and sample an integral allocation from this distribution before proceeding to the next stage.

The algorithm then fixes the assignments of the goods to the agents in accordance with the aforementioned integral partial allocation, and repeats the eating procedure with the reduced set of goods.

In the final stage of the algorithm, fewer than nnn goods might remain, in which case some agents do not receive any good under the integral allocation. The full procedure is describe in pseudo code.

Pseudo-code of Algorithm 1

Ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1

  1. B‚Üê(‚àÖ,‚ãØ‚Äâ,‚àÖ)B\gets(\empty,\cdots,\empty)B‚Üê(‚àÖ,‚ãØ,‚àÖ)
  2. M0‚ÜêMM^0\gets MM0‚ÜêM
  3. for t=1t=1t=1 to ‚åàmn‚åâ\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ do
    • Xt‚ÜêX^t\getsXt‚Üê eating(Mt,1)(M^t,1)(Mt,1) // eating protocol for one unit of time
    • BvN: Xt=‚àëk=1‚Ñìwt,kAt,kX^t=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{t,k}A^{t,k}Xt=‚àëk=1‚Ñì‚Äãwt,kAt,k // decomposition from theorem 1
    • Bt‚ÜêAt,kB^t\gets A^{t,k}Bt‚ÜêAt,k with probability wt,kw^{t,k}wt,k // sampling step
    • Mt+1‚ÜêMt‚ï≤‚ãÉi‚ààNBitM^{t+1}\gets M^t\diagdown\bigcup_{i\in N}B_i^tMt+1‚ÜêMt‚ï≤‚ãÉi‚ààN‚ÄãBit‚Äã // fix the assignments according to the sampled allocation
    • Bi‚ÜêBi‚ãÉt=1‚åàmn‚åâBitB_i\gets B_i\bigcup_{t=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}B_i^tBi‚Äã‚ÜêBi‚Äã‚ãÉt=1‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ‚ÄãBit‚Äã for all i‚ààNi\in Ni‚ààN // update integral allocation
  4. return BBB

Every integral allocation returned by Algorithm 1 satisfies EF1.

ü§îLemma 1. Let t<‚åàmn‚åât\lt\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilt<‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ. Let gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t‚Äã denote the good allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt of Algorithm 1. Then agent iii weakly prefers gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t‚Äã to all goods in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1 (goods unallocated after ttt iterations of the algorithm).

Proof by contradiction.

If there exists a good g‚àó‚ààMt+1g^*\in M^{t+1}g‚àó‚ààMt+1 s.t. vi(g‚àó)>vi(gi,t)v_i(g^*)\gt v_i(g_{i,t})vi‚Äã(g‚àó)>vi‚Äã(gi,t‚Äã), then by theorem 1, agent iii must have eaten a non-zero share of good gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t‚Äã in iteration ttt. On the other hand, g‚àó‚ààMt+1g^*\in M^{t+1}g‚àó‚ààMt+1 implies that g‚àó‚ààMtg^*\in M^tg‚àó‚ààMt, and thus g‚àóg^*g‚àó must not be fully consumed in iteration ttt. However, since gi(g‚àó)>vi(g)g_i(g^*)\gt v_i(g)gi‚Äã(g‚àó)>vi‚Äã(g), agent iii should have then consumed g‚àóg^*g‚àó before consuming gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t‚Äã in iteration ttt, which is a contradiction.

ü§îLemma 2. Every integral allocation returned by Algorithm 1 satisfies EF1.

‚àÄi‚àà[n]\forall i\in[n]‚àÄi‚àà[n], let gi,tg_{i,t}gi,t‚Äã denote the good received by agent iii in iteration ttt. Fix a pair of agents i,k‚ààNi,k\in Ni,k‚ààN. By lemma 1, for every t<‚åàmn‚åât\lt\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilt<‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ, we have vi(gi,t)‚â•vi(gk,t+1)v_i(g_{i,t})\ge v_i(g_{k,t+1})vi‚Äã(gi,t‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(gk,t+1‚Äã) because gk,t+1‚ààMt+1g_{k,t+1}\in M^{t+1}gk,t+1‚Äã‚ààMt+1. Hence,

vi(Ai)‚â•‚àëi=1‚åàmn‚åâ‚àí1vi(gi,t)‚â•‚àëi=2‚åàmn‚åâvi(gi,t)=vi(Ak‚ï≤{gk,1})v_i(A_i)\ge\sum_{i=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil-1}v_i(g_{i,t})\ge\sum_{i=2}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}v_i(g_{i,t})=v_i(A_k\diagdown\{g_{k,1}\})vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)‚â•i=1‚àë‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ‚àí1‚Äãvi‚Äã(gi,t‚Äã)‚â•i=2‚àë‚åànm‚Äã‚åâ‚Äãvi‚Äã(gi,t‚Äã)=vi‚Äã(Ak‚Äã‚ï≤{gk,1‚Äã})

üéØü§îTheorem 2. The randomized allocation implemented by algorithm 1 is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

By lemma, it is indeed ex-post EF1.

Notice that each agent eats her preferred available good at each point in time during the eating algorithm. Therefore, for any iteration ttt, the partial fractional allocation XtX^tXt computed by the eating procedure in iteration ttt is EF.

The rest is induction.

Since Recursive Probabilistic Serial takes only the ordinal references of agents over goods as input, thus it is in fact ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

A Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Full randomized allocation constructed by Algorithm 1 require exponential time.

Approach to reducing the support size is to use the Carath√©odory‚Äôs theorem from convex analysis: If a point x‚ààRdx\in\mathbb R^dx‚ààRd lies in the convex hull of a set PPP, then xxx can be expressed as a convex combination of at most d+1d+1d+1 vertices of PPP.

Any fractional allocation XXX is a point in an n√ómn\times mn√óm-dimensional space. By Carath√©odory‚Äôs theorem, if it is a convex combination of integral allocations in the support {A1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,A‚Ñì}\{A^1,\cdots,A^\ell\}{A1,‚ãØ,A‚Ñì}, then it can also be written as a convex combination of at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 allocations from this set.

This establishes the existence of a convex combination with small support, it does not automatically provide an efficient algorithm for converting a convex combination with large support to one with small support.

In the modification of recursive probabilistic serial, we ensure that the support size remains mn+1mn+1mn+1 after every step of ‚Äúbranching out‚Äù.

Every step of branching out can increase the support size of mn+1mn+1mn+1 to (nm+1)‚ãÖp(m,n)(nm+1)\cdot p(m,n)(nm+1)‚ãÖp(m,n). Thus we need a way to reduce the support size from at most (mn+1)‚ãÖp(m,n)(mn+1)\cdot p(m,n)(mn+1)‚ãÖp(m,n) to at most nm+1nm+1nm+1.

ü§îProposition 3. There is a polynomial-time algorithm, that given a polytope P\mathcal PP with a strong separation oracle and a point y‚ààPy\in\mathcal Py‚ààP, returns a representation of yyy as a convex combination of dim‚Å°(P)+1\dim(\mathcal P)+1dim(P)+1 vertices of P\mathcal PP.

Notice that at the end of the first iteration t=1t=1t=1, the fractional partial allocation X1X^1X1 consists of a polynomial number of integral allocations in its support, i.e., X1=‚àëk=1‚Ñìw1,kA1,kX^1=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{1,k}A^{1,k}X1=‚àëk=1‚Ñì‚Äãw1,kA1,k, where ‚Ñì=p(m,n)\ell=p(m,n)‚Ñì=p(m,n) for some polynomial ppp. Consider the polytope P1\mathcal P^1P1 formed by the convex hull of the integral allocations A1,1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,A1,‚ÑìA^{1,1},\cdots,A^{1,\ell}A1,1,‚ãØ,A1,‚Ñì as follows

\mathcal P^1=\{z:z=\sum_k\alpha_kA^{1,k}\text{ where }(\alpha_k\ge0\forall k\in[\ell])\and(\sum_k\alpha_k=1)\}

polytope Â§öËÉû‰Ωì

  1. Convexity: A polytope is a convex set, meaning that for any two points inside the polytope, the line segment connecting them lies entirely within the polytope.
  2. Finite Set of Vertices: A polytope is defined by a finite set of vertices (or corners) in Euclidean space. These vertices are the extreme points of the polytope and determine its shape.
  3. Higher-Dimensional Analogues: Just as a polygon is a two-dimensional polytope and a polyhedron is a three-dimensional polytope, polytopes can exist in any finite number of dimensions. For example, a four-dimensional polytope is called a polytope, and a five-dimensional polytope is called a polychoron.
  4. Faces: The faces of a polytope are the lower-dimensional subsets of the polytope that are themselves polytopes. For example, in a three-dimensional polyhedron, the faces are the polygons that form its surface.
  5. Simplexes and Polygons: Simplexes are special types of polytopes that are defined as the convex hull of a set of affinely independent points. A simplex in two dimensions is a triangle, and in three dimensions, it is a tetrahedron. Polygons are also considered special cases of polytopes.

Observe that P1\mathcal P^1P1 admits a polynomial-time strong separation oracle. One can decide in polynomial time whether a given point y‚ààRn√ómy\in\mathbb R^{n\times m}y‚ààRn√óm belongs to P1\mathcal P^1P1, or return a separating hyper-plane if it doesn‚Äôt. This implies that an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, as guaranteed by Carath√©odory‚Äôs theorem can be computed in polynomial time.

Having computed an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, we obtain at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 sub-instances in each of which we re-run algorithm. Notice that this result in a probability distribution over (nm+1)‚ãÖp(n,m)(nm+1)\cdot p(n,m)(nm+1)‚ãÖp(n,m) deterministic allocations at the end of the second iteration. Re-invoke algorithmic version of Carath√©odory‚Äôs theorem to obtain a decomposition over at most mn+1mn+1mn+1 of these integral allocations in polynomial time.

Produced randomized allocation has support that is a subset of the support of the randomized allocation produced by recursive probabilistic serial. Hence, ex-post EF1 of this modified procedure follows immediately from lemma 1.

Like algorithm 1, this algorithm produces the same ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

Impossibility: ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO

The previous lacks efficiency.

ex-ante PO ‚áí\Rarr‚áí ex-post fPO ‚áí\Rarr‚áí ex-post PO

ex-ante EF + ex-post PO + ex-post EF1? Not solve‚Ä¶

How about stronger one, ex-post fPO? The answer is negative for ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

üéØü§îTheorem 3. There exists an instance with additive valuations in which no randomized allocation is simultaneously ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

It suffices to give an instance with unique EF1 + fPO allocation which violates PROP.

2 goods g1,g2g_1,g_2g1‚Äã,g2‚Äã, 2 agent a1,a2a_1,a_2a1‚Äã,a2‚Äã with valuations

g1g_1g1‚Äãg2g_2g2‚Äã
a1a_1a1‚Äã12
a2a_2a2‚Äã13

This instance has exactlly 2 integral EF1 allocations: A=({g1},{g2})A=(\{g_1\},\{g_2\})A=({g1‚Äã},{g2‚Äã}) and B=({g2},{g1})B=(\{g_2\},\{g_1\})B=({g2‚Äã},{g1‚Äã}). It‚Äôs easy to check that BBB is not fPO, since it is Pareto dominated by a fractional allocation XXX that assign g1g_1g1‚Äã to a1a_1a1‚Äã and splits g2g_2g2‚Äã equally between 2 agents.

AAA is fPO, maximizing the utilitarian social welfare.

Observe that AAA violates PROP since v1(A1)=v1(g1)<12v1(g1‚à™g2)v_1(A_1)=v_1(g_1)\lt\frac{1}{2}v_1(g_1\cup g_2)v1‚Äã(A1‚Äã)=v1‚Äã(g1‚Äã)<21‚Äãv1‚Äã(g1‚Äã‚à™g2‚Äã).

Additionally, ex-ante EF and ex-ante GF imply ex-ante PROP, thus these are also incompatible with ex-post EF1 + PO.

Since ex-ante PO implies ex-post fPO, thus ex-ante (PROP + PO) and ex-ante (EF + PO) are incompatible with ex-post EF1.

Possibility: ex-ante GF + ex-post PROP1 + ex-post EF11

Omitted

Characterizing MNW

Seems related to GF, can be omitted.

The Case of Bads

‚ÄúBads‚Äù here means chores. aka all items are negative valued.

Let MMM be set of mmm bads. Fractional, integral and randomized allocations are defined analogously as in the case of goods.

However the agents have non-positive valuation functions. There are differences when defining fairness notions.

PROP1, aka proportionality up to one bad. An integral allocation AAA is PROP1 if for every agent iii, either vi(Ai)‚â•vi(M)/nv_i(A_i)\ge v_i(M)/nvi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(M)/n or there exists a bad j‚ààAij\in A_ij‚ààAi‚Äã s.t. vi(Ai‚ï≤{j})‚â•vi(M)/nv_i(A_i\diagdown\{j\})\ge v_i(M)/nvi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã‚ï≤{j})‚â•vi‚Äã(M)/n, where vi(M)v_i(M)vi‚Äã(M) is iii‚Äôs valuation for all bads.

EFk, aka envy-freeness up to kkk bads. An integral allocation AAA is EFk if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, there ‚àÉSi‚äÜAi\exist S_i\subseteq A_i‚àÉSi‚Äã‚äÜAi‚Äã with ‚à£Si‚à£‚â§k|S_i|\le k‚à£Si‚Äã‚à£‚â§k s.t. vi(Ai‚ï≤Si)‚â•vi(Ah)v_i(A_i\diagdown S_i)\ge v_i(A_h)vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã‚ï≤Si‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(Ah‚Äã).

EF11, aka envy-freeness up to one bad more-and-less. An integral allocation AAA is EF11 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h s.t. Ai‚â†‚àÖA_i\neq\emptyAi‚ÄãÓÄ†=‚àÖ, we have vi(Ai‚ï≤{ji})‚â•vi(Ah‚à™{jh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{j_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\cup\{j_h\})vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã‚ï≤{ji‚Äã})‚â•vi‚Äã(Ah‚Äã‚à™{jh‚Äã}) for some bads ji‚ààAij_i\in A_iji‚Äã‚ààAi‚Äã and jh‚ààÃ∏Ahj_h\not\in A_hjh‚ÄãÓÄ†‚ààAh‚Äã.

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 for Bads

Recursive Probabilistic Serial and its polynomial-time variant only use ordinal preferences of agents over goods.

Problem here: Can we construct an ordinal preference over bads in which the bads are sorted in a non-increasing order of the agent‚Äôs valuation for them.

Both RPS and its polynomial-time variant are always ex-post EF2 for bads.

ü§îProposition 6. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial variant produce randomized allocation that are ex-ante EF and ex-post EF2.

eating procedure is EF because agents are forced to eat bads at the same rate and an agent is always eating a bad that she prefers the most among all bads not fully consumed.

Since each XtX^tXt is EF, a probability distribution over XtX^tXt in different branches is also envy-free. Hence, the expected fractional allocation induced in step ttt is EF for each ttt. Hence, ex-ante EF.

For ex-post EF2, let AAA be an integral allocation produced by RPS. By lemma 1 still holds for bads.

For t<‚åàm/n‚åât\lt\lceil m/n\rceilt<‚åàm/n‚åâ, if bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t‚Äã denotes the bad allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt, then agent iii prefers bi,tb_{i,t}bi,t‚Äã to all bads in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1.

When t<‚åäm/n‚åãt\lt\lfloor m/n \rfloort<‚åäm/n‚åã, we know that another agent hhh must receive a bad in round t+1‚â§‚åäm/n‚åãt+1\le\lfloor m/n \rfloort+1‚â§‚åäm/n‚åã. Hence, for all agents i,h‚ààNi,h\in Ni,h‚ààN and all t<‚åäm/n‚åãt\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<‚åäm/n‚åã, we have vi(bi,t)‚â•vi(bh,t+1)v_i(b_{i,t})\ge v_i(b_{h,t+1})vi‚Äã(bi,t‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(bh,t+1‚Äã).

Summing over t<‚åäm/n‚åãt\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<‚åäm/n‚åã, we get

vi({bi,t:1‚â§t<‚åäm/n‚åã})‚â•vi({bh,t:2‚â§t‚â§‚åäm/n‚åã})‚â•vi(Ah)v_i(\lbrace b_{i,t}:1\le t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(\lbrace b_{h,t}:2\le t\le\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(A_h)vi‚Äã({bi,t‚Äã:1‚â§t<‚åäm/n‚åã})‚â•vi‚Äã({bh,t‚Äã:2‚â§t‚â§‚åäm/n‚åã})‚â•vi‚Äã(Ah‚Äã)

In the LHS, there are at most 2 bads missing from AiA_iAi‚Äã:

  • The bad allocated to agent iii in round ‚åäm/n‚åã\lfloor m/n\rfloor‚åäm/n‚åã
  • Tge bad which may be allocated tot agent iii in the final round ‚åàm/n‚åâ\lceil m/n\rceil‚åàm/n‚åâ

Q.E.D.

Naturally, the algorithm also produces ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF2.

When mmm is a multiple of nnn, it turns out that the allocation is in fact ex-post EF1.

ü§îLemma 5. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial-time variant from Section 3.2 produce randomized allocations that are ex-ante envy-free (EF) and ex-post envy-free up to one bad (EF1) whenever the number of bads is divisible by the number of agents.

Proof by proposition 6.

If nnn divides mmm, we guarantee that there is only one bad missing from the LHS, which is that allocated to agent iii in round m/nm/nm/n.

Simple modification of RPS, simply add a number of ‚Äúdummy bads‚Äù which all agent value at 000 s.t. the total number of bads becomes divisible by the number of nnn, then run RPS to compute ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

üéØü§îTheorem 6. For additive valuation over bads, there always exists a randomized allocation that is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 which can be computed in polynomial time.

What about fair division of mixed manna?

Each item can be either a good or a bad for each agent.

EF1 can be generalized to the mixed manna setting. It requires that if iii envies hhh, then the envy can be eliminated by either removing one item from agent hhh‚Äôs bundle (which must be a good for iii), or one item from agent iii‚Äôs bundle (which must be a bad for iii).

EF1 aka envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is EF1 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists an item o‚ààAi‚à™Aho\in A_i\cup A_ho‚ààAi‚Äã‚à™Ah‚Äã s.t. vi(Ai‚ï≤{o})‚â•vi(Ah‚ï≤{o})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o\})vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã‚ï≤{o})‚â•vi‚Äã(Ah‚Äã‚ï≤{o}).

The algorithm of this paper achieve the relaxation of EF1 in mixed manna setting, w-EF1.

w-EF1 aka weak envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is w-EF1 if for every pair i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists a good oh‚ààAho_h\in A_hoh‚Äã‚ààAh‚Äã and/or a bad oi‚ààAio_i\in A_ioi‚Äã‚ààAi‚Äã s.t. vi(Ai‚ï≤{oi})‚â•vi(Ah‚ï≤{oh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o_h\})vi‚Äã(Ai‚Äã‚ï≤{oi‚Äã})‚â•vi‚Äã(Ah‚Äã‚ï≤{oh‚Äã}).

üéØü§îTheorem 7. For additive valuation in the mixed manna setting, there always exists a randomized algorithm producing ex-ante EF + ex-post w-EF1, which can be computed in polynomial time.

Add dummy items to guarantee that mmm is a integer multiple of nnn, and remove them at the end.

When we run RPS on such instance, we can again apply the same argument as in the proof in proposition 6. That is equivalent to ex-post w-EF1 guarantee.

Of course, this results is also ex-ante SD-EF and ex-post SD-w-EF1 for mixed manna.

Ex-ante GF + Ex-post PROP1 + Ex-post EF11 for Bads

Omitted

Discussion

‚ùìOpen question:

  • ex-ante PROP + ex-post (EF1 + PO)
  • ex-ante EF + ex-post (EF1 + PO)

Difficulty: hard to analyze the methods of finding EF1 + PO allocations.

‚ùìOpen question:

  • Does there always exist an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii doesn‚Äôt envy agent jjj?
  • What about an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii does not envy any other agent?
  • Given a priority ordering over the agents, does there always exist an EF1 + PO allocation in which no agent envies an agent with lower priority?

Other possible work direction: EFX/MMS for ex-post fairness?

How about ex-ante and ex-post fairness guarantees in voting, matching and public decision-making?

entry.title: ÈöèÊú∫ÁÆóÊ≥ï 10 Invertible Bloom Filters
entry.content:
Brief Introduction

Invertible Bloom Lookup Table (abbr. IBLT)

a fancy hash-table stores key-value pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y)

space budget: ttt

Guarantee

It ‚Äúworks‚Äù when the number of key-value pairs, nnn, in table has n‚â§tn\le tn‚â§t.

‚Äútemporarily‚Äù stops working if n>tn\gt tn>t.

starts working again if nnn drops below ttt.

Operations

(x,y) is key-value pair.

insert(x,y), delete(x,y), get(x), listentries.

Details

Start with table with k‚â•3k\ge3k‚â•3 rows, m=2√ótm=2\times tm=2√ót columns.

In each row, we have a hash function h1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,hkh_1,\cdots,h_kh1‚Äã,‚ãØ,hk‚Äã.

hih_ihi‚Äã is universal.

Each of the entry, called cell, stores values:

  • count
  • key_sum
  • value_sum

Insert Operation

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi‚Äã(x)]
    • c.count++c.count++c.count++
    • c.key_sum+=xc.key\_sum+= xc.key_sum+=x
    • c.value_sum+=yc.value\_sum+=yc.value_sum+=y

Delete Operation

‚Äúundo‚Äù insert operation

We must know the pair is there before deletion.

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi‚Äã(x)]
    • c.count‚àí‚àíc.count--c.count‚àí‚àí
    • c.key_sum‚àí=xc.key\_sum-= xc.key_sum‚àí=x
    • c.value_sum‚àí=yc.value\_sum-=yc.value_sum‚àí=y

Get Operation

slightly different from min sketch count

  1. ret=‚àûret=\inftyret=‚àû

  2. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk

    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hi‚Äã(x)]

    • if c.count==0c.count==0c.count==0 return ‚Äúnot there‚Äù

    • else if c.count==1c.count==1c.count==1 then

      • if c.key_sum==xc.key\_sum==xc.key_sum==x

        return c.value_sumc.value\_sumc.value_sum

      • else return ‚Äúnot there‚Äù

  3. return ‚Äúdon‚Äôt know‚Äù

Probability of Success

If n‚â§tn\le tn‚â§t, then get(x) succeeds with probability ‚â•1‚àí2‚àík\ge1-2^{-k}‚â•1‚àí2‚àík.

Assume k>1k\gt1k>1, nnn pairs: (xi,yi)(x_i,y_i)(xi‚Äã,yi‚Äã) is stored in IBLT, n‚â§tn\le tn‚â§t.

For get(x)

  • If xxx is in IBLT

    1. ÂΩì xxx Âú® IBLT ÁöÑËøô‰∏ÄË°åÈáåÈù¢Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØ get ÂáΩÊï∞ÂèëÁé∞ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂìàÂ∏åÂÄºÊåáÂêëÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÈÉΩÂèëÁîü‰∫ÜÁ¢∞ÊíûÁöÑÊ¶ÇÁéá„ÄÇ
    2. ÊòéÊòé xxx ‰∏çÂú® IBLT ‰∏≠Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØ get ÂáΩÊï∞ÂèëÁé∞ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂìàÂ∏åÂÄºÊåáÂêëÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆ‰∏≠Â≠òÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÄºÔºåÂç≥ count=1 ‰ΩÜ value ‰∏çÊòØ xxx ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑ„ÄÇ

    Define fail-event Ei:{h(x)=h(xi)}E_i:\{h(x)=h(x_i)\}Ei‚Äã:{h(x)=h(xi‚Äã)},

Pr‚Å°[get(x)¬†fails]=Pr‚Å°[‚ãÉxi‚â†xEi]‚â§‚àëxi‚â†xPr‚Å°[Ei]‚â§‚àëxi‚â†x1m=n‚àí1m‚â§t‚àí1m=t‚àí12t‚â§12\Pr[get(x)\text{ fails}]=\Pr[\bigcup_{x_i\neq x}E_i]\le\sum_{x_i\neq x}\Pr[E_i]\\\le\sum_{x_i\neq x}\frac{1}{m}=\frac{n-1}{m}\le\frac{t-1}{m}=\frac{t-1}{2t}\le\frac{1}{2}Pr[get(x)¬†fails]=Pr[xi‚ÄãÓÄ†=x‚ãÉ‚ÄãEi‚Äã]‚â§xi‚ÄãÓÄ†=x‚àë‚ÄãPr[Ei‚Äã]‚â§xi‚ÄãÓÄ†=x‚àë‚Äãm1‚Äã=mn‚àí1‚Äã‚â§mt‚àí1‚Äã=2tt‚àí1‚Äã‚â§21‚Äã

  • If xxx is not in IBLT.

    ÊòéÊòé xxx ‰∏çÂú® IBLT ÁöÑËøô‰∏ÄË°åÈáåÈù¢Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØ get ÂáΩÊï∞ÂæóÂá∫ËØ•ÈîÆÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂìàÂ∏åÂÄºÊåáÂêëÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÂú® IBLT Ëøô‰∏ÄË°å‰∏≠‰∫ßÁîüÁ¢∞ÊíûÁöÑÊ¶ÇÁéá„ÄÇ

    Define fail-event Eij={h(x)=h(xi)=h(xj)}E_{ij}=\{h(x)=h(x_i)=h(x_j)\}Eij‚Äã={h(x)=h(xi‚Äã)=h(xj‚Äã)}

entry.title: Êï∞ÊçÆÊåñÊéò 11 Frequent Subgraph Mining
entry.content:
A labeled graph is a triple G=(V,E,‚Ñì)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,‚Ñì) where ‚Ñì:V‚à™E‚ÜíL\ell:V\cup E\rarr L‚Ñì:V‚à™E‚ÜíL is a labeling function assigning a label from a set of labels LLL to each node and each edge.

Definition of frequency: it is encoded into a support measure that return the number of occurrences of the subgraph in the graph.

FSM in Graph Collections

A graph collection aka a graph database is a set D={G1,G2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1‚Äã,G2‚Äã,‚ãØ,Gn‚Äã} of labeled graphs Gi=(Vi,Vi,‚Ñìi),i‚àà[1,n]G_i=(V_i,V_i,\ell_i),i\in[1,n]Gi‚Äã=(Vi‚Äã,Vi‚Äã,‚Ñìi‚Äã),i‚àà[1,n].

Since a subgraph is uniquely identified by the nodes and edges of a certain graph, we need to relax the definition, so that it counts the occurrences of that subgraph in different graphs.

A graph G1(V1,E1,‚Ñì1)G_1(V_1,E_1,\ell_1)G1‚Äã(V1‚Äã,E1‚Äã,‚Ñì1‚Äã) is isomorphic ÂêåÊûÑ to a graph G2=(V2,E2,‚Ñì2)G_2=(V_2,E_2,\ell_2)G2‚Äã=(V2‚Äã,E2‚Äã,‚Ñì2‚Äã) if there exists a bijective function f:V1‚ÜíV2f:V_1\rarr V_2f:V1‚Äã‚ÜíV2‚Äã such that if u‚ààV1u\in V_1u‚ààV1‚Äã then f(u)‚ààV2f(u)\in V_2f(u)‚ààV2‚Äã and ‚Ñì1(u)=‚Ñì2(f(u))\ell_1(u)=\ell_2(f(u))‚Ñì1‚Äã(u)=‚Ñì2‚Äã(f(u)) and if (u,v)‚ààE1(u,v)\in E_1(u,v)‚ààE1‚Äã then (f(u),f(v))‚ààE2(f(u),f(v))\in E_2(f(u),f(v))‚ààE2‚Äã and ‚Ñì1((u,v))=‚Ñì2((f(u),f(v)))\ell_1((u,v))=\ell_2((f(u),f(v)))‚Ñì1‚Äã((u,v))=‚Ñì2‚Äã((f(u),f(v))).

If a graph G1G_1G1‚Äã is isomorphic to a subgraph of another graph GGG, we say G1G_1G1‚Äã is subgraph isomorphic to GGG. Subgraph isomorphism is NP-complete, which graph isomorphism is NP.

Denote: G‚äëG1G\sqsubseteq G_1G‚äëG1‚Äã a subgraph isomorphism from GGG to G1G_1G1‚Äã.

Given a collection of graphs D={G1,G2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1‚Äã,G2‚Äã,‚ãØ,Gn‚Äã} and a graph GGG, the support set DG\mathcal D_GDG‚Äã is the subset of D\mathcal DD, s.t. GGG is subgraph isomorphic to every graph in G‚Ä≤‚ààDGG'\in\mathcal D_GG‚Ä≤‚ààDG‚Äã, i.e., DG={G‚Ä≤‚ààD‚à£G‚äëG‚Ä≤}\mathcal D_G=\{G'\in\mathcal D|G\sqsubseteq G'\}DG‚Äã={G‚Ä≤‚ààD‚à£G‚äëG‚Ä≤}. The support sup‚Å°(G)\sup(G)sup(G) of GGG is the proportion œÉ(G)=‚à£DG‚à£‚à£D‚à£\sigma(G)=\frac{|\mathcal D_G|}{|\mathcal D|}œÉ(G)=‚à£D‚à£‚à£DG‚Äã‚à£‚Äã.

The Frequent Subgraph Mining FSM problem in collection of graphs D={G1,G2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1‚Äã,G2‚Äã,‚ãØ,Gn‚Äã} finds all the subgraphs GGG having at least support min‚Å°sup‚Å°\min\supminsup, i.e., œÉ(G)‚â•min‚Å°sup‚Å°\sigma(G)\ge\min\supœÉ(G)‚â•minsup.

Downward Closure Property

  • Downward closure is the property under which a support measure decreases by expanding a pattern. In particular in our case sup‚Å°(G)‚â§sup‚Å°(G‚Ä≤)\sup(G)\le\sup(G')sup(G)‚â§sup(G‚Ä≤) if G‚Ä≤‚äëGG'\sqsubseteq GG‚Ä≤‚äëG.

The downward closure property leads to 2 different family of approaches: apriori-based approaches and pattern-growth approaches.

Apriori-based Approaches

This approaches stem from the observation that any subgraph of a frequent subgraph must be frequent as well.

FSG is one of the first methods that utilizes the apriori principle. The algorithm builds on the idea that a frequent kkk-subgraph is built on top of frequent (k‚àí1)(k-1)(k‚àí1)-subgraphs, where kkk indicates the number of edges.

The algorithm simply starts enumerating frequent 111-subgraphs and 222-subgraphs and store them into the set F1,F2F_1,F_2F1‚Äã,F2‚Äã respectively.

Similarly, FkF_kFk‚Äã is the set of frequent kkk-subgraphs. FSG then builds larger kkk-subgraphs by merging the subgraphs obtained in the previous iteration.

Pseudo code

  1. F1‚ÜêF_1\getsF1‚Äã‚Üê frequent 111-subgraphs with counts
  2. F2‚ÜêF_2\getsF2‚Äã‚Üê frequent 222-subgraphs with counts
  3. k‚Üê3k\gets3k‚Üê3
  4. while Fk‚àí1‚â†‚àÖF_{k-1}\neq\emptyFk‚àí1‚ÄãÓÄ†=‚àÖ do
    • candidate_generation: get CkC_kCk‚Äã, the set of candidate kkk-subgraphs from Fk‚àí1F_{k-1}Fk‚àí1‚Äã
    • candidate_pruning: for a candidate to be frequent, each (k‚àí1)(k-1)(k‚àí1)-subgraph should be frequent
    • frequency_pruning: scan D\mathcal DD, count occurrences of subgraphs in CkC_kCk‚Äã
    • Fk‚Üê{c‚ààCk‚à£œÉ(c)‚â•min‚Å°sup‚Å°}F_k\gets\{c\in C_k|\sigma(c)\ge\min\sup\}Fk‚Äã‚Üê{c‚ààCk‚Äã‚à£œÉ(c)‚â•minsup}
    • k‚Üêk+1k\gets k+1k‚Üêk+1
  5. return ‚à™i=1kFi\cup_{i=1}^kF_i‚à™i=1k‚ÄãFi‚Äã

each of 3 steps run isomorphism checks to understand whether some candidate is isomorphic to any of the other candidates. Moreover, in order to compute the support of a subgraph the algorithm runs subgraph isomorphism on all the candidate graphs in CkC_kCk‚Äã. FSG employs heuristics to reduce the number of isomorphism tests at each iteration.

Candidate Generation

Generate candidates by merging the frequent (k‚àí1)(k-1)(k‚àí1)-subgraphs. The main idea is to first detect cores to generate the candidates easily. A core is the maximum common subgraph among two subgraphs. Although generating the core requires to run subgraph isomorphism, in practice

  1. one core is common to many subgraphs.
  2. the subgraphs are typically small.

Candidate pruning

In order to prune the candidates we can check if every subgraph of a candidate is also frequent. In theory, this requires to perform isomorphism tests for each of the candidate‚Äôs subgraph.

In order to hash a graph, we require a signature, i.e., a numeric representation, that is unique for each graph. This is possible through canonical labeling. Canonical labeling, finds a unique representation of a graph in a smart manner. In particular, FSG empolys a canonical scheme that reorders the column and the rows of the adjacency matrix. The string obtained by reading the sequence of node and edge labels in the column of the matrix that is smallest lexicographic string among all of those obtained by reordering is the canonical code and is unique, i.e., code(G)=min‚Å°code(M)‚à£Mcode(G)=\min code(M)|Mcode(G)=mincode(M)‚à£M is adjacency matrix.

It seems that this method effectively solves graph isomorphism in O(1)\mathcal O(1)O(1). However, this is not the case as the canonical labeling is obtained by a, potentially exponential, number of reordering of the adjacency matrix. By reordering, we are computing automorphisms over the graph. In practice, not all the permutations lead to a valid matrix and can be pruned by simple heuristics.

Frequency Counting

Frequency counting requires to scan the data to find which graphs contain a subgraph. In frequency counting, most of the subgraph isomorphism tests can be avoided with a simple shortcut.

Let TID(G‚Ä≤),TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)TID(G'),TID(G'')TID(G‚Ä≤),TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤) be the set of graphs in the collection D\mathcal DD that contain the subgraph G‚Ä≤G'G‚Ä≤ and G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤G''G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤, respectively. If we merge the two patterns, it follows immediately that TID(merge(G‚Ä≤,G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤))‚äÜTID(G‚Ä≤)‚à©TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)TID(merge(G',G''))\subseteq TID(G')\cap TID(G'')TID(merge(G‚Ä≤,G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤))‚äÜTID(G‚Ä≤)‚à©TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤). As such all the graphs in (TID(G‚Ä≤)‚à™TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤))‚ï≤(TID(G‚Ä≤)‚à©TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤))(TID(G')\cup TID(G''))\diagdown(TID(G')\cap TID(G''))(TID(G‚Ä≤)‚à™TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤))‚ï≤(TID(G‚Ä≤)‚à©TID(G‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)) can be ignored as they will not contribute to the support.

üëç

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Easy to include heuristics to reduce the computation time.

üëé

  • FSG generates the same subgraph a large number of times.
  • The canonical labeling scheme is quadratic in the size of the subgraph.
  • FSG requires several isomorphism and subgraph isomorphism tests.

Pattern-growth Approaches

It follows a different philosophy.

Start first with empty subgraphs and progressively expand these subgraphs by adding one edge at the time. The pattern expands always in a certain order to redundancy as much as possible.

gSpan is the most famous algorithm in the pattern-growth family.

gSpan organizes the patterns in a prefix-tree, a data structure for alphabetically ordered string that store string prefixes as nodes of a tree. However, graphs do not have a predefined order of traversal, or a unique way of enumerating the nodes.

To create a prefix-tree of non-repeating patterns gSpan:

  1. Defines a traversal over the nodes in the graphs
  2. Identifies in advance which nodes of a subgraph to expand
  3. Defines a total ordering over the subgraphs, so as to detect duplicate patterns.

Node Traversal

gSpan traverses the subgraphs in a DFS manner, that means that the next node vjv_jvj‚Äã to visit after viv_ivi‚Äã is the first in the list of neighbors N(i)N(i)N(i). A DFS vist defines a spanning-tree over the nodes in the subgraph. The edges in the spanning tree are called forward edges; the remaining edges are called backward edges.

In the beginning of the DFS a counter assigns a unique identifier to each node. The counter represents the discovery time of the node.

Rightmost Expansion

Since a DFS defines a specific traversal and the order of the visit is market by a counter, there is only one way to add an edge to the subgraph, namely expanding from the rightmost path. The rightmost path is the path from the root of the spanning tree to the leaf with the highest identifier.

Total Ordering

The main innovation of gSpan is to treat canonical labeling as a DFS-visit and thus ensure a reduced number of operations and redundant subgraphs.

DFS Codes

Representation of a graph that is comparable among other DFS codes. Such a comparison as a total ordering for which a minimum exists. The minimum DFS-code is a canonical labeling of a graph.

Definition of DFS-edge. It‚Äôs a tuple (i,j,‚Ñì(i),‚Ñì((i,j)),‚Ñì(j))(i,j,\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j))(i,j,‚Ñì(i),‚Ñì((i,j)),‚Ñì(j)) where i,ji,ji,j are identifiers given by the DFS traversal order, ‚Ñì(i),‚Ñì((i,j)),‚Ñì(j)\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j)‚Ñì(i),‚Ñì((i,j)),‚Ñì(j) are the labels of node iii, edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) and node jjj.

DFS-code for a graph G=(V,E,‚Ñì)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,‚Ñì) is a sequence ‚ü®e1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,et‚ü©\langle e_1,\cdots,e_t\rangle‚ü®e1‚Äã,‚ãØ,et‚Äã‚ü© where each eie_iei‚Äã is a DFS-edge and t=‚à£E‚à£t=|E|t=‚à£E‚à£.

Valid DFS-codes. Precedence order ‚â∫\prec‚â∫ on DFS-edges corresponding to the DFS traversal. Given 2 DFS-edges e1e_1e1‚Äã connecting nodes with discovery time (i1,j1)(i_1,j_1)(i1‚Äã,j1‚Äã) and e2e_2e2‚Äã connecting nodes with discovery time (i2,j2)(i_2,j_2)(i2‚Äã,j2‚Äã). A DFS-code is valid if it complies to:

  1. i1=i2i_1=i_2i1‚Äã=i2‚Äã and j1<j2‚áíe1‚â∫e2j_1\lt j_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1‚Äã<j2‚Äã‚áíe1‚Äã‚â∫e2‚Äã backward edges ordering
  2. i1<j1i_1\lt j_1i1‚Äã<j1‚Äã and j1=i2‚áíe1‚â∫e2j_1=i_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1‚Äã=i2‚Äã‚áíe1‚Äã‚â∫e2‚Äã forward edges ordering
  3. e1‚â∫e2e_1\prec e_2e1‚Äã‚â∫e2‚Äã and e2‚â∫e3‚áíe1‚â∫e3e_2\prec e_3\Rarr e_1\prec e_3e2‚Äã‚â∫e3‚Äã‚áíe1‚Äã‚â∫e3‚Äã transitive property

Total ordering and minimum codes. A graph can have multiple valid DFS-codes depending on the DFS traversal order. gSpan further defines a total ordering over the DFS-codes so to define a minimum DFS-code for a graph.

The minimum DFS-code is unique and a canonical labeling of the graph. This implies that 2 graphs are isomorphic iff they have the same DFS-code.

Let Œ±,Œ≤\alpha,\betaŒ±,Œ≤ two DFS-codes. We say Œ±‚â∫Œ≤\alpha\prec\betaŒ±‚â∫Œ≤ iff either of the following conditions are true:

  • ‚àÉt,0‚â§t‚â§min‚Å°(n,m)\exist t,0\le t\le\min(n,m)‚àÉt,0‚â§t‚â§min(n,m) s.t. ak=bka_k=b_kak‚Äã=bk‚Äã for k<tk\lt tk<t and at‚â∫ebta_t\prec_e b_tat‚Äã‚â∫e‚Äãbt‚Äã
  • ak=bka_k=b_kak‚Äã=bk‚Äã for 0‚â§k‚â§m0\le k\le m0‚â§k‚â§m and n‚â•mn\ge mn‚â•m

Simply speaking, Œ±‚â∫Œ≤\alpha\prec\betaŒ±‚â∫Œ≤ if either 1. Œ±\alphaŒ± and Œ≤\betaŒ≤ are equal up to some point ttt and the next corresponding DFS-edges is s.t. at‚â∫ebta_t\prec_e b_tat‚Äã‚â∫e‚Äãbt‚Äã, or 2. Œ±\alphaŒ± and Œ≤\betaŒ≤ are the same in terms of DFS-edges but Œ≤\betaŒ≤ contains more edges.

We need to define ‚â∫e\prec_e‚â∫e‚Äã: Let at=(ia,ja,Lia,Lia,ja,Lja),bt=(ib,jb,Lib,Lib,jb,Ljb)a_t=(i_a,j_a,L_{i_a},L_{i_a,j_a},L_{j_a}),b_t=(i_b,j_b,L_{i_b},L_{i_b,j_b},L_{j_b})at‚Äã=(ia‚Äã,ja‚Äã,Lia‚Äã‚Äã,Lia‚Äã,ja‚Äã‚Äã,Lja‚Äã‚Äã),bt‚Äã=(ib‚Äã,jb‚Äã,Lib‚Äã‚Äã,Lib‚Äã,jb‚Äã‚Äã,Ljb‚Äã‚Äã) be two DFS-edges. We say at‚â∫ebta_t\prec_e b_tat‚Äã‚â∫e‚Äãbt‚Äã if

  1. Both are forward edges
    • ib<iai_b\lt i_aib‚Äã<ia‚Äã OR
    • ib=iai_b=i_aib‚Äã=ia‚Äã and the labels of aaa are lexicographical less than labels of bbb, in order of tuple.
  2. Both are backward edges
    • ja‚â§jbj_a\le j_bja‚Äã‚â§jb‚Äã OR
    • ja=jbj_a=j_bja‚Äã=jb‚Äã and the edge label of aaa is lexicographical less than the one of bbb.
  3. ata_tat‚Äã is backward and btb_tbt‚Äã is forward.

The above enforce a total order on DFS-codes and, as such, the min-DFS(GGG) of a graph GGG is a canonical labeling of GGG.

DFS-code tree. It allows also to organize data into DFS-tree that is prefix tree. Because the codes have a precedence order. If min-DFS(G1G_1G1‚Äã)={a0,a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n\}={a0‚Äã,a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã} and min-DFS(G2G_2G2‚Äã)={a0,a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an,b}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n,b\}={a0‚Äã,a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã,b}, then G1G_1G1‚Äã is parent of G2G_2G2‚Äã, since min-DFS(G1G_1G1‚Äã) is a prefix of min-DFS(G2G_2G2‚Äã).

Given a parent-child relationship defined, we can construct a DFS Tree. An interesting property of the DFS-tree is that an in-order traveersal follows DFS lexicographic order.

gSpan algorithm

Input: Collection of graphs D\mathcal DD, minimum support min‚Å°sup‚Å°\min\supminsup

Output: Frequent subgraph set SSS

  1. Let SSS be frequent one-edge subgraphs in D\mathcal DD using DFS code.
  2. Sort SSS in lexicographic order
  3. N‚ÜêSN\gets SN‚ÜêS
  4. for each n‚ààNn\in Nn‚ààN do
    • GSpanExtend(D,n,min‚Å°sup‚Å°,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)
  5. return SSS

GSpanExtend(D,n,min‚Å°sup‚Å°,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S) // checking minimality of DFS-code is computationally expensive

  1. if nnn not minimal then return

  2. else

    • S‚ÜêS‚à™nS\gets S\cup nS‚ÜêS‚à™n

    • for each Rightmost expansion eee of nnn do

      • if Œ¥(e)‚â•min‚Å°sup‚Å°\delta(e)\ge\min\supŒ¥(e)‚â•minsup then

        GSpanExtend(D,n,min‚Å°sup‚Å°,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)

üëç

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Generates less redundant subgraphs.

üëé

  • Works only in collections of graphs.
  • Generally slow for low min‚Å°sup‚Å°\min\supminsup.

Frequent Subgraph Mining on a Single Graph

If the support is defined a the number of time a specific subgraph appears, the downward property does not hold anymore as bigger subgraphs can have a larger support.

We defined a support measure to be admissible if for any graph PPP and any subgraph Q‚äëPQ\sqsubseteq PQ‚äëP, the support of PPP is not larger than the support of QQQ. In the last few years, a number of admissible support measures have appeared. These include,

  • Maximum independent set support (MIS): Based on maximum number of non-overlapping matches
  • Harmful overlap support (HO): Based on number of patterns for which no multi-node subgraph is identical
  • Minimum image-based support (MNI): Based on the number of times a node in the pattern is mapped into a distinct node in the graph.

MIS Support

The maximum independent set support œÉMIS\sigma_{MIS}œÉMIS‚Äã counts how many times a pattern maps to a subgraph that does not overlap to any other subgraphs. The computation of MIS is as follows

  1. Construct an overlap graph GO=(VO,EO)G_O=(V_O,E_O)GO‚Äã=(VO‚Äã,EO‚Äã), in which the set of nodes VOV_OVO‚Äã is the set of matches of a pattern PPP into a graph GGG and E_O=\{(f_1,f_2)|f_1,f_2\in V_O\or f_1\neq f_2\neq f_1\sqcap f_2\neq\empty\}, i.e., EOE_OEO‚Äã has an edge among each pair of overlapping matches.
  2. Compute the œÉMIS\sigma_{MIS}œÉMIS‚Äã as the size of the maximum independent set of nodes in the overlap graph.

Recall that the maximum finding the maximum independent set of NP-hard.

Harmful Overlap Support

The HO support is less restrictive than MIS support as it considers overlap only those matchings of a pattern that share one are more edges. Two matching subgraph are connected through a node are not considered overlapping.

NMI Support

The minimum image-based support is even less restrictive as it considers the minimum number of times a node of the pattern matches a node in the graph.

Definition of MNI. Let f1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1‚Äã,‚ãØ,fm‚Äã be the set of isomorphism of a pattern P:‚ü®VP,EP,‚ÑìP‚ü©P:\langle V_P,E_P,\ell_P\rangleP:‚ü®VP‚Äã,EP‚Äã,‚ÑìP‚Äã‚ü© in a graph GGG. Let F(v)=‚à£{f1(v),‚ãØ‚Äâ,fm(v)}‚à£F(v)=|\{f_1(v),\cdots,f_m(v)\}|F(v)=‚à£{f1‚Äã(v),‚ãØ,fm‚Äã(v)}‚à£ be the number of distinct mappings of a node v‚ààVPv\in V_Pv‚ààVP‚Äã to a node in GGG by functions f1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1‚Äã,‚ãØ,fm‚Äã. The MNI

œÉMNI(P)¬†ofP¬†in¬†G¬†is¬†œÉMNI(P)=min‚Å°{F(v),v‚ààVP}\sigma_{MNI}(P)\ of P\ in\ G\ is\ \sigma_{MNI}(P)=\min\{F(v),v\in V_P\}œÉMNI‚Äã(P)¬†ofP¬†in¬†G¬†is¬†œÉMNI‚Äã(P)=min{F(v),v‚ààVP‚Äã}

Since MNI considers one node at the time, given the matching of pattern in the graph, NMI support can be computed in polynomial time.

Approaches for Large Graphs

With an anti-monotone support measure, we can apply any previous support measure such as gSPAN, just changing how the support is computed and leaving the rest unchanged. Such approaches are called grow-and-store

  • Add all frequent edges to the list of frequent subgraphs
  • Extend frequent subgraphs to larger candidates
  • Compute candidate frequency (find all occurrences)
  • Repeat step 2 until no more frequent subgraphs is found

One of the methods that exploits and optimizes gSpan is GraMi
