entry.title: ÈöèÊú∫ÁÆóÊ≥ï 9 Prophets, Secretaries and Martingales
entry.content:
First part of lecture notes on prophet inequality and secretary problem is by Anupam Gupta (CMU)

Prophet inequalities and Secretary problems are 2 classes of problem where online decision-making meets stochasticity: in the first set of problems the inputs are random variables, whereas in the second one the inputs are worst-case but revealed to the algorithm (aka decision maker) in random order.

Here are some results, proofs and techniques about them.

The Prophet Inequality

Âú®‰πãÂâçÁöÑÁÆóÊ≥ïÂçöÂºàËÆ∫ËØæ‰∏äÂ≠¶ËøáÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂèØ‰ª•ÂèÇËÄÉÊàëÁöÑÂØπÂ∫î ËØæÂ†ÇÁ¨îËÆ∞

nnn random variables X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XnX_1,\cdots,X_nX1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã. We know their distributions up-front, but not their realizations. The realizations are revealed one-by-one.

We want to give a strategy that, upon seeing the value XiX_iXi‚Äã decides either to choose iii in which case we get reward XiX_iXi‚Äã and the process stops. Or we can pass, in which case we move on to the next random variables, and are not allowed to come back to iii every again. We want to maximize our expected reward. If X_\max=\max\{X_1,X_2,\cdots,X_n\}, it is clear that our reward can‚Äôt exceed \mathbb E[X_\max].

Theorem 1 by Krengel, Sucheston and Garling. There exists a strategy with expected reward \frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max].

Let œÑ\tauœÑ be the median of the distribution of X_\max, i.e., \Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]=1/2.

Now the strategy is simple: pick the first XiX_iXi‚Äã which exceeds œÑ\tauœÑ. Clearly, we will pick an item with probability exactly 121\over221‚Äã, then notice that

\mathbb E[X_\max]\le\tau+\mathbb E[(X_\max-\tau)^+]\\\le\tau+\mathbb E[\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-\tau)^+].

Then for algorithm:

ALG\ge\tau\cdot\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]+\sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb E[(X_i-\tau)^+]\cdot\Pr[\bigwedge_{j\le i}(X_j\lt\tau)]\\\ge\tau\cdot\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]+\sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb E[(X_i-\tau)^+]\cdot\Pr[X_\max\lt\tau]

By letting \Pr[X_\max\lt\tau]=\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]=1/2, we have

ALG\ge\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max]

The proof is beautiful, but hard to generalize. What if we can choose kkk variables?

There are LP-based version of proof, which can be generalized:

Define pip_ipi‚Äã as the probability that element XiX_iXi‚Äã takes on the highest value. Hence ‚àëipi=1\sum_ip_i=1‚àëi‚Äãpi‚Äã=1. Moreover, suppose œÑi\tau_iœÑi‚Äã is s.t. Pr‚Å°[Xi‚â•œÑi]=pi\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]=p_iPr[Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]=pi‚Äã, i.e., the pip_ipi‚Äã-th percentile for XiX_iXi‚Äã. Define

vi(pi)=E[Xi‚à£Xi‚â•œÑi]v_i(p_i)=\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]vi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)=E[Xi‚Äã‚à£Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]

as value of XiX_iXi‚Äã conditioned on it lying in the top pip_ipi‚Äã-th percentile. Clearly, \mathbb E[X_\max]\le\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i.

A simpler weaker bound. Here‚Äôs a simple algorithm that gets value \frac{1}{4}\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i\ge\frac{1}{4}\mathbb E[X_\max].

If we haven‚Äôt chosen an item among 1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,i‚àí11,\cdots,i-11,‚ãØ,i‚àí1, when looking at item iii, pass with probability half without even looking at XiX_iXi‚Äã, else accept it if Xi‚â•œÑiX_i\ge\tau_iXi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã.

Definition: we ‚Äúreach‚Äù item iii if we have not picked an item before iii. The expected value of the algorithm is

ALG‚â•‚àëi=1nPr‚Å°[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖ12‚ãÖPr‚Å°[Xi‚â•œÑi]‚ãÖE[Xi‚à£Xi‚â•œÑi]=‚àëi=1nPr‚Å°[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖ12‚ãÖpi‚ãÖvi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]\cdot\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]\\=\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALG‚â•i=1‚àën‚ÄãPr[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖ21‚Äã‚ãÖPr[Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]‚ãÖE[Xi‚Äã‚à£Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]=i=1‚àën‚ÄãPr[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖ21‚Äã‚ãÖpi‚Äã‚ãÖvi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)

Since we pick each item with probability 12pi\frac{1}{2}p_i21‚Äãpi‚Äã, the expected number of items we choose is half. So, by Markov‚Äôs inequality, the probability we pick no item at all is at least half. Hence, the probability we reach item iii is at least one half too, the above expression is 14‚ãÖ‚àëivi(pi)‚ãÖpi\frac{1}{4}\cdot\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i41‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àëi‚Äãvi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)‚ãÖpi‚Äã as claimed.

The bound of 2. To improve the algorithm, suppose we denote the probability of reaching item iii by rir_iri‚Äã and suppose we reject item iii outright with probability 1‚àíqi1-q_i1‚àíqi‚Äã. Then inequality shows that

ALG‚â•‚àëi=1nri‚ãÖqi‚ãÖpi‚ãÖvi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^nr_i\cdot q_i\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALG‚â•i=1‚àën‚Äãri‚Äã‚ãÖqi‚Äã‚ãÖpi‚Äã‚ãÖvi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)

Above, we ensured that qi=ri=12q_i=r_i=\frac{1}{2}qi‚Äã=ri‚Äã=21‚Äã, and hence lost a factor of 14\frac{1}{4}41‚Äã. But if we ensures that ri‚ãÖqi=1/2r_i\cdot q_i=1/2ri‚Äã‚ãÖqi‚Äã=1/2, we would get the desired result of \frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max]. For the first item r1=1r_1=1r1‚Äã=1 and hence we can set q1=12q_1=\frac{1}{2}q1‚Äã=21‚Äã.

For future items, since

ri+1=ri(1‚àíqi‚ãÖpi)r_{i+1}=r_i(1-q_i\cdot p_i)ri+1‚Äã=ri‚Äã(1‚àíqi‚Äã‚ãÖpi‚Äã)

we can just set qi+1=12ri+1q_{i+1}=\frac{1}{2r_{i+1}}qi+1‚Äã=2ri+1‚Äã1‚Äã. A simple induction shows that ri+1‚â•12r_{i+1}\ge\frac{1}{2}ri+1‚Äã‚â•21‚Äã. Summing up this equation to get ri+1=r1‚àí‚àëj‚â§ipi/2r_{i+1}=r_1-\sum_{j\le i}p_i/2ri+1‚Äã=r1‚Äã‚àí‚àëj‚â§i‚Äãpi‚Äã/2, so that qi+1‚àà[0,1]q_{i+1}\in[0,1]qi+1‚Äã‚àà[0,1] and is well-defined.

The Computational Aspect

If the distribution of the random variable stream XiX_iXi‚Äã is explicitly given, the proofs above immediately give us algorithms. But what if XiX_iXi‚Äã are given via a black-box (we can only access via samples)?

The first proof merely relies on finding the median: finding an approximate median œÑ^\hat\tauœÑ^ s.t. \Pr[X_\max\lt\hat\tau]\in(\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon,\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon) gives us expected reward \frac{1}{2+\epsilon/2}\mathbb E[X_\max]. To do this, sample from X_\max O(\epsilon^{-2}\log\delta^{-1}) times and take œÑ^\hat\tauœÑ^ is an approximate median with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1-\delta1‚àíŒ¥.

For the second proof, there are 2 ways of making it algorithmic. Firstly, if the quantities are polynomially bounded, estimate pip_ipi‚Äã and viv_ivi‚Äã by sampling. Alternatively, solve the convex program

max‚Å°{‚àëiyi‚ãÖvi(yi)‚à£‚àëiyi=1}\max\{\sum_iy_i\cdot v_i(y_i)|\sum_iy_i=1\}max{i‚àë‚Äãyi‚Äã‚ãÖvi‚Äã(yi‚Äã)‚à£i‚àë‚Äãyi‚Äã=1}

and use the yiy_iyi‚Äã‚Äôs from its solution in lieu of pip_ipi‚Äã‚Äôs in the algorithm above.

Since getting samples from the distributions may be expensive, there are method to get a constant fraction of \mathbb E[X_\max] via taking just one sample from each of the XiX_iXi‚Äãs.

Extensions: Picking Multiple Items

What if we are allowed to choose kkk variables from among the nnn?

If pip_ipi‚Äã is the probability that XiX_iXi‚Äã is among the top kkk values, we have

‚àëipi=k.\sum_ip_i=k.i‚àë‚Äãpi‚Äã=k.

The upper bound on our quantity of interest remains essentially unchanged

E[sum¬†of¬†top¬†k¬†r.v.s]‚â§‚àëivi(pi)‚ãÖpi\mathbb E[\text{sum of top }k\text{ r.v.s}]\le\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_iE[sum¬†of¬†top¬†k¬†r.v.s]‚â§i‚àë‚Äãvi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)‚ãÖpi‚Äã

What about an algorithm to get value 1/41/41/4 of the value in this inequality? Then same: reject each item outright with probability 1/21/21/2, else pick iii if Xi‚â•œÑiX_i\ge\tau_iXi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã. Proof goes through unchanged.

Better

One can get within (1‚àí1k+3)(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{k+3}})(1‚àík+3‚Äã1‚Äã) of the value. For k=1k=1k=1, this matches 1/21/21/2. One can, however, get a fractor of 1‚àíO(log‚Å°kk)1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}})1‚àíO(klogk‚Äã‚Äã) using a simple concentration bound.

Suppose we reduce the rejection probability to Œ¥\deltaŒ¥. Then the probability that we reach some item iii without having picked kkk items already is lower-bounded by the probability that we pick at most kkk elements in the entire process. Since we reject items with probability Œ¥\deltaŒ¥, the expected number of elements we pick is (1‚àíŒ¥)k(1-\delta)k(1‚àíŒ¥)k.

Hence, the probability that we pick less than kkk items is at least 1‚àíe‚àíŒò(Œ¥2k)1-e^{-\Theta(\delta^2k)}1‚àíe‚àíŒò(Œ¥2k), by a Hoeffding bound for sums of independent random variables. Now setting Œ¥=O(log‚Å°kk)\delta=O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}})Œ¥=O(klogk‚Äã‚Äã) ensures that the probability of reaching each item is at least (1‚àí1/k)(1-1/k)(1‚àí1/k), and a argument similar to that in Proof shows that

ALG‚â•‚àëi=1nPr‚Å°[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖPr‚Å°[not¬†reject¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖPr‚Å°[Xi‚â•œÑi]‚ãÖE[Xi‚à£Xi‚â•œÑi]=‚àëi=1n(1‚àí1/k)‚ãÖ(1‚àíO(log‚Å°kk))‚ãÖpi‚ãÖvi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\Pr[\text{not reject item }i]\cdot\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]\cdot\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]\\=\sum_{i=1}^n(1-1/k)\cdot(1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}}))\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALG‚â•i=1‚àën‚ÄãPr[reach¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖPr[not¬†reject¬†item¬†i]‚ãÖPr[Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]‚ãÖE[Xi‚Äã‚à£Xi‚Äã‚â•œÑi‚Äã]=i=1‚àën‚Äã(1‚àí1/k)‚ãÖ(1‚àíO(klogk‚Äã‚Äã))‚ãÖpi‚Äã‚ãÖvi‚Äã(pi‚Äã)

which gives the claimed bound of (1‚àíO(log‚Å°kk))(1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}}))(1‚àíO(klogk‚Äã‚Äã)).

Secretary Problems

nnn items, each has some intrinsic non-negative value.

Assume the values are distinct, but we know nothing about their ranges.

We only know nnn.

The item are presented one by one. Upon seeing an item, we can either pick it or we can pass. The goal is to maximize the probability of picking the item with the highest value.

If an adversary chooses the order in which the items are presented, every deterministic strategy must fail.

‚ùìSecretary problem: what if the items are presented in uniformly random order? For this setting, it seems surprising that one can prove the following theorem:

Theorem 2.1. There is a strategy to pick the best item with probability at least 1e\frac{1}{e}e1‚Äã.

A simple algorithm and proof showing probability of 14\frac{1}{4}41‚Äã: ignore the first n/2n/2n/2 items, and then pick the next item that is better than all the ones seen so far. Note that this algorithm succeeds if the best item is in the second half of the items (happens with probability 1/21/21/2). Hence 1/41/41/4. Rejecting the first half of the items is not optimal, and there are other cases where the algorithm succeeds that this simple analysis does not account for.

First, the algorithm should never pick an element that is not the best so far. Moreover, if we define

f(i)=Pr‚Å°[ith¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best‚à£ith¬†is¬†best¬†so¬†far]=Pr‚Å°[ith¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best]Pr‚Å°[ith¬†is¬†best¬†so¬†far]=1/n1/i=ing(i)=Pr‚Å°[picking¬†global¬†best¬†using¬†optimal¬†strategy¬†from¬†item¬†i¬†onwards]f(i)=\Pr[i^{th}\text{ item is global best}|i^{th}\text{ is best so far}]\\=\frac{\Pr[i^{th}\text{ item is global best}]}{\Pr[i^{th}\text{ is best so far}]}=\frac{1/n}{1/i}=\frac{i}{n}\\g(i)=\Pr[\text{picking global best using optimal strategy from item i onwards}]f(i)=Pr[ith¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best‚à£ith¬†is¬†best¬†so¬†far]=Pr[ith¬†is¬†best¬†so¬†far]Pr[ith¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best]‚Äã=1/i1/n‚Äã=ni‚Äãg(i)=Pr[picking¬†global¬†best¬†using¬†optimal¬†strategy¬†from¬†item¬†i¬†onwards]

then g(i)g(i)g(i) is a non-increasing and f(i)f(i)f(i) is increasing.

Any optimal strategy should pass at times iii where f(i)<g(i+1)f(i)\lt g(i+1)f(i)<g(i+1) and pick at other times if we see an element that is best so far. i.e., a strategy of the type used in the simple proof of 1/41/41/4 is optimal.

So if we reject the first œÑ\tauœÑ items, then the probability we succeed in picking the global best is

‚àët=œÑ+1nPr‚Å°[tth¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best]‚ãÖPr‚Å°[best¬†of¬†first¬†t‚àí1¬†items¬†in¬†first¬†œÑ¬†positions]=‚àët=œÑ+1n1n‚ãÖœÑt‚àí1=œÑn(Hn‚àí1‚àíHœÑ‚àí1).\sum_{t=\tau+1}^n\Pr[t^{th}\text{ item is global best}]\cdot\Pr[\text{best of first }t-1\text{ items in first }\tau\text{ positions}]\\=\sum_{t=\tau+1}^n\frac{1}{n}\cdot\frac{\tau}{t-1}=\frac{\tau}{n}(H_{n-1}-H_{\tau-1}).t=œÑ+1‚àën‚ÄãPr[tth¬†item¬†is¬†global¬†best]‚ãÖPr[best¬†of¬†first¬†t‚àí1¬†items¬†in¬†first¬†œÑ¬†positions]=t=œÑ+1‚àën‚Äãn1‚Äã‚ãÖt‚àí1œÑ‚Äã=nœÑ‚Äã(Hn‚àí1‚Äã‚àíHœÑ‚àí1‚Äã).

This is g(œÑ+1)g(\tau+1)g(œÑ+1). So the first position where f(œÑ)=œÑ/n‚â•g(œÑ+1)f(\tau)=\tau/n\ge g(\tau+1)f(œÑ)=œÑ/n‚â•g(œÑ+1) is given by the smallest œÑ\tauœÑ s.t. 1‚â•Hn‚àí1‚àíHœÑ‚àí11\ge H_{n-1}-H_{\tau-1}1‚â•Hn‚àí1‚Äã‚àíHœÑ‚àí1‚Äã, i.e., œÑ‚âàn/e\tau\approx n/eœÑ‚âàn/e for large nnn, hence g(œÑ+1)‚âà1/eg(\tau+1)\approx1/eg(œÑ+1)‚âà1/e.

There is an alternate proof that uses a convex-programming. We will write down an LP that captures some properties of any feasible solution, optimize this LP and show a strategy whose success probability is comparable to the objective of this LP.

Fix an optimal strategy. Assume w.l.o.gÔºà‰∏çÂ§±‰∏ÄËà¨ÊÄßÔºâ that it does not pick any item that is not the best so far.

Let pip_ipi‚Äã be the probability that this strategy picks an item at position iii. Let qiq_iqi‚Äã be the probability that we pick an item at position iii, conditioned on it being the best so far. So qi=pi1/i=i‚ãÖpiq_i=\frac{p_i}{1/i}=i\cdot p_iqi‚Äã=1/ipi‚Äã‚Äã=i‚ãÖpi‚Äã.

Now the probability of picking the best item is

‚àëiPr‚Å°[ith¬†position¬†is¬†global¬†best¬†and¬†we¬†pick¬†it]=‚àëiPr‚Å°[ith¬†position¬†is¬†global¬†best]‚ãÖqi=‚àëi1nqi=‚àëiinpi\sum_i\Pr[i^{th}\text{ position is global best and we pick it}]\\=\sum_i\Pr[i^{th}\text{ position is global best}]\cdot q_i\\=\sum_i\frac{1}{n}q_i=\sum_{i}\frac{i}{n}p_ii‚àë‚ÄãPr[ith¬†position¬†is¬†global¬†best¬†and¬†we¬†pick¬†it]=i‚àë‚ÄãPr[ith¬†position¬†is¬†global¬†best]‚ãÖqi‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãn1‚Äãqi‚Äã=i‚àë‚Äãni‚Äãpi‚Äã

Constraints: pi‚àà[0,1]p_i\in[0,1]pi‚Äã‚àà[0,1]. But also

pi=Pr‚Å°[pick¬†item¬†i‚à£i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚ãÖPr‚Å°[i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚â§Pr‚Å°[didn‚Äôt¬†pick¬†1,...,i-1‚à£i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚ãÖ(1/i)p_i=\Pr[\text{pick item }i|i\text{ best so far}]\cdot\Pr[i\text{ best so far}]\\\le\Pr[\text{didn't pick 1,...,i-1}|i\text{ best so far}]\cdot(1/i)pi‚Äã=Pr[pick¬†item¬†i‚à£i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚ãÖPr[i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚â§Pr[didn‚Äôt¬†pick¬†1,...,i-1‚à£i¬†best¬†so¬†far]‚ãÖ(1/i)

But not picking the first i‚àí1i-1i‚àí1 items is independent of iii being the best so far, so we get

pi‚â§1i(1‚àí‚àëj<ipj).p_i\le\frac{1}{i}(1-\sum_{j\lt i}p_j).pi‚Äã‚â§i1‚Äã(1‚àíj<i‚àë‚Äãpj‚Äã).

Hence the success probability of any strategy is upper-bounded by the following LP in variables pip_ipi‚Äã:

max‚Å°‚àëiin‚ãÖpii‚ãÖpi‚â§1‚àí‚àëj<ipjpi‚àà[0,1]\max\sum_i\frac{i}{n}\cdot p_i\\i\cdot p_i\le1-\sum_{j\lt i}p_j\\p_i\in[0,1]maxi‚àë‚Äãni‚Äã‚ãÖpi‚Äãi‚ãÖpi‚Äã‚â§1‚àíj<i‚àë‚Äãpj‚Äãpi‚Äã‚àà[0,1]

Now it can be checked that the solution pi=0p_i=0pi‚Äã=0 for i‚â§œÑi\le\taui‚â§œÑ and piœÑn(1i‚àí1‚àí1i)p_i\frac{\tau}{n}(\frac{1}{i-1}-\frac{1}{i})pi‚ÄãnœÑ‚Äã(i‚àí11‚Äã‚àíi1‚Äã) for œÑ‚â§i‚â§n\tau\le i\le nœÑ‚â§i‚â§n is a feasible solution, where œÑ\tauœÑ is defined by the smallest value s.t. Hn‚àí1‚àíHœÑ‚àí1‚â§1H_{n-1}-H_{\tau-1}\le1Hn‚àí1‚Äã‚àíHœÑ‚àí1‚Äã‚â§1.

Finally we can get a stopping strategy whose success probability matches that of the LP. Indeed solve the LP.

For ithi^{th}ith position if we‚Äôve not picked an item already and if this item is the best so far, pick it with probability ipi1‚àí‚àëj<ipj\frac{ip_i}{1-\sum_{j\lt i}p_j}1‚àí‚àëj<i‚Äãpj‚Äãipi‚Äã‚Äã. By the LP constraint, this probability ‚àà[0,1]\in[0,1]‚àà[0,1]. More over, removing the conditioning shows we pick an item at location iii with probability pip_ipi‚Äã, and a calculation similar to the one above shows that the algorithm‚Äôs success probability is ‚àëiipi/n\sum_iip_i/n‚àëi‚Äãipi‚Äã/n, the same as the LP.

Extension: Game-Theoretic Issues

In the optimal strategy, we don‚Äôt pick any items in the first n/en/en/e timesteps, and then we pick items with quite varying probabilities.

Suppose we insist that for each position iii, the probability of picking the item at position iii is the same.

Let‚Äôs fix any such strategy, and write an LP capturing the success probbailities of this strategy with uniformity condition as a constraint. Suppose p‚â§1/np\le1/np‚â§1/n is this uniform probability. Again, let qiq_iqi‚Äã be the probability of picking an item at position iii, conditioned on it being the best so far. Note that we may pick items even if they are not the best so far, just to satisfy the uniformity condition; hence instead of qi=i‚ãÖpq_i=i\cdot pqi‚Äã=i‚ãÖp, we have qi‚â§ipq_i\le ipqi‚Äã‚â§ip.

By same argument constraint in LP, we know that qi‚â§1‚àí(i‚àí1)pq_i\le1-(i-1)pqi‚Äã‚â§1‚àí(i‚àí1)p.

And the strategy‚Äôs success probability is again ‚àëqi/n\sum q_i/n‚àëqi‚Äã/n. So we can now solve the LP

max‚Å°‚àëi1n‚ãÖqiqi‚â§1‚àí(i‚àí1)‚ãÖpqi‚â§i‚ãÖpqi‚àà[0,1],p‚â•0\max\sum_i\frac{1}{n}\cdot q_i\\q_i\le1-(i-1)\cdot p\\q_i\le i\cdot p\\q_i\in[0,1],p\ge0maxi‚àë‚Äãn1‚Äã‚ãÖqi‚Äãqi‚Äã‚â§1‚àí(i‚àí1)‚ãÖpqi‚Äã‚â§i‚ãÖpqi‚Äã‚àà[0,1],p‚â•0

Buchbinder et al. shows the optimal value of this LP is at least 1‚àí1/2‚âà0.291-1/\sqrt 2\approx 0.291‚àí1/2‚Äã‚âà0.29.

Extension: Multiple Items

Suppose we want kkk items, maximizing the expected sum of these kkk values.

Suppose the set of kkk largest values is S‚àó‚äÜ[n]S^*\subseteq[n]S‚àó‚äÜ[n], and their total value is V‚àó=‚àëi‚ààSviV^*=\sum_{i\in S}v_iV‚àó=‚àëi‚ààS‚Äãvi‚Äã. It is easy to get an algorithm with expected value Œ©(V‚àó)\Omega(V^*)Œ©(V‚àó).

E.g., split the nnn items into kkk groups of n/kn/kn/k items, and run the single-item algorithm separately on each of these. Or ignore the first half of the elements, look at the value v^\hat vv^ of the (1‚àíœµ)k/2th(1-\epsilon)k/2^{th}(1‚àíœµ)k/2th highest value item in this set, and pick all items in the second half with values grater than v^\hat vv^. And indeed, ignoring half the items must lose a constant factor in expectation.

But here‚Äôs an algorithm that gives value V‚àó(1‚àíŒ¥)V^*(1-\delta)V‚àó(1‚àíŒ¥) where Œ¥‚Üí0\delta\rarr 0Œ¥‚Üí0 as k‚Üí‚àûk\rarr\inftyk‚Üí‚àû. We set Œ¥=O(k‚àí1/3log‚Å°k)\delta=O(k^{-1/3}\log k)Œ¥=O(k‚àí1/3logk) and œµ=Œ¥/2\epsilon=\delta/2œµ=Œ¥/2. Ignore the first Œ¥n\delta nŒ¥n items.

Now look at the value v^\hat vv^ of the (1‚àíœµ)Œ¥kth(1-\epsilon)\delta k^{th}(1‚àíœµ)Œ¥kth-highest valued item in this ignored set, and pick the first kkk elements with values grater than v^\hat vv^ among the remaining (1‚àíŒ¥)n(1-\delta)n(1‚àíŒ¥)n elements.

Second part of lecture notes on martingales is by Elias Koutsoupias (Oxford)

Martingales

‰∏≠ÊñáÁøªËØëÔºö‚ÄùÈûÖ‚ÄúÔºå‰πãÂâç‰ªéÊù•Ê≤°Âê¨ËØ¥Ëøá„ÄÇ

Chernoff bounds cannot be used for sums of dependent variables.

If the dependency of particular type, the Azuma-Hoeffding inequality provides a general concentration bound.

Definition of martingale: A martingale is a sequence of random variables X0,X1,‚ãØX_0,X_1,\cdotsX0‚Äã,X1‚Äã,‚ãØ of bounded expectation s.t. for every i‚â•0i\ge0i‚â•0,

E[Xi+1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]=Xi.\mathbb E[X_{i+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_i]=X_i.E[Xi+1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]=Xi‚Äã.

More generally, a sequence of random variables Z0,Z1,‚ãØZ_0,Z_1,\cdotsZ0‚Äã,Z1‚Äã,‚ãØ is a martingale w.r.t. the sequence X0,X1,‚ãØX_0,X_1,\cdotsX0‚Äã,X1‚Äã,‚ãØ if for all n>0n\gt0n>0 the following conditions hold:

  • ZnZ_nZn‚Äã is a function of X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã
  • E[‚à£Zn‚à£]‚â§‚àû\mathbb E[|Z_n|]\le\inftyE[‚à£Zn‚Äã‚à£]‚â§‚àû
  • E[Zn+1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn]=Zn\mathbb E[Z_{n+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_n]=Z_nE[Zn+1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã]=Zn‚Äã

Here are some example of martingales.

Gambler‚Äôs Fortune

A gambler plays a sequence of fair games. Let XiX_iXi‚Äã be the amount that the gambler‚Äôs total winnings immediately after the iii-th game. Since the games are fair, E[Xi]=0\mathbb E[X_i]=0E[Xi‚Äã]=0 and E[Zi+1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]=Zi+E[Xi+1]=Zi\mathbb E[Z_{i+1}|X_0,\cdots, X_i]=Z_i+\mathbb E[X_{i+1}]=Z_iE[Zi+1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]=Zi‚Äã+E[Xi+1‚Äã]=Zi‚Äã, which shows that very finite sequence Z0,Z1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,ZnZ_0,Z_1,\cdots,Z_nZ0‚Äã,Z1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Zn‚Äã is a martingale. This is a generalization of the simple random walk on a line. The gambler can use the past outcomes and any algorithm to calculate the amount of the next bet.

Balls and Bins

Suppose that we throw mmm balls into nnn bins independently and uniformly at random.

Consider the expected number of empty bins. Let XiX_iXi‚Äã be the random variable representing the bin into which the iii-th ball falls. Let YYY be a random variable representing the number of empty bins. Then the sequence of random variables

Zi=E[Y‚à£X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]Z_i=\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i]Zi‚Äã=E[Y‚à£X1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]

is a martingale. Clearly ZiZ_iZi‚Äã is a function of the X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XiX_1,\cdots,X_iX1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã‚Äôs and has bounded expectation. Furthermore

E[Zi+1‚à£X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]=E[E[Y‚à£X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi,Xi+1]‚à£X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]=E[Y‚à£X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi]=Zi\mathbb E[Z_{i+1}|X_1,\cdots,X_i]=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i,X_{i+1}]|X_1,\cdots,X_i]\\=\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i]=Z_iE[Zi+1‚Äã‚à£X1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]=E[E[Y‚à£X1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã,Xi+1‚Äã]‚à£X1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]=E[Y‚à£X1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã]=Zi‚Äã

We can view ZiZ_iZi‚Äã as an estimate of YYY after having observed the outcomes X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XiX_1,\cdots,X_iX1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚Äã. At the beginning Z0Z_0Z0‚Äã is a crude estimate, simply the expectation of YYY. As we add more balls to the bins. ZiZ_iZi‚Äã‚Äôs give improved estimates of YYY, and at the end we get the exact value Zm=YZ_m=YZm‚Äã=Y.

Doob Martingales

The balls and bins is a typical doob martingale. Doob martingales are processes in which we obtain a sequence of improved estimates of the value of a random variable as information about it is revealed progressively. More precisely, suppose YYY is a r.v. that is a function of random variables X0,X1,‚ãØX_0,X_1,\cdotsX0‚Äã,X1‚Äã,‚ãØ. As we observe the sequence of random variables X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã, we improve our estimates of YYY. The sequence of the mean estimates

Zt=E[Y‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xt]Z_t=\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t]Zt‚Äã=E[Y‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xt‚Äã]

form a martingale w.r.t. the sequence X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã (provided that ZtZ_tZt‚Äã‚Äôs bounded). Indeed, when we argued that the balls and bins process is a martingale, we used no property of the experiment, therefore the following holds in general

E[Zt+1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xt]=E[E[Y‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xt,Xt+1]‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xt]=E[Y‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xt]=Zt\mathbb E[Z_{t+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_t]\\=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t,X_{t+1}]|X_0,\cdots,X_t]\\=\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t]=Z_tE[Zt+1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xt‚Äã]=E[E[Y‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xt‚Äã,Xt+1‚Äã]‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xt‚Äã]=E[Y‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xt‚Äã]=Zt‚Äã

Azuma-Hoeffding Inequality

Let X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚Äã be a martingale s.t. ‚à£Xi‚àíXi‚àí1‚à£‚â§ci|X_i-X_{i-1}|\le c_i‚à£Xi‚Äã‚àíXi‚àí1‚Äã‚à£‚â§ci‚Äã.

Then for any Œª>0\lambda\gt0Œª>0,

P(Xn‚àíX0‚â•Œª)‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíŒª22‚àëi=1nci2),\mathbb P(X_n-X_0\ge\lambda)\le\exp(-\frac{\lambda^2}{2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2}),P(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã‚â•Œª)‚â§exp(‚àí2‚àëi=1n‚Äãci2‚ÄãŒª2‚Äã),

and

P(Xn‚àíX0‚â§‚àíŒª)‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíŒª22‚àëi=1nci2).\mathbb P(X_n-X_0\le-\lambda)\le\exp(-\frac{\lambda^2}{2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2}).P(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã‚â§‚àíŒª)‚â§exp(‚àí2‚àëi=1n‚Äãci2‚ÄãŒª2‚Äã).

Proof of the first inequality, (similar proof for second inequality):

By applying Markov‚Äôs inequality to an appropriate random variable and it is similar to the proof of Chernoff‚Äôs bounds.

We use the variables Yi=Xi‚àíXi‚àí1Y_i=X_i-X_{i-1}Yi‚Äã=Xi‚Äã‚àíXi‚àí1‚Äã. The step of the proof:

  1. We use Chernoff bounds and instead of bounding P(Xn‚àíX0‚â•Œª)\mathbb P(X_n-X_0\ge\lambda)P(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã‚â•Œª), we bound P(exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))‚â•exp‚Å°(tŒª))\mathbb P(\exp(t(X_n-X_0))\ge\exp(t\lambda))P(exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))‚â•exp(tŒª)):

P(exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))‚â•exp‚Å°(tŒª))‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àítŒª)E[exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))].\mathbb P(\exp(t(X_n-X_0))\ge\exp(t\lambda))\le\exp(-t\lambda)\mathbb E[\exp(t(X_n-X_0))].P(exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))‚â•exp(tŒª))‚â§exp(‚àítŒª)E[exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))].

Then focus on E[exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))]\mathbb E[\exp(t(X_n-X_0))]E[exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))], which can be replaced by YiY_iYi‚Äã‚Äôs

E[exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))]=E[‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°(tYi)],\mathbb E[\exp(t(X_n-X_0))]=\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)],E[exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))]=E[i=1‚àèn‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)],

by telescoping, Xn‚àíX0‚àëi=1n(Xi‚àíXi‚àí1)=‚àëi=1nYiX_n-X_0\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-X_{i-1})=\sum_{i=1}^nY_iXn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚Äã(Xi‚Äã‚àíXi‚àí1‚Äã)=‚àëi=1n‚ÄãYi‚Äã.

  1. We can‚Äôt use E[Y1Y2]=E[Y1]E[Y2]\mathbb E[Y_1Y_2]=\mathbb E[Y_1]\mathbb E[Y_2]E[Y1‚ÄãY2‚Äã]=E[Y1‚Äã]E[Y2‚Äã] since YiY_iYi‚Äãs are not independent. Consider the conditional expectation.

E[‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°(tYi)‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1]=(‚àèi=1n‚àí1exp‚Å°(tYi))E[exp‚Å°(tYn)‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1]\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]\\=(\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i))\mathbb E[\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]E[i=1‚àèn‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã]=(i=1‚àèn‚àí1‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã))E[exp(tYn‚Äã)‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã]

because for fixed X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã, all but the last factor in the product are constant and can be moved out.

Then find an upper bound on E[exp‚Å°(tYn)‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1]\mathbb E[\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]E[exp(tYn‚Äã)‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã].

  • Observe that E[Yi‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]=0\mathbb E[Y_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]=0E[Yi‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]=0 by martingale property.

    E[Yi‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]=E[Xi‚àíXi‚àí1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]=E[Xi‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]‚àíE[Xi‚àí1‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]=Xi‚àí1‚àíXi‚àí1=0\mathbb E[Y_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\mathbb E[X_i-X_{i-1}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\mathbb E[X_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]-\mathbb E[X_{i-1}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=X_{i-1}-X_{i-1}=0E[Yi‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]=E[Xi‚Äã‚àíXi‚àí1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]=E[Xi‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]‚àíE[Xi‚àí1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]=Xi‚àí1‚Äã‚àíXi‚àí1‚Äã=0

  • Then by the condition ‚à£Yi‚à£‚â§ci|Y_i|\le c_i‚à£Yi‚Äã‚à£‚â§ci‚Äã,

    exp‚Å°(tYi)‚â§Œ≤i+Œ≥iYi\exp(tY_i)\le\beta_i+\gamma_iY_iexp(tYi‚Äã)‚â§Œ≤i‚Äã+Œ≥i‚ÄãYi‚Äã

    for Œ≤i=(etci+e‚àítci)/2‚â§exp‚Å°((tci)2/2)\beta_i=(e^{tc_i}+e^{-tc_i})/2\le\exp((tc_i)^2/2)Œ≤i‚Äã=(etci‚Äã+e‚àítci‚Äã)/2‚â§exp((tci‚Äã)2/2), Œ≥i=(etci+e‚àítci)/(2ci)\gamma_i=(e^{tc_i}+e^{-tc_i})/(2c_i)Œ≥i‚Äã=(etci‚Äã+e‚àítci‚Äã)/(2ci‚Äã). Then rewrite YiY_iYi‚Äã as Yi=rci+(1‚àír)(‚àíci)Y_i=rc_i+(1-r)(-c_i)Yi‚Äã=rci‚Äã+(1‚àír)(‚àíci‚Äã), where r=1+Yi/ci2‚àà[0,1]r=\frac{1+Y_i/c_i}{2}\in[0,1]r=21+Yi‚Äã/ci‚Äã‚Äã‚àà[0,1], then use the convexity of etxe^{tx}etx to get

    etYi‚â§retci+(1‚àír)e‚àítci=Œ≤i+Œ≥iYi.e^{tY_i}\le re^{tc_i}+(1-r)e^{-tc_i}\\=\beta_i+\gamma_iY_i.etYi‚Äã‚â§retci‚Äã+(1‚àír)e‚àítci‚Äã=Œ≤i‚Äã+Œ≥i‚ÄãYi‚Äã.

  • Combine the above to get

    E[etYi‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]‚â§E[Œ≤i+Œ≥iYi‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xi‚àí1]=Œ≤i‚â§exp‚Å°((tci)2/2).\mathbb E[e^{tY_i}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\le\mathbb E[\beta_i+\gamma_iY_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\beta_i\le\exp((tc_i)^2/2).E[etYi‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]‚â§E[Œ≤i‚Äã+Œ≥i‚ÄãYi‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xi‚àí1‚Äã]=Œ≤i‚Äã‚â§exp((tci‚Äã)2/2).

It follows that

E[‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°(tYi)]=E[‚àèi=1n‚àí1exp‚Å°(tYi)√óexp‚Å°(tYn)‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1]‚â§E[‚àèi=1n‚àí1exp‚Å°(tYi)]exp‚Å°((tcn)2/2).\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]=\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)\times\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]\\\le\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)]\exp((tc_n)^2/2).E[i=1‚àèn‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)]=E[i=1‚àèn‚àí1‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)√óexp(tYn‚Äã)‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã]‚â§E[i=1‚àèn‚àí1‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)]exp((tcn‚Äã)2/2).

  1. Then take expectations on both sides to get rid of the conditional expectation:

E[‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°(tYi)]=E[E[‚àèi=1n‚àí1exp‚Å°(tYi)‚à£X0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Xn‚àí1]]‚â§E[‚àèi=1n‚àí1exp‚Å°(tYi)]exp‚Å°((tcn)2/2).\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]]\\\le\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)]\exp((tc_n)^2/2).E[i=1‚àèn‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)]=E[E[i=1‚àèn‚àí1‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)‚à£X0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1‚Äã]]‚â§E[i=1‚àèn‚àí1‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)]exp((tcn‚Äã)2/2).

  1. Then use same standard techniques
  • By induction: E[‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°(tYi)]‚â§‚àèi=1nexp‚Å°((tci2)/2)=exp‚Å°(t2‚àëi=1nci2/2)\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]\le\prod_{i=1}^n\exp((tc_i^2)/2)=\exp(t^2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2/2)E[‚àèi=1n‚Äãexp(tYi‚Äã)]‚â§‚àèi=1n‚Äãexp((tci2‚Äã)/2)=exp(t2‚àëi=1n‚Äãci2‚Äã/2)
  • Therefore P(exp‚Å°(t(Xn‚àíX0))‚â•exp‚Å°(Œªt))‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíŒªt)exp‚Å°(t2‚àëi=1nci2/2)\mathbb P(\exp(t(X_n-X_0))\ge\exp(\lambda t))\le\exp(-\lambda t)\exp(t^2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2/2)P(exp(t(Xn‚Äã‚àíX0‚Äã))‚â•exp(Œªt))‚â§exp(‚àíŒªt)exp(t2‚àëi=1n‚Äãci2‚Äã/2)
  • Set t=Œª/‚àëi=1nci2t=\lambda/\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2t=Œª/‚àëi=1n‚Äãci2‚Äã to minimize the above expression and get the bound of the theorem.

Apply AH Bounds on Gambler‚Äôs Fortune

A gambler plays a sequence of fair games. We have seen that if ZiZ_iZi‚Äã denotes the gambler‚Äôs total winnings immediately after the iii-th game, the sequence Z0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,ZnZ_0,\cdots,Z_nZ0‚Äã,‚ãØ,Zn‚Äã is a martingale. Suppose that the gambler has a very sophisticated algorithm to decide the amount that he bets every day that takes into account past bets and outcomes. Since the games are fair, the expected gain ZnZ_nZn‚Äã is zero.

Winning is not concentrated around the mean value in general.

For example, the case that gambler puts higher and higher bets. Suppose now that there is a bound on the size of bets, By AH inequality, the final winnings are concentrated with high probability in [‚àík,k][-k,k][‚àík,k] where k=O(nlog‚Å°n)k=O(\sqrt{n\log n})k=O(nlogn‚Äã).
entry.summary:
First part of lecture notes on prophet inequality and secretary problem is by Anupam Gupta (CMU)

Prophet inequalities and Secretar

entry.title: Êï∞ÊçÆÊåñÊéò 10 Graph Neural Networks
entry.content:
GNN - graph neural networks

Intuition: how to propagate information over the neighbors in a non-linear manner.

Graph Embeddings as Matrix Factorization

Linear embeddings correspond to SVD of the similarity matrices chosen in the objective.

For adjacency-based similarity, the best linear ddd-dimensional embedding corresponds to the projection of the dataset into the ddd directions associated to the top-ddd singular values:

if¬†SVD(A)=UŒ£V‚ä§then¬†the¬†embedding¬†matrix¬†Z=UdŒ£d\text{if }SVD(\mathbf A)=\mathbf U\Sigma\mathbf V^\top\\\text{then the embedding matrix }\mathbf Z=\mathbf U_d\Sigma_dif¬†SVD(A)=UŒ£V‚ä§then¬†the¬†embedding¬†matrix¬†Z=Ud‚ÄãŒ£d‚Äã

Question: Does there exist a matrix that, once factorized, would be approximately equivalent to run gradient descent over the non-linear objective?

NetMF

DeepWalk, one of the most popular random-walk embedding methods.

A random-walk approach samples random walks using a certain strategy RRR.

A random-walk embedding method optimizes the likelihood that a node jjj is reachable from a random-walk starting from node iii.

DeepWalk‚Äôs strategy is to generate random-walks of length LLL and then generate pairs of co-occuring nodes in a window of size TTT. The co-occurences are stored in a multiset D\mathcal DD.

Pseudo-code:

  • for each n=1,2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Nn=1,2,\cdots,Nn=1,2,‚ãØ,N do
    • pick w1nw_1^nw1n‚Äã according to probability distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1‚Äã)
    • generate vertex sequence (w1n,‚ãØ‚Äâ,wLn)(w_1^n,\cdots,w_L^n)(w1n‚Äã,‚ãØ,wLn‚Äã) of length LLL by random walk on network GGG
    • for each j=1,2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,L‚àíTj=1,2,\cdots,L-Tj=1,2,‚ãØ,L‚àíT do
      • for each r=1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Tr=1,\cdots,Tr=1,‚ãØ,T do
        • add vertex-context pair (wjn,wj+rn)(w_j^n,w_{j+r}^n)(wjn‚Äã,wj+rn‚Äã) to multi-set D\mathcal DD
        • add vertex-context pair (wj+rn,wjn)(w_{j+r}^n,w_{j}^n)(wj+rn‚Äã,wjn‚Äã) to multi-set D\mathcal DD

The first vertex of the random-walk w1nw_1^nw1n‚Äã is sampled from a prior distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1‚Äã) that in undirected, connected bipartite graphs correspond to p(i)=di/2‚à£E‚à£p(i)=d_i/2|E|p(i)=di‚Äã/2‚à£E‚à£.

This process and the relative transformation through softmax corresponds to a similarity matrix. We can represent the similarity among two nodes i,ji,ji,j as

\log\left(\frac{\text{(# of RW between i and j)}\cdot\text{(# of node/context pairs)}}{k\text{(# of occurrences of i)}\cdot\text{(# of occurrences of j)}}\right)\\=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)

where kkk is the number of negative samples.

Understand this formula:

  • First partition the set of multi-set D\mathcal DD of pairs of nodes co-occurring in walks into two set Dr‚Üí\mathcal D_{r\rarr}Dr‚Üí‚Äã and Dr‚Üê\mathcal D_{r\larr}Dr‚Üê‚Äã

    Dr‚Üí={(w,c):(w,c)‚ààD,w=wjn,c=wj+rn}Dr‚Üê={(w,c):(w,c)‚ààD,c=wj+rn,w=wjn}\mathcal D_{r\rarr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,w=w_j^n,c=w_{j+r}^n\}\\\mathcal D_{r\larr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,c=w_{j+r}^n,w=w_j^n\}Dr‚Üí‚Äã={(w,c):(w,c)‚ààD,w=wjn‚Äã,c=wj+rn‚Äã}Dr‚Üê‚Äã={(w,c):(w,c)‚ààD,c=wj+rn‚Äã,w=wjn‚Äã}

  • Then observe that

    log‚Å°(#(i,j)‚à£D‚à£k#(i)#(j))=log‚Å°(#(i,j)√∑‚à£D‚à£k(#(i)√∑‚à£D‚à£)(#(j)√∑‚à£D‚à£))#(i,j)√∑‚à£D‚à£=12T‚àër=1T(#(i,j)r‚Üí‚à£D‚à£r‚Üí+#(i,j)r‚Üê‚à£D‚à£r‚Üê)\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|}{k(\#(i)\div|\mathcal D|)(\#(j)\div|\mathcal D|)}\right)\\\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}+\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\right)log(k#(i)#(j)#(i,j)‚à£D‚à£‚Äã)=log(k(#(i)√∑‚à£D‚à£)(#(j)√∑‚à£D‚à£)#(i,j)√∑‚à£D‚à£‚Äã)#(i,j)√∑‚à£D‚à£=2T1‚Äãr=1‚àëT‚Äã(‚à£D‚à£r‚Üí‚Äã#(i,j)r‚Üí‚Äã‚Äã+‚à£D‚à£r‚Üê‚Äã#(i,j)r‚Üê‚Äã‚Äã)

    where the latter observation comes from ‚à£Dr‚Üí‚à£/‚à£D‚à£=‚à£Dr‚Üê‚à£/‚à£D‚à£=12T|\mathcal D_{r\rarr}|/|\mathcal D|=|\mathcal D_{r\larr}|/|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}‚à£Dr‚Üí‚Äã‚à£/‚à£D‚à£=‚à£Dr‚Üê‚Äã‚à£/‚à£D‚à£=2T1‚Äã.

  • The observe what happens as the length of random walk L‚Üí‚àûL\rarr\infty%L‚Üí‚àû. We first define the random walk matrix P=Œî‚àí1A\mathbf P=\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf AP=Œî‚àí1A. The volume of a graph GGG is the sum of the entries of adjacency matrix vol(G)=‚àëi‚àëjai,j\text{vol}(G)=\sum_i\sum_ja_{i,j}vol(G)=‚àëi‚Äã‚àëj‚Äãai,j‚Äã. There are 3 important Lemmas:

    \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}\and \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\\\frac{\#(i,j)}{|\mathcal D|}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)\\\frac{\#(i,j)|D|}{\#(w),\#(c)}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{2T}\left(\frac{1}{d_j}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{1}{d_i}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)

  • Putting all together we obtain DeepWalk with infinite length random walks converges to

    log‚Å°(vol(G)k(1T‚àër=1T(Œî‚àí1A)r)Œî‚àí1)\log\left(\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{k}(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf A)^r)\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\right)log(kvol(G)‚Äã(T1‚Äãr=1‚àëT‚Äã(Œî‚àí1A)r)Œî‚àí1)

    Notice that the internal sum reminds close to a random walk iteration as the power of matrix Œî‚àí1A\mathbf \Delta^{-1}\mathbf AŒî‚àí1A encodes the probability of reaching nodes in rrr steps through random walking the graph. By factorizing such a similarity with SVD we can obtain the desired result that approximates the embeddings of a random-walk approach.

Graph Neural Network

abbr GNN

An architecture that allows nodes to propagate information to the neighbors in a non-linear manner. We have an attributed graph G=(V,E,X)G=(V,E,\mathbf X)G=(V,E,X) with matrix of node features X‚ààRm√ón\mathbf X\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}X‚ààRm√ón. (such a matrix encodes nodes attributes such as labels, profiles or characteristics)

The main ingredient of a GNN is the aggregation function that takes in input the features from the neighbors of a node iii and finds an embedding hi\mathbf h_ihi‚Äã.

Neighborhood Aggregation

Main idea: Generate node embeddings based on local neighborhoods of each node, using neural networks to represent the complex relationships of a graph.

Intuitively, think of the neighbors as a computational graph of a Neural Network.

The embeddings in the layer lll is an aggregation of the embeddings in layer l‚àí1l-1l‚àí1.

How to aggregate information across the layers? A simple approach: average neighbor information and apply a neural network.

The embeddings of the initial layer 000 are the attributes zi0=zi\mathbf z_i^0=\mathbf z_izi0‚Äã=zi‚Äã. The lll-th layer embedding of iii is

zil=œÉ(Wl‚àëj‚ààN(i)zjl‚àí1‚à£N(i)‚à£+Blzil‚àí1),‚àÄt>0\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{|N(i)|}+\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}),\forall t\gt0zil‚Äã=œÉ(Wl‚Äãj‚ààN(i)‚àë‚Äã‚à£N(i)‚à£zjl‚àí1‚Äã‚Äã+Bl‚Äãzil‚àí1‚Äã),‚àÄt>0

œÉ\sigmaœÉ is non-linear activation function. The sum is the average of each neighbor‚Äôs embeddings compute in layer l‚àí1l-1l‚àí1.

Loss function. W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B are the trainable weight matrices. After kkk-layers of neighborhood aggregation, we get output embeddings for each node. Loss function needs non-linear and differentiable.

We optimize the parameters of model through stochastic gradient descent SGD.

Rewrite model in matrix notation

Zl+1=œÉ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1l)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l+\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l_1)Zl+1=œÉ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1l‚Äã)

where A~=Œî‚àí1/2AŒî‚àí1/2\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf {A\Delta}^{-1/2}A~=Œî‚àí1/2AŒî‚àí1/2. To optimize the parameters, a cross-entropy loss function would work in a supervised setting w.r.t. node‚Äôs labels.

An important properties of models: ability to share the parameters W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B and allow for generalization to unseen nodes, edges or graphs.

Depend on loss function and embedding matrix, the GNN can learn node embeddings, graph embeddings or clusters.

Graph Convolutional Networks

abbr. GCN

A different neighbor aggragation

zil=œÉ(Wl‚àëj‚ààN(i)‚à™izjl‚àí1‚à£N(i)‚à£‚à£N(j)‚à£).\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma\left(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)\cup i}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{\sqrt{|N(i)||N(j)|}}\right).zil‚Äã=œÉ‚éù‚éõ‚ÄãWl‚Äãj‚ààN(i)‚à™i‚àë‚Äã‚à£N(i)‚à£‚à£N(j)‚à£‚Äãzjl‚àí1‚Äã‚Äã‚é†‚éû‚Äã.

The main idea is node with a large number of connections should be less important. There is no need for the bias term B\mathbf BB and the per-neighbor normalization.

Normalization empirically attains better results and better parameter sharing. We can efficiently compute the embeddings using sparse batch operations

Zl+1=œÉ(Œî‚àí1/2A~Œî‚àí1/2ZlWl)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W_l)Zl+1=œÉ(Œî‚àí1/2A~Œî‚àí1/2ZlWl‚Äã)

where A~=A+I\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf A+\mathbf IA~=A+I and Œ¥\deltaŒ¥ is the diagonal degree matrix. The time complexity to propagate the information is O(‚à£E‚à£)\mathcal O(|E|)O(‚à£E‚à£).

GraphSAGE

Instead of fixed aggregation, GraphSAGE use any differentiable function that maps set of vectors to a single vector. So, if we use a generalized aggregation, we get

zil=œÉ([Wl‚ãÖAGG({zjl‚àí1,‚àÄj‚ààN(i)}),Blzil‚àí1])\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma([\mathbf W_l\cdot AGG(\{\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\}),\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}])zil‚Äã=œÉ([Wl‚Äã‚ãÖAGG({zjl‚àí1‚Äã,‚àÄj‚ààN(i)}),Bl‚Äãzil‚àí1‚Äã])

Concentrate self embedding of neighbor embedding. Also we use a generalized aggregation.

Some variants:

  • Mean. Take weighted average of neighbors:

    AGG=‚àëj‚ààN(i)zjl‚àí1N(i)AGG=\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{N(i)}AGG=j‚ààN(i)‚àë‚ÄãN(i)zjl‚àí1‚Äã‚Äã

  • Pool. Transform neighbor vectors and apply symmetric vector function:

    AGG=Œ≥({Qzjl‚àí1,‚àÄj‚ààN(i)})AGG=\gamma(\{\mathbf{Qz}_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\})AGG=Œ≥({Qzjl‚àí1‚Äã,‚àÄj‚ààN(i)})

    where we take element-wise mean/max

  • LSTM. Apply LSTM to reshuffled neighbors œÄ(N(i))\pi(N(i))œÄ(N(i))

    AGG=LSTM([zjl‚àí1,‚àÄj‚ààœÄ(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in\pi(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([zjl‚àí1‚Äã,‚àÄj‚ààœÄ(N(i))])
entry.summary:
GNN - graph neural networks

Intuition: how to propagate information over the neighbors in a non-linear manner.

ÂÜô‰ΩúÁªÉ‰π† Seite 93

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

mit gro√üen Interesse habe ich Ihren Artikel ‚ÄûWissenschaftler fordern Mittagsschlaf im B√ºro‚Äú gelesen.

Ich bin der Meinung, dass das Schlafen am Arbeitsplatz sehr wichtig ist, denn dadurch k√∂nnen die Mitarbeiter ihre Leistung ÊïàÁéá wiedererlangen ÊÅ¢Â§ç und fit an die Arbeit zur√ºckkehren ÂõûÂΩí.

Der Mittagsschlaf im B√ºro sollte nicht nur erlaubt, sondern auch gef√∂rdert werden.

Im Folgenden m√∂chte ich meine Meinung dazu einmal erl√§utern Ëß£Èáä. Laut zahlreichen Studien ist der Mittagsschlaf vorteilhaft ÊúâÁõäÁöÑ, wie folgende Beispiele zeigen/verdeutlichen:

Schon nach 20 Minuten Mittagsruhe zeigen sich positive Auswirkungen auf den K√∂rper: Der Blutdruck sinkt, die Muskeln entspannen sich, Stresshormone werden abgebaut.

Au√üerdem wurde auch bewiesen, dass er zu wenig schl√§ft, laut Medizinern, h√§ufiger Fehler bei der Arbeit macht.

Deswegen sollte der Mittagsschlaf in Deutschland eigentlich √ºblich sein. Aber f√ºr die meisten kommt ein Mittagsschlaf √ºberhaupt nicht in Frage ‰∏çÂú®ËÄÉËôëËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖ, weil sie furchten, als faul zu gelten.

Es ist tats√§chlich schwer den Minischlaf oder Kurzschlaf in Betrieben einzuf√ºhren ÈááÁî®. In Deutschland hat man im Durchschnitt 30 Minuten Mittagspause. Gerade lang genug f√ºr das Mittagessen. Nach dem Essen geht es direkt wieder an die Arbeit. Doch so kurz nach dem Essen, f√§llt sich schwer auf seine Arbeit zu konzentrieren.

Wenn es m√∂glich w√§re, w√ºrde ich auf jeden Fall einen Mittagsschlaf machen.‚Äô

Abschlie√üend m√∂chte ich nochmals betonen, dass sich Mittagsschlaf positiv auf die Leistungsf√§higkeit auswirkt und gesund ist. In Unternehmen sollte der Mittagsschlaf eingesetzt und gleichzeitig gef√∂rdert werden.

entry.title: Fair Division 6 Computing EF1 + PO
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate methods for computing allocations satisfying both EF1 and PO.

Activities: Review the paper Finding Fair and Efficient Allocations.

Caragiannis et al has established the result: for additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 + PO by maximizing Nash Social Welfare.

However, computing MNW is NP-Hard.

This paper:

  1. develop a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm for finding EF1 + PO. When valuations are bounded, the algorithm is polynomial time.
  2. For additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally Pareto Efficient.
  3. The algorithm provides a polynomial time 1.451.451.45-approximation to the Nash social welfare objective.
  4. The algorithm is completely combinatorial, and relies on constructing integral Fisher market wherein specific equilibria are not only efficient, but also fair.

~~This paper is very difficult and I felt suffocated while reading it.~~ü§°ü§°ü§°

Introduction

Caragiannis showed by maximizing Nash Welfare, the geometric mean of the agents‚Äô valuations is both fair (EF1) and Pareto efficient. However, maximizing the Nash welfare is an NP-hard problem (more accurately, APX-hard)

This paper provides a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm for finding an EF1 and Pareto Optimal allocation of indivisible goods under additive valuations.

In particular, if the valuations are scaled, the algorithm finds such an allocation in polynomial time.

Maximizing Nash welfare remains APX-hard even for bounded valuations.

Related problem: approximation algorithm for Nash welfare maximization. But approximating Maximal Nash welfare is not guaranteed to be EF1 or Pareto optimal.

This algorithm provides a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation to the Maximal Nash welfare problem. SOTA! It is also guaranteed to return a fair and efficient outcome.

Contributions

  1. Pseudo-polynomial for unscaled valuation and polynomial for scaled valuation. Computing EF1 + PO allocations. This algorithm can find an approximate EF1 and approximate PO allocation without scaled valuations.

  2. Stronger existence results. For additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally Pareto efficient.

    There exists a non-deterministic polynomial time algorithm for finding EF1 + PO.

    Whereas even verifying whether an arbitrary allocation is PO is known to be co-NP-complete.

  3. Polynomial time 1.451.451.45-approximation for the Nash social welfare maximization.

    Interesting byproduct: under same valuations, EF1 allocation provides a 1.451.451.45-approximation to the MNW.

Techniques

Fisher market along with an underlying equilibrium which is integral and EF1.

Start with a Pareto Optimal allocation, then iteratively modify the allocation by exchanging goods between the agents. The goal of the exchange step is to move toward a fair allocation. Stop when the equilibrium of the market satisfies price envy-freeness up to one good.

First the algorithm works with an integral Fisher market at every step, breaking away from the standard relax-and-round paradigm where a fractional market equilibrium is first computed followed by round step. Second, the algorithm uses the notion of price envy-freeness up to one good as a measure of balanced spending in the Fisher market. The notion is novel.

Preliminaries

The Fair Division Model

Problem Instance

Omitted!!!

Valuations are non-negative, additive.

For single item jjj, denote iii‚Äôs valuation for it as vi,j=vi({j})v_{i,j}=v_i(\{j\})vi,j‚Äã=vi‚Äã({j})

Denote v_\max=\max_{i\in[n],j\in[m]}v_i(j)=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Allocation

Allocation: Omitted!!!

Fractional allocation: For all agents, no more than one unit of each good is allocated:

‚àëi‚àà[n]xi,j‚â§1\sum_{i\in[n]}x_{i,j}\le1i‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãxi,j‚Äã‚â§1

Fairness Notions

EF, EF1

œµ\epsilonœµ-EF1: for every pair of agent i,k‚àà[n]i,k\in[n]i,k‚àà[n], there exists a good j‚ààxkj\in\mathbf x_kj‚ààxk‚Äã s.t.

(1+œµ)vi(xi)‚â•vi(xk‚ï≤{j})(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbb x_i)\ge v_i(\mathbb x_k\diagdown\{j\})(1+œµ)vi‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})

Nash social welfare

NSW(x)=(‚àèi‚àà[n]vi(xi))1/nNSW(\mathbf x)=(\prod_{i\in[n]}v_i(\mathbf x_i))^{1/n}NSW(x)=(i‚àà[n]‚àè‚Äãvi‚Äã(xi‚Äã))1/n

It is okay to ignore the 1/n1/n1/n power.

x‚àó‚ààarg‚Å°max‚Å°x‚ààXNSW(x)\mathbf x^*\in\arg\max_{\mathbf x\in\mathcal X}NSW(\mathbf x)x‚àó‚ààargmaxx‚ààX‚ÄãNSW(x)

Efficiency Notions

Pareto Efficiency.

x\mathbf xx is Pareto dominated by another allocation y\mathbf yy if vk(yk)‚â•vk(xk)v_k(\mathbf y_k)\ge v_k(\mathbf x_k)vk‚Äã(yk‚Äã)‚â•vk‚Äã(xk‚Äã) for every agent k‚àà[n]k\in[n]k‚àà[n], and some of them is >\gt>.

An allocation is said to be Pareto efficient or Pareto optimal if it is not Pareto dominated by any other allocation. Similarly, x\mathbf xx is œµ\epsilonœµ-PO if it is not œµ\epsilonœµ-PO dominated by any other allocation (vk(yk)‚â•(1+œµ)vk(xk)v_k(\mathbf y_k)\ge(1+\epsilon)v_k(\mathbf x_k)vk‚Äã(yk‚Äã)‚â•(1+œµ)vk‚Äã(xk‚Äã), for some kkk the inequalities are strict).

Fractional Pareto Efficiency. If it is not Pareto dominated by any fractional allocation.

fractionally PO ‚áí\Rarr‚áí PO, but PO ‚áíÃ∏\not\RarrÓÄ†‚áí fractionally PO.

Main Results

Algorithm computes EF1 + PO

üéØü§îTheorem 1.

Given any fair division instance I\mathcal II with additive valuations, an allocation that is EF1 and PO can be found in O(poly(m,n,vmax‚Å°))\mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,v_{\max}))O(poly(m,n,vmax‚Äã)) time, where v_\max=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Remark: If v_\max is polynomial bounded by f(m,n)f(m,n)f(m,n), the EF1 + PO can be computed in polynomial time.

If we relax the fairness and efficiency requirements to approximate versions, then the algorithm is guaranteed to run in polynomial time.

œµ\epsilonœµ-EF1 + œµ\epsilonœµ-PO in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max))

Existence for EF1 and fractionally PO

üéØü§îTheorem 2. Given any fair division instance with additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally PO (fPO)

Remark: üò≠ I don‚Äôt understand. What is TFNP (Total Function Nondeterministic Polynomial)?

A binary relation P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) is in TFNP if and only if there is a deterministic polynomial time algorithm that can determine whether P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) holds given both xxx and yyy, and for every xxx, there exists a yyy which is at most polynomially longer than xxx such that P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) holds.

Approximation algorithm for Nash social welfare

üéØü§îTheorem 3. For additive valuations, there exists a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for the Nash social welfare maximization problem.

ü§îLemma 1. Given a fair division instance with identical and additive valuations, any œµ\epsilonœµ-EF1 allocations provides a e(1+œµ)ee^{(1+\epsilon)e}e(1+œµ)e-approximation to Nash social welfare.

The Algorithm

Market Terminology

Fisher Market

A fundamental model in the economics of resource allocation.

A set of buyers enter the market with pre-specified budgets and use it to buy goods that provide maximum utility per unit of money spent.

[n][n][n] buyers, [m][m][m] divisible goods, valuation profile V\mathcal VV.

Each buyer i‚àà[n]i\in[n]i‚àà[n] has an initial endowment/budget ei>0e_i\gt0ei‚Äã>0. The endowment is only used for buying goods. Endowment vector e\mathbf ee.

Fisher market equilibrium. An outcome ‚ü®x,p‚ü©\langle\mathbf x,\mathbf p\rangle‚ü®x,p‚ü© satisfies the following conditions:

Price envy-freeness and its variants

  • x\mathbf xx is price envy-free (pEF) w.r.t. p\mathbf pp if for every pair of buyers i,k‚àà[n]i,k\in[n]i,k‚àà[n], we have p(xi)‚â•p(xk)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k)p(xi‚Äã)‚â•p(xk‚Äã). (Equivalently, ===)

Hierarchy structure

  • Let GGG denote the augmented MBB graph for a Fisher market instance with the market outcome (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p).

  • Fix a source agent i‚àà[n]i\in[n]i‚àà[n] in GGG. Define the level of an agent kkk as half the length of the shortest alternating path from iii to kkk. The level of the source agent iii is defined to be 000. If there is no alternating path from iii to some agent kkk in GGG, then the level of kkk is set to be nnn. The hierarchy structure Hi\mathcal H_iHi‚Äã of agent iii is defined as a level-wise collection of all agents that are reachable from iii, where Hi‚Ñì\mathcal H_i^\ellHi‚Ñì‚Äã denotes the set of agents that are at level ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì w.r.t. the agent iii. BuildHierarchy is used for constructing such a hierarchy.

    In a hierarchy cannot have edges between agents at the same level.

Violators

  • An agent iii with smallest spending money among all the agents is called least spender, i.e., i‚ààarg‚Å°min‚Å°k‚àà[n]p(xk)i\in\arg\min_{k\in[n]}\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k)i‚ààargmink‚àà[n]‚Äãp(xk‚Äã). An agent k‚àà[n]k\in[n]k‚àà[n] is said to be a violator if for every good j‚ààxkj\in\mathbf x_kj‚ààxk‚Äã, we have p(xk‚ï≤{j})>p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\gt\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})>p(xi‚Äã), where iii is the least spender.

  • Analogously, kkk is said to be œµ\epsilonœµ-violator if for every good j‚ààxkj\in\mathbf x_kj‚ààxk‚Äã, we have p(xk‚ï≤{j})>(1+œµ)p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\gt(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})>(1+œµ)p(xi‚Äã). An agent can be a violator without being an œµ\epsilonœµ violator.

Path-violator

  • Let iii denote the least spender, and let Hi\mathcal H_iHi‚Äã denote the hierarchy of agent iii. An agent k‚ààHik\in\mathcal H_ik‚ààHi‚Äã is said to be path-violator w.r.t. the alternating path P=(i,j1,i1,j2,i2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,i‚Ñì‚àí1,j‚Ñì,k)P=(i,j_1,i_1,j_2,i_2,\cdots,i_{\ell-1},j_\ell,k)P=(i,j1‚Äã,i1‚Äã,j2‚Äã,i2‚Äã,‚ãØ,i‚Ñì‚àí1‚Äã,j‚Ñì‚Äã,k) if p(xk‚ï≤{j‚Ñì})>p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j_\ell\})\gt\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j‚Ñì‚Äã})>p(xi‚Äã).
  • A path-violator need not be a violator, since there can be a good j‚ààxkj\in\mathbf x_kj‚ààxk‚Äã not on the path PPP s.t. p(xk‚ï≤{j})‚â§p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\le\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})‚â§p(xi‚Äã). Similarly, an agent k‚ààHik\in\mathcal H_ik‚ààHi‚Äã is said to be an œµ\epsilonœµ-path-violator w.r.t. PPP if p(xk‚ï≤{j‚Ñì})>(1+œµ)p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j_\ell\})\gt(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j‚Ñì‚Äã})>(1+œµ)p(xi‚Äã).

Description of the Algorithm

Given any fair division instance III as input and a parameter œµ>0\epsilon\gt0œµ>0. constructs a market equilibrium (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) w.r.t. a Fisher market instance ‚ü®[n],[m],V,e‚ü©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V,\mathbf e\rangle‚ü®[n],[m],V,e‚ü©. The pair (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) has the following two properties:

  1. x\mathbf xx is an integral allocation.

  2. x\mathcal xx is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp.

    This shows that the allocation x\mathbf xx is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-EF1 for the corresponding fair division instance I\mathcal II.

By proposition 1, the allocation x\mathbf xx is guaranteed to be fractionally Pareto Optimal for the Fisher market instance, and consequently for the fair division instance I\mathcal II.

ü§îLemma 2. Let œµ>0\epsilon\gt0œµ>0, and let x\mathbf xx and p\mathbf pp be an allocation and a price vector respectively for a market instance ‚ü®[n],[m],V,e‚ü©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V,\mathbf e\rangle‚ü®[n],[m],V,e‚ü© s.t.

  1. x\mathbf xx is œµ\epsilonœµ-pEF1.
  2. xi‚ààMBBi\mathbf x_i\in MBB_ixi‚Äã‚ààMBBi‚Äã for each player i‚àà[n]i\in[n]i‚àà[n].

Then, x\mathbf xx is œµ\epsilonœµ-EF1 for the associated fair division instance ‚ü®[n],[m],V‚ü©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V\rangle‚ü®[n],[m],V‚ü©.

Since x\mathbf xx is œµ\epsilonœµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp, for any pair of buyers i,k‚àà[n]i,k\in[n]i,k‚àà[n], ‚àÉj‚ààxk\exist j\in\mathbf x_k‚àÉj‚ààxk‚Äã s.t. (1+œµ)p(xi)‚â•p(xk‚ï≤{j})(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})(1+œµ)p(xi‚Äã)‚â•p(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j}).

Multiplying both sides with maximum bang per ratio Œ±i\alpha_iŒ±i‚Äã for agent iii, we have

Œ±i(1+œµ)p(xi)‚â•Œ±ip(xk‚ï≤{j})‚áí(1+œµ)vi(xi)‚â•Œ±ip(xk‚ï≤{j})‚àµxi‚äÜMBBi‚áí(1+œµ)vi(xi)‚â•vi(xk‚ï≤{j}),\alpha_i(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\alpha_i\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\\\Rarr(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbf x_i)\ge\alpha_i\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\because\mathbf x_i\subseteq MBB_i\\\Rarr(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbf x_i)\ge v_i(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\}),Œ±i‚Äã(1+œµ)p(xi‚Äã)‚â•Œ±i‚Äãp(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})‚áí(1+œµ)vi‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚â•Œ±i‚Äãp(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j})‚àµxi‚Äã‚äÜMBBi‚Äã‚áí(1+œµ)vi‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚â•vi‚Äã(xk‚Äã‚ï≤{j}),

which is the œµ\epsilonœµ-EF1 guarantee for the allocation x\mathbf xx.

The algorithm‚Äôs behavior:

  • Phase 1: starts with a welfare maximizing allocation x\mathbf xx and p\mathbf pp s.t. x\mathbf xx is fPO and each agent gets a subset of its MBB goods. If the allocation x\mathbf xx is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp, then the algorithm terminates with the output (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p). Otherwise, goto phase 2.

  • Phase 2: the algorithm works with hierarchy of the least spending agent, and performs a series of exchanges (or swaps) of goods between the agents in the hierarchy. The swaps are aimed at ensuring that at the end of Phase 2, no agent in the hierarchy is œµ\epsilonœµ-pEF1 envied by the least spender.

    All exchanges happen only along the MBB edges, thus maintaining at each stage the condition that x\mathbf xx is an equilibrium allocation, and hence fPO.

    If at the end of Phase 2, the current allocation x\mathbf xx is still not 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1 w.r.t. the price vector p\mathbf pp, the algorithm move to Phase 3.

  • Phase 3: Uniformly raising the price of the goods owned by the members of the hierarchy. The price are raised until either the allocation x\mathbf xx becomes 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1 w.r.t. the new price vector p\mathbf pp, or a new agent gets added to the hierarchy. In the latter case, the algorithm goes back to the start of Phase 2.

Establishing the time complexity for this algorithm is complicated. The stated running time bound is obtained via a number of involved arguments relying on analyzing the spending of the agents in different phases.

Analysis of ALG when the Valuations are power-of-(1+Œµ)

power-of-(1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ): ‚àÉœµ>0\exist\epsilon\gt0‚àÉœµ>0, s.t. ‚àÄi‚àà[n],j‚àà[m]:vi,j‚àà{0,(1+œµ)a}\forall i\in[n],j\in[m]:v_{i,j}\in\{0,(1+\epsilon)^a\}‚àÄi‚àà[n],j‚àà[m]:vi,j‚Äã‚àà{0,(1+œµ)a} for some natural number aaa.

  1. Swap in Phase 2

  4. Termination step.

Denote time step the indexing of any execution of ALG.

ü§îLemma 3. Given any power-of-(1+œµ1+\epsilon1+œµ) instance as input, the allocation returned by ALG is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-EF1 and fPO.

fPO: observation: at each step, the allocation of any agent is a subset of its MMB goods.

Step 1: true (by way of setting prices).

Step 2: swap operation only happens along an alternating MBB-allocation edge which maintains MBB condition.

Step 3: raising the prices of goods owned by the members of hierarchy Hi\mathcal H_iHi‚Äã without changing the allocation. ARGUMENT

Then define a Fisher market where each agent‚Äôs endowment equals its spending under x\mathbf xx. Since (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) is an equilibrium, x\mathbf xx is fPO.

Next, argue that x\mathbf xx is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-EF1. The ALG terminates only if either 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1, or Œ±=Œ±2\alpha=\alpha_2Œ±=Œ±2‚Äã. If Œ±=Œ±2\alpha=\alpha_2Œ±=Œ±2‚Äã, we need to argue it‚Äôs 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-pEF1. omitted

ü§îLemma 4. Given any power-of-(1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ) instance as input, ALG terminates in time \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) where v_\max=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Proof omitted.

Analysis of ALG for General Valuations: Proof of Theorem 1

Show that for any given fair division instance I\mathcal II with integral valuations, EF1 + PO allocation can be found in pseudo-polynomial time.

Proof by running ALG on œµ\epsilonœµ-rounded version I‚Ä≤=‚ü®[n],[m],V‚Ä≤‚ü©\mathcal I'=\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V'\rangleI‚Ä≤=‚ü®[n],[m],V‚Ä≤‚ü© of the given instance I\mathcal II for some parameter œµ>0\epsilon\gt0œµ>0. The I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ is a power-of-(1+œµ1+\epsilon1+œµ) instance constructed by rounding up the valuations in I\mathcal II to the nearest integer power of (1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ). From Lemma 3, we know this allocation is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-EF1 and fPO w.r.t. I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤. Then it remians to show that for an appropriate choice of œµ\epsilonœµ, the same allocation turns out to be EF1 + PO w.r.t. I\mathcal II.

In addition, the running time bound in Lemma 4 instantiated for the choice of œµ\epsilonœµ shows that ALG runs in pseudo-polynomial time.

œµ\epsilonœµ-rounded version:

for each agent iii, the valuation is replaced by

vi,j‚Ä≤={(1+œµ)‚åàlog‚Å°1+œµvi,j‚åâ¬†if¬†vi,j>00¬†if¬†vi,j=0v'_{i,j}=\begin{cases}(1+\epsilon)^{\lceil\log_{1+\epsilon}v_{i,j}\rceil}\text{ if }v_{i,j}\gt0\\0\text{ if }v_{i,j}=0\end{cases}vi,j‚Ä≤‚Äã={(1+œµ)‚åàlog1+œµ‚Äãvi,j‚Äã‚åâ¬†if¬†vi,j‚Äã>00¬†if¬†vi,j‚Äã=0‚Äã

vi,j‚â§vi,j‚Ä≤‚â§(1+œµ)vi,jv_{i,j}\le v'_{i,j}\le(1+\epsilon)v_{i,j}vi,j‚Äã‚â§vi,j‚Ä≤‚Äã‚â§(1+œµ)vi,j‚Äã for each i,ji,ji,j.

ü§îLemma 5. Let I\mathcal II be a fair division instance. Let \epsilon\le\frac{1}{6m^3v^4_\max}. Then, an allocation x\mathbf xx that is fPO for I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ is PO for I\mathcal II.

Lemma 5 establishes for an appropriate choice of œµ\epsilonœµ, an allocation that is fPO for the œµ\epsilonœµ-rounded instance I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ is PO w.r.t. the original instance I\mathcal II.

ü§îLemma 6. Let I\mathcal II be a fair division instance, and let 0\lt\delta\lt\frac{1}{2mv_\max} Then, an allocation x\mathbf xx is Œ¥\deltaŒ¥-EF1 for I\mathcal II iff it is EF1 for I\mathcal II.

Omitted.

The proof of Theorem 1:

  • I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ is œµ\epsilonœµ-rounded version of I\mathcal II with \epsilon=\frac{1}{14m^3v^4_\max}. From Lemma 3 and 4, x\mathcal xx is 3œµ3\epsilon3œµ-EF1 and fPO for I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ can be found in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) time.
  • Under this choice, by lemma 5, x\mathbf xx must be PO for I\mathcal II. Thus x\mathbf xx is EF1.

ü§îLemma 7. Given the œµ\epsilonœµ-rounded version I‚Ä≤\mathcal I'I‚Ä≤ as input, ALG finds a 7œµ7\epsilon7œµ-EF1 and œµ\epsilonœµ-PO allocation for I\mathcal II in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) time.

I am lost.

Theorem 2 EF1+fPO

üéØü§îTheorem 2. Given any fair division instance with additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fPO.

\epsilon_z=\frac{1}{14zm^3v^4_\max},z\in\mathbb N.

Suffocating.

Theorem 3 Nash Social Welfare Approximation

ALG provides 1.45‚âàe1/e1.45\approx e^{1/e}1.45‚âàe1/e-approximation for Nash social welfare maximization in polynomial time.

Use lemma 8 to prove lemma 1.

ü§îLemma 8. Let I\mathcal II be an instance with additive and identical valuation functions s.t. m‚â•nm\ge nm‚â•n. Let B‚äÇ[m]B\sub[m]B‚äÇ[m] be a subset of goods s.t. ‚à£B‚à£<n|B|\lt n‚à£B‚à£<n. Then, there is a partially-fractional allocation œâ‚ààFB\omega\in\mathcal F_Bœâ‚ààFB‚Äã that maximize Nash social welfare among allocations in FB\mathcal F_BFB‚Äã s.t.

  1. Each agent gets at most one goods from BBB under œâ\omegaœâ.
  2. Any agent with strictly-better-than-the-worst allocation under œâ\omegaœâ gets exactly one integral good. That is, for any agent i‚àà[n]i\in[n]i‚àà[n] s.t. v(œâi)>min‚Å°kv(œâk)v(\omega_i)\gt\min_kv(\omega_k)v(œâi‚Äã)>mink‚Äãv(œâk‚Äã), we have œâi,j=1\omega_{i,j}=1œâi,j‚Äã=1 for some j‚ààBj\in Bj‚ààB and œâi,j‚Ä≤=0\omega_{i,j'}=0œâi,j‚Ä≤‚Äã=0 for all j‚Ä≤‚â†jj'\neq jj‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=j.

Property 2. proved by contradiction.

Property 1. proved by swap operation.

Proof of lemma 1: Too difficult.

üéØü§îTheorem 3. For additive valuations, there exists a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for the Nash social welfare maximization problem.

omitted.

Conclusion

Based on integral Fisher markets and approximate pEF condition

Psudo-polynomial algorithm for finding EF1 and PO

Poly time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for Nash social welfare.

Future work:

  • Does there exist polynomial time algorithm for EF1 + PO?
  • How about more general classes of valuations?
entry.summary:
Objective: Investigate methods for computing allocations satisfying both EF1 and PO.

Activities: Review the paper

entry.title: Êï∞ÊçÆÊåñÊéò 9 Graph Embedding
entry.content:
Main problem with graphs: lack of predefined node ordering.

Graph is non-Euclidean: the distance among two nodes does not depend on the coordinates of the nodes.

Origin idea of graph embedding: graph could become a set of multi-dimensional points in which Euclidean distances represent similarities among the nodes.

2 methods of embedding:

  1. Linear embedding: linear transformation of the edges.
  2. Random-walk embedding: preserving the probability that a node is reachable from another node.

Linear Embeddings

Simplest form of graph embeddings.

Let zi‚ààRd\mathbf z_i\in\mathbb R^dzi‚Äã‚ààRd the embedding vector of the node iii.

The similarity between vector zi,zj\mathbf z_i,\mathbf z_jzi‚Äã,zj‚Äã is sim(i,j)‚âàzi‚ä§‚ãÖzjsim(i,j)\approx\mathbf z_i^\top\cdot\mathbf z_jsim(i,j)‚âàzi‚ä§‚Äã‚ãÖzj‚Äã. If two nodes are ‚Äúclose‚Äù under some definition of similarity, they should be also similar in the embedding space.

To define embedding vectors, we need

  1. An encoder from nodes to the embedding space.
  2. A similarity among nodes in the graph.

Then we need to define an objective or loss function, s.t. the embeddings are the parameters of optimization. Depending on the loss function, we can then use the appropriate optimizer to find the embeddings zi\mathbf z_izi‚Äã

Shallow encoding. We define the embedding matrix Zn√ód\mathbf Z^{n\times d}Zn√ód in which row iii is the embedding zi\mathbf z_izi‚Äã of node iii. Given Z\mathbf ZZ we can encode each node in its corresponding embedding by a lookup on the embedding matrix. Let v‚ààIn\mathbf v\in\mathbb I^nv‚ààIn the indicator vector that has a 111 in position iii and 000 otherwise. Then

zi=Z‚ä§v\mathbf z_i=\mathbf Z^\top\mathbf vzi‚Äã=Z‚ä§v

Node similarity. Intuitively check whether two nodes connected, are far form each other in shortest-path, are reachable from random walk, or simply share any common information.

Adjacency-based Similarity

The simplest: two nodes are similar if they share an edge between them.

sim(i,j)=aijsim(i,j)=a_{ij}sim(i,j)=aij‚Äã implies the dot-product among the embedding vectors should approximate the entries of the adjacency matrix aij‚âàzi‚ä§zja_{ij}\approx\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jaij‚Äã‚âàzi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã.

We then find embedding that minimize the distance among the entries aija_{ij}aij‚Äã and the dot-product among the embedding vectors zi‚ä§zj\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jzi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã:

L=‚àë(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚à£zi‚ä§zj‚àíaij‚à£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-a_{ij}|^2L=(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚àë‚Äã‚à£zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã‚àíaij‚Äã‚à£2

which corresponds to the minimization of the norm between A\mathbf AA and the matrix ZZ‚ä§,‚à£‚à£ZZ‚ä§‚àíA‚à£‚à£F2\mathbf{ZZ^\top},||\mathbf{ZZ^\top-\mathbf A||}_F^2ZZ‚ä§,‚à£‚à£ZZ‚ä§‚àíA‚à£‚à£F2‚Äã.

In order to minimize the objective, we use gradient descent or matrix decomposition (such as SVD or QR-decomposition) on A\mathbf AA.

Pros and Cons

üëç

  1. The similarity function is straightforward
  2. Many methods for solving the optimization problem.

üëé

  1. O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2) running time to consider all pairs, O(‚à£E‚à£)\mathcal O(|E|)O(‚à£E‚à£) if we sum only over the non-zero entries.
  2. O(dn)\mathcal O(dn)O(dn) parameters, one vector for each node.
  3. Only consider direct and local connections through the adjacency matrix.

Multi-hop Similarity

Connections at distance kkk from a certain node to remedy to the strict requirements of the adjacency-based similarity.

The kkk-th power of the adjacency matrix captures kkk-hop connections. Indeed the position i,ji,ji,j in Ak\mathbf A^kAk represents the number of paths of lengths kkk from node iii to node jjj.

Similarly to the case above loss function minimizes the differences between the entry i,ji,ji,j in the kkk-th power of the adjacency matrix and the dot-product among the embedding vectors of the nodes i,ji,ji,j.

L=‚àë(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚à£zi‚ä§zj‚àíaijk‚à£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-a_{ij}^k|^2L=(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚àë‚Äã‚à£zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã‚àíaijk‚Äã‚à£2

Similarly, this corresponds to minimizing ‚à£‚à£Z‚ä§Z‚àíAk‚à£‚à£F2||\mathbf{Z^\top Z}-\mathbf A^k||_F^2‚à£‚à£Z‚ä§Z‚àíAk‚à£‚à£F2‚Äã. In practice, to avoid numerical explosion, GraRep use a log-transformed probabilistic adjacency matrix

a~ijk=max‚Å°{log‚Å°(aij/di‚àël‚ààV(alj/dl))k‚àíŒ±,0}\tilde a_{ij}^k=\max\{\log(\frac{a_{ij}/d_i}{\sum_{l\in V}(a_{lj}/d_l)})^k-\alpha,0\}a~ijk‚Äã=max{log(‚àël‚ààV‚Äã(alj‚Äã/dl‚Äã)aij‚Äã/di‚Äã‚Äã)k‚àíŒ±,0}

where ddd is node degree, and Œ±\alphaŒ± is a constant shift. GraRep trains embeddings with different kkk and concatenates the embedding vectors.

A more flexible option to capture multi-hop similarities relies on the overlap between node neighborhoods, using overlap functions such as Jaccard Similarity and Adamic-Adar score which is sij=‚àël‚ààN(i)‚à©N(j)1log‚Å°N(l)s_{ij}=\sum_{l\in N(i)\cap N(j)}\frac{1}{\log N(l)}sij‚Äã=‚àël‚ààN(i)‚à©N(j)‚ÄãlogN(l)1‚Äã. The loss function becomes

L=‚àë(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚à£zi‚ä§zj‚àísij‚à£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-s_{ij}|^2L=(i,j)‚ààV√óV‚àë‚Äã‚à£zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã‚àísij‚Äã‚à£2

One drawback with Linear embedding is, in their current form, they require to compute the pairwise similarities for all nodes, taking O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2) in the worst case. For large graphs, a quadratic complexity is not feasible. Moreover. we need to define the similarity beforehand.

Neural Embeddings

Alternative to the pairwise computation by exploiting the efficiency of probability distributions.

Random-walk based embeddings, non-linear similarity embeddings

Random Walk Embeddings

Let zi‚ä§zj\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jzi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã be the probability that node iii and node jjj co-occur in a random walk over the graph. We can estimate the probability of visiting node iii from node jjj using random-walk or methods like Personalized PageRank. If we sample a large enough number of random walks. the process converges to the PageRank.

Random walks are efficient as they do not require to traverse the entire graphs, they can be easily simulated and they converge to probability distributions.

Assume we have a strategy RRR to sample random walks. We can define our embedding algorithm:

  1. Run short random walk starting from each node using strategy RRR.

  2. For each node iii, collect NR(i)N_R(i)NR‚Äã(i), the multi-set of nodes visited on random walks starting from iii

  3. Optimize the embeddings according to

    L=‚àëi‚ààV‚àëj‚ààNR(i)‚àílog‚Å°(p(j‚à£zi))\mathcal L=\sum_{i\in V}\sum_{j\in N_R(i)}-\log(p(j|\mathbf z_i))L=i‚ààV‚àë‚Äãj‚ààNR‚Äã(i)‚àë‚Äã‚àílog(p(j‚à£zi‚Äã))

The optimization is to find embeddings that maximize the likelihood of random walk co-occurrences. We can parametrize p(j‚à£zi)p(j|\mathbf z_i)p(j‚à£zi‚Äã) by using softmax

p(j‚à£zi)=exp‚Å°(zi‚ä§zj)‚àël‚ààVexp‚Å°(zi‚ä§zl)p(j|\mathbf z_i)=\frac{\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}{\sum_{l\in V}\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_l)}p(j‚à£zi‚Äã)=‚àël‚ààV‚Äãexp(zi‚ä§‚Äãzl‚Äã)exp(zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã)‚Äã

The above loss can be optimized using gradient descent. However, the nested sum takes O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2), although the real bottleneck is the denominator of the probability, that sums over all nodes. One strategy to reduce the complexity is to employ a negative sampling approach.

Negative sampling treats the problem as a classification problem and splits the fraction into two parts.

log‚Å°exp‚Å°(zi‚ä§zj)‚àël‚ààVexp‚Å°(zi‚ä§zl)‚àºlog‚Å°(œÉ(zi‚ä§zj))‚àí‚àël=1klog‚Å°(zl‚ä§znl)\log\frac{\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}{\sum_{l\in V}\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_l)}\sim\log(\sigma(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j))-\sum_{l=1}^k\log(\mathbf z_l^\top\mathbf z_{n_l})log‚àël‚ààV‚Äãexp(zi‚ä§‚Äãzl‚Äã)exp(zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã)‚Äã‚àºlog(œÉ(zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã))‚àíl=1‚àëk‚Äãlog(zl‚ä§‚Äãznl‚Äã‚Äã)

where nl‚àºpVn_l\sim p_Vnl‚Äã‚àºpV‚Äã is a node sampled from a negative distribution pVp_VpV‚Äã over the nodes and œÉ\sigmaœÉ is the sigmoid function. A typical choice of the negative distribution is to sample negative nodes proportional to the degree of each node. The more we sample, the more robust is the approximation. A higher kkk corresponds to higher prior on negative events.

Pros and Cons

üëç

  1. Expressive and non-linear
  2. Scale up with sampling techniques

üëé

  1. Similarity is fixed to random walks

General Similarities

Another approach to graph embedding is to generalize the similarity-based approaches to any samplable similarity. An appealing choice for similarity is PPR. For a given restart vector v\mathbf vv for node iii the PPR r\mathbf rr is

ri=(I‚àíŒ±AŒî‚àí1)‚àí1(1‚àíŒ±)v\mathbf r_i=(\mathbf I-\alpha\mathbf{A\Delta}^{-1})^{-1}(1-\alpha)\mathbf vri‚Äã=(I‚àíŒ±AŒî‚àí1)‚àí1(1‚àíŒ±)v

from which we obtain the PPR-matrix

S=((1‚àíŒ±)I)(I‚àíŒ±AŒî‚àí1)‚àí1\mathbf S=((1-\alpha)\mathbf I)(\mathbf I-\alpha\mathbf{A\Delta}^{-1})^{-1}S=((1‚àíŒ±)I)(I‚àíŒ±AŒî‚àí1)‚àí1

where each row iii represents the PPR vector ri\mathbf r_iri‚Äã.

One choice to embed S\mathbf SS is to use SVD; however this embedding method is again linear. We instead consider each row Si\mathbf S_iSi‚Äã separately as probability distributions to reach any node from node iii. This is the approach of VERSE. VERSE computes the embedding matrix Z\mathbf ZZ to preserve the distribution of the similarities node by node.

VERSE optimize the KL-divergence between the distribution of node iii and node jjj, where the KL-divergence between distribution ppp and qqq is

D(p‚à£‚à£q)=‚àëxp(x)log‚Å°p(x)q(x),D(p||q)=\sum_xp(x)\log\frac{p(x)}{q(x)},D(p‚à£‚à£q)=x‚àë‚Äãp(x)logq(x)p(x)‚Äã,

Typically, with KL-divergence the distribution ppp is fixed and given as input, while the distribution qqq is the one to learn. If that is the case, in order to learn ppp, notice that

D(p‚à£‚à£q)=‚àëxp(x)log‚Å°p(x)‚àíp(x)log‚Å°q(x)D(p||q)=\sum_xp(x)\log p(x)-p(x)\log q(x)D(p‚à£‚à£q)=x‚àë‚Äãp(x)logp(x)‚àíp(x)logq(x)

Entropy of ppp minus Cross entropy

The first term, the entropy of ppp is constant if we minimize for qqq. So it suffices to reduce objective to ‚àí‚àëxp(x)log‚Å°q(x)-\sum_x p(x)\log q(x)‚àí‚àëx‚Äãp(x)logq(x).

For each node iii we can parametrize q(i)q(i)q(i) as the similarity one-to-all in embedding space given by softmax of the dot-product of the embeddings

sim(i,‚ãÖ)=exp‚Å°(Zzi)‚àëj=1nexp‚Å°(zi‚ä§zj)sim(i,\cdot)=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{Zz}_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^n\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}sim(i,‚ãÖ)=‚àëj=1n‚Äãexp(zi‚ä§‚Äãzj‚Äã)exp(Zzi‚Äã)‚Äã

Notice the numerator multiplies for the entire embedding matrix Z\mathbf ZZ. The final loss becomes

L=‚àí‚àëi‚ààVSilog‚Å°sim(v,‚ãÖ)\mathcal L=-\sum_{i\in V}\mathbf S_i\log sim(v,\cdot)L=‚àíi‚ààV‚àë‚ÄãSi‚Äãlogsim(v,‚ãÖ)

sim(i,‚ãÖ)sim(i,\cdot)sim(i,‚ãÖ) can benefit from a strategy similar to negative sampling. Another alternative is to use Noise Contrastive estimation and change the loss function into.

L=‚àëi‚àºP,j‚àºSi[log‚Å°p(D=1‚à£sim(i,j))+sEj~‚àºQ(i)log‚Å°p(D=0‚à£simE(i,j~))]\mathcal L=\sum_{i\sim\mathcal P,j\sim\mathbf S_i}[\log p(D=1|sim(i,j))+s\mathbb E_{\tilde j\sim Q(i)}\log p(D=0|sim_E(i,\tilde j))]L=i‚àºP,j‚àºSi‚Äã‚àë‚Äã[logp(D=1‚à£sim(i,j))+sEj~‚Äã‚àºQ(i)‚Äãlogp(D=0‚à£simE‚Äã(i,j~‚Äã))]
